**PRELIMINARY OFFERING MEMORANDUM** **IN THE UNITED STATES**


## Constellation Automotive Financing plc
#### £650,000,000 % Senior Secured Notes due 2027


Constellation Automotive Financing plc (the “Issuer”), a public limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, is offering
£650,000,000 aggregate principal amount of its % senior secured notes due 2027 (the “Notes”). The Issuer will pay interest on the Notes semi-annually
in arrear on each and, commencing on, 2021. The Notes will mature on, 2027. The Issuer is a wholly owned subsidiary of
Constellation Automotive Group Limited (the “Parent”), a private limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales. The gross
proceeds from the offering of the Notes (the “Offering”) will be used, together with the proceeds from other financing transactions described herein, to
(i) repay in full the outstanding borrowings under the Existing Senior Term Loan Facilities, the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, the Existing Second
Lien Facility and the Existing Liquidity Facility (each as defined herein) (together, the “Existing Facilities”), (ii) make a distribution to the direct parent
company of the Parent and (iii) pay costs, fees and expenses (including prepayment costs) incurred in connection with the Refinancing Transactions (as
defined herein). See “Use of Proceeds.”
The Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at any time prior to, 2023 at a redemption price equal to 100% of the
principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts (as defined herein), if any, to, but excluding, the
date of redemption, plus the applicable “make whole”premium as set forth in this preliminary offering memorandum (this “Offering Memorandum”). At
any time prior to 2023, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes may be redeemed with the net proceeds of one or more specified equity
offerings at a redemption price equal to %, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of
redemption, provided that at least 50% of the aggregate principal amount (including any additional Notes) remains outstanding after the redemption
(unless all Notes are redeemed substantially concurrently). At any time prior to, 2023, the Issuer may also redeem during each calendar year
commencing with the Issue Date (as defined herein) up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes outstanding, at its option, from time to
time, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if
any. The Notes may be redeemed at any time on or after, 2023 at the redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum, plus accrued and
unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. The Issuer may also redeem all, but not part, of the Notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal
amount plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, upon the occurrence of certain changes in applicable tax law. See “Description
_of the Notes—Optional Redemption” and “Description of the Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”_
Upon the occurrence of certain change of control events, the Issuer may be required to offer to redeem the Notes at 101% of the principal amount
redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.” A change of control,
however, will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. In
addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable
outstanding series of Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender
offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right
to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder
of the Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”
On the Issue Date, the Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer. The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis (i) on the Issue Date,
by the Parent, Constellation Automotive Limited (“Constellation Automotive”), BCA Central Limited (“BCA Central,”and together with the Parent and
Constellation Automotive, the “Initial Guarantors,” and such guarantees provided, the “Initial Guarantees”) and (ii) within two business days from the
Issue Date, by the Additional Guarantors (as defined herein, and such guarantees provided, the “Additional Guarantees” and, together with the Initial
Guarantees, the “Guarantees” and each, a “Guarantee”). The Initial Guarantors and the Additional Guarantors are collectively referred to as
“Guarantors” and each, a “Guarantor.” The Guarantee of each Guarantor will rank equal in right of payment with such Guarantor’s existing or future
obligations that are not subordinated in right of payment to its Guarantee, and will be secured by the Collateral (as defined herein).
On the Issue Date, subject to the release of security in respect of the Existing Facilities (as defined herein), the Notes will be secured on a first-priority
basis by the Initial Collateral (as defined herein), and within two business days from the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured on a first-priority basis by
the Post-Closing Collateral (as defined herein, and together with the Initial Collateral, the “Collateral”). The Collateral will also secure borrowings under
the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility, the Second Lien Facility (each as defined herein) and certain hedging obligations, if any.
The Notes will rank equal in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s existing or future obligations that are not subordinated in right of payment to the
Notes, including the Issuer’s obligations under the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations, if any. See
“Description of Other Financial Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.”
The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain
limitations, including the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein). See also “Certain Insolvency and Local Law Limitations.” The security interests
in favor of the Notes and the Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances.
There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”)
for the listing of the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”) and admission to trade on the Exchange. There is
no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange. The Exchange is not a regulated market for purposes of the provisions of
Directive 2014/65/EU, as amended (“MiFID II”).
**Investing in the Notes involves risks. See “Risk Factors” beginning on page 29.**
Issue price of the Notes: % plus accrued interest, if any, from the Issue Date.
The Notes and the Guarantees have not been and will not be registered under the U.S. Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the “Securities Act”), or the
securities laws of any State of the United States or any other jurisdiction. Accordingly, the Notes are being offered and sold in the United States only to
“qualified institutional buyers” in accordance with Rule 144A under the Securities Act (“Rule 144A”) and to persons who are not a U.S. person (as
defined in Regulation S under the Securities Act (“Regulation S”)) and who are outside of the United States in offshore transactions in reliance on
Regulation S. Prospective purchasers of the Notes that are qualified institutional buyers are hereby notified that the seller may be relying on the exemption
from the provisions of Section 5 of the Securities Act provided by Rule 144A. For further details about eligible offerees and resale restrictions, see
“Transfer Restrictions.”
The Notes will be issued in the form of global notes in registered form. See “Book-entry, Delivery and Form.” We expect the Notes to be delivered to
investors in book-entry form through Euroclear Bank SA/NV (“Euroclear”) and Clearstream Banking S.A. (“Clearstream”) on or about, 2021 (the
“Issue Date”).

**ALTERNATIVE SETTLEMENT CYCLE**

We expect that the delivery of the Notes will be made against payment therefor on or about the Issue Date,
which will be ten business days following the date of pricing of the Notes (such settlement cycle being herein


-----

referred to as “T+10”). Under Rule 15(c)6-1 under the Exchange Act (as defined herein), trades in the
secondary market generally are required to settle in two business days, unless the parties to any such trade
expressly agree otherwise. Accordingly, purchasers who wish to trade the Notes on the date of pricing or the
next seven business days will be required, by virtue of the fact that the Notes initially will settle T+10, to
specify an alternative settlement cycle at the time of any such trade to prevent a failed settlement. Purchasers
of the Notes who wish to trade the Notes on the date of pricing or the next seven business days should consult
their advisors.

Our fiscal year accounting periods typically run from the calendar day following the previous fiscal year end
to a Sunday within seven days of March 31. For the fiscal years 2021, 2020 and 2019, the relevant Sundays
were March 28, 2021, March 29, 2020 and March 31, 2019. While the Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial
Statements and the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements comprise the 52-week period ended
March 28, 2021 (from and including March 30, 2020 to and including March 28, 2021) and the 52-week
period ended March 31, 2019 (from and including April 2, 2018 to and including March 31, 2019), respectively,
the Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements only comprise the 42-week period ended March 29,
2020 (from and including June 10, 2019 to and including March 29, 2020). As such, the Fiscal Year 2020
Consolidated Financial Statements are not comparable to the other Consolidated Financial Statements since
they only cover the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020, representing the period from the incorporation
date of the Parent on June 10, 2019.

In addition, due to the CA Acquisition, which completed on November 6, 2019, the Fiscal Year 2020
Consolidated Financial Statements do not reflect our trading results during the period from April 1, 2019 to
November 5, 2019. Below is an overview of the trading history covered by the Consolidated Financial
Statements.

- The Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the results of operations of BCA
Marketplace and its subsidiaries from and including April 2, 2018 to and including March 31, 2019.
Accordingly, the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements represent 52 weeks of trading,
reflecting our results of operations prior to the CA Acquisition.

- The Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the results of operations of the Parent and
Constellation Automotive (which were incorporated for the purpose of facilitating the CA Acquisition
and, as such, are holding companies with no operations and no assets other than the shares held) from and
including the date of incorporation of the Parent on June 10, 2019 to and including March 29, 2020.
During the period from June 10, 2019 to the completion date of the CA Acquisition on November 6, 2019,
the Parent had no activities and had very limited financial results to report. Following the consummation


-----

of the CA Acquisition on November 6, 2019, our financial results are consolidated at the Parent level.
Accordingly, the Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements represent 145 days of trading,
reflecting our results of operations after the CA Acquisition.

- The Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the results of operations of the Parent
group from and including March 30, 2020 to and including March 28, 2021. Accordingly, the Fiscal Year
2021 Consolidated Financial Statements represent 52 weeks of trading.

_Application of IFRS 16_

IFRS 16 (Leases) became effective on January 1, 2019 and applies to the first full fiscal year commencing on
or after that date. Accordingly, we have applied IFRS 16 since the fiscal year 2020. We have adopted IFRS 16
under the modified retrospective approach on April 1, 2019, with the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 16
recognized on adoption as an adjustment to opening equity. Under this approach, comparative information
for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 is not restated and, as a result, no IFRS 16 adjustments have
been made to the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements. Accordingly, the financial information
included in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, the 2020
Predecessor Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information, may not be
comparable insofar as they relate to the application of IFRS 16 (Leases).

Following the CA Acquisition, a purchase price allocation exercise was undertaken in order to identify the
fair value of the assets and liabilities acquired thereunder, in line with IFRS 3 (Business Combinations).
IFRS 3 requires the revaluation of IFRS 16 right of use assets and lease liabilities using a revised incremental
borrowing rate (“IBR”). The IBR we used for these purposes increased significantly following the CA
Acquisition as a result of the indebtedness incurred in connection therewith. Due to the significant change in
IBR used for the valuation of right of use assets and lease liabilities resulting from the CA Acquisition, the
full year IFRS 16 depreciation and interest included in our Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information
represents the aggregation of (i) the pre-CA Acquisition IFRS 16 depreciation and interest calculated with
reference to the original, pre-CA Acquisition IBR and (ii) the post-CA Acquisition IFRS 16 depreciation and
interest calculated with reference to the revised, post-CA Acquisition IBR. Accordingly, the financial
information included in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, the
2020 Predecessor Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information, may not
be comparable.

**_Non-IFRS Measures_**

The non-IFRS measures included in this Offering Memorandum include Reported Adjusted EBITDA, IAS
17 Adjusted EBITDA, IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA, IAS 17 Pro Forma Adjusted Run Rate EBITDA,
Underlying Cash CAPEX, Adjusted Operating Cash Flow, Adjusted Cash Conversion, COVID Adjusted
Operating Cash Flow and COVID Adjusted Cash Conversion are defined as follows:

- “Reported Adjusted EBITDA” means operating profit/(loss) for the period as reported in the relevant
Consolidated Financial Statements, the 2020 Predecessor Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020
Aggregated Financial Information, as adjusted for depreciation and amortization and significant or
non-recurring items;

- “IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA”means Reported Adjusted EBITDA, which is further adjusted to remove (i) the
impact of IFRS 16 and (ii) the results relating to cinch;

- “IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA” means IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA, which is further adjusted for the
impact of the COVID 19 pandemic;

- “IAS 17 Pro Forma Adjusted Run Rate EBITDA” means IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA for the
unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, adjusted for the incremental impact of current
run rate C2B Vehicle Volume, incremental impact of current run rate C2B Profitability Per Vehicle,
incremental impact of current run rate B2B Vehicle Volume, incremental impact of current run rate B2B
Profitability Per Vehicle, incremental impact of current run rate Automotive Services EBITDA and rates
relief adjustment;

- “Underlying Cash CAPEX”means cash cost of capital expenditure adjusted for right of use asset additions
and the purchase of assets that are subject to sale and leaseback as well as one-off and other items including
proceeds from sale;

- “Adjusted Operating Cash Flow” means IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA less Underlying Cash CAPEX;

- “Adjusted Cash Conversion” means Adjusted Operating Cash Flow over IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA;

- “COVID Adjusted Operating Cash Flow” means IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA less Underlying Cash
CAPEX; and

- “COVID Adjusted Cash Conversion” means COVID Adjusted Operating Cash Flow over IAS 17 COVID
Adjusted EBITDA.

For a reconciliation of these non-IFRS measures, see “Summary—Summary Historical Financial and Other
_Information.”_

**Overview**

We operate leading digital used vehicle marketplaces (both business to business (“B2B”) and consumer to
business (“C2B”)) in the UK and B2B marketplaces in continental Europe and are a leading provider of
associated automotive services, including vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet
management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. We have physical presence in 10 countries
across the UK and continental Europe as well as unmatched sourcing, data, technology and logistics
capabilities. As of March 28, 2021, our business comprises:

- a leading B2B digital used vehicle marketplace across the UK and continental Europe, which facilitated the
sale of approximately 1.5 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 1.2 million vehicles in the fiscal year
2021;

- a leading C2B digital used vehicle marketplace in the UK, WeBuyAnyCar, with sold volumes of 321,000
vehicles and 300,000 vehicles in the fiscal years 2020 and 2021, respectively, reflecting the COVID 19
restrictions on the business that now has an annualized run rate of 461,000 vehicles (based on trading in
March, April and May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period); and

- a leading automotive logistics service business in the UK, which moved more than 2.8 million vehicles in
the UK in the fiscal year 2020 and 2.4 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2021, and stored, refurbished and
processed more than 950,000 vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 675,000 in the fiscal year 2021.

We estimate that for the fiscal year 2020 we came in contact with approximately one in every three vehicles in
the UK (approximately 29 million touch points, of which approximately 13 million were unique vehicles out
of a vehicle parc of approximately 41 million, and including approximately 24 million digital touch points).
Through our digital used vehicle marketplaces (the “Marketplace”), we are a critical liquidity provider to the
used vehicles market across the UK and continental Europe, matching the complex requirements of both
vendors and buyers and also facilitating the purchase of individual vehicles from consumers. The Marketplace
facilitates speedy disposal of high volumes of vehicles and offers a broad range of consistently graded vehicle
stock, thereby providing efficiency, liquidity (i.e., fast disposal of vehicle stock) and choice. Moreover, we are
the UK’s leading provider of automotive services solutions.

By providing a full suite of auction and automotive services, we offer our customers solutions for almost all
stages of the vehicle life-cycle, beginning as soon as the new car arrives at the port. Our scope of services
provides synergistic benefits across our divisions, as our vehicle sales platforms, together with our automotive
services solutions, generate vehicle and pricing data used in both our vehicle remarketing and vehicle buying
operations.

Throughout the COVID 19 pandemic, we have accelerated our digital transition and now transact digitally
almost 100% of our volumes through online channels. We integrate our digital and physical assets to provide
innovative multi-service solutions, maximizing speed, intelligence and performance across our comprehensive
offerings. In the fiscal year 2021, 100% (2020: 37%) of our auction volumes in the UK Vehicle Remarketing
division and 96% (2020: 84%) of our auction volumes in the International Vehicle Remarketing division were
transacted online, which is a testament to our successful shift towards a predominantly digital online business
model moving forward.

In the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021, we generated £253.1 million of IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA,
as compared to £232.8 million, £204.1 million and £174.4 million in the 52-week period ended March 28,
2021, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019,
respectively.

We operate through three main business lines: (i) the B2B Marketplace business line, which is comprised of
our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, our International Vehicle Remarketing division and our Vehicle Buying
division’s operations in continental Europe, (ii) the C2B Marketplace business line, which is WeBuyAnyCar,
our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in the UK, and (iii) the Automotive Services business line, which is
accounted for in our Automotive Services division.


-----

- B2B Marketplace: B2B Marketplace is our core business that facilitates the exchange of used vehicles
between vendors and buyers through primarily digital auctions. As of March 28, 2021, our digital auctions
are supported by 21 physical sites in the UK (23 as of June 1, 2021) and 30 physical sites in continental
Europe at which vehicles are stored, inspected, repaired and refurbished.

B2B Marketplace (which excludes WeBuyAnyCar) does not take title to the majority of vehicles that it sells,
but instead serves as an agent between vendor and buyer and recognizes revenues through auction transaction
fees as well as fees for a suite of value-added digital and physical pre- and post- auction services such as
inspections, appraisals, repairs, refurbishment, imaging, storage and handling. We also purchase vehicles
directly from certain corporate vendors under outsourced remarketing contracts, whereby we directly buy our
vendors’ inventory and have discretion over the remarketing channel through which we sell the vehicle. B2B
Marketplace takes title to such vehicles until the time of resale and recognizes revenues for the full sale value
of the vehicle less the cost of acquisition. Vehicles acquired pursuant to outsourced remarketing contracts are
typically resold within 15 to 30 days of acquisition and in turn generate additional revenue above the auction
fees.

B2B Marketplace also includes our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in continental Europe, which is
focused on purchasing batches of vehicles primarily from corporates in continental Europe.

In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division generated £90.5 million
of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £116.3 million; 52-week
period ended March 31, 2019: £109.4 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division
sold approximately 867,000 vehicles (2020: 1,063,000 vehicles; 2019: 1,030,0000 vehicles). In the 52-week
period ended March 28, 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division generated £29.2 million of IAS
17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £34.2 million; 52-week period ended
March 31, 2019: £33.7 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division sold
approximately 334,000 vehicles (2020: 401,000 vehicles; 2019: 388,000 vehicles).

- C2B Marketplace: C2B Marketplace is our C2B vehicle buying business which operates in the UK through
WeBuyAnyCar. WeBuyAnyCar purchases used vehicles directly from consumers, leveraging its proprietary
online pricing quotation systems and efficient physical inspection processes to facilitate purchases from
such consumers. WeBuyAnyCar has carried out a total of 2.2 million vehicle purchases since its inception
in 2006, and in the fiscal year ended March 28, 2021, WeBuyAnyCar recorded more than 22 million unique
visitors to its website and performed approximately 15.6 million valuations online. As of March 28, 2021,
WeBuyAnyCar operates in 357 locations across the UK, which are located within an average drive time of
under 14 minutes to customers. In addition, WeBuyAnyCar offers swift services to its consumers, allowing
them to obtain a quote in under 60 seconds and to then subsequently receive monies for the purchase of
their vehicle within 30 minutes of the sale being concluded.

C2B Marketplace remarkets the vehicles it purchases exclusively through B2B Marketplace within
approximately 10 days and accounted for 35% of the vehicles sold in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division in
the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This allows us to actively manage the volumes and mix on the
Marketplace, while helping to de-risk the supply of vehicles to the auction.

C2B Marketplace’s consistent and growing profitability over the past years demonstrates our ability to
generate “metal margin” (accounted for in our Vehicle Buying division) on C2B vehicles in addition to core
auction buyer fees (accounted for in our UK Vehicle Remarketing division). Vehicles sourced via our C2B
Marketplace therefore result in higher profitability per vehicle for the CA Group. Our sophisticated and
proprietary pricing mechanism and real-time market data enable us to more accurately price the purchase of
vehicles to generate a profitable onward sale. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Vehicle Buying
division generated £44.0 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29,
2020: £27.7 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £24.1 million), which was predominantly generated
through C2B Marketplace (i.e., WeBuyAnyCar).

- Automotive Services: Automotive Services provides vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery
inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. With our refurbishment
offering (which has a 250,000 yearly vehicle refurbishment capacity), we are able to bring vehicles to either
wholesale standard or a “Retail Ready” standard (which refers to vehicles that are cosmetically and
mechanically prepared to be immediately placed for sale to end consumers and are therefore particularly
attractive to online car dealers). These standards increase prices achieved at auction and render it simpler
for dealers to on-sell the vehicle to consumers. We seek to develop a relationship with vendors and endeavor
to act as a one-stop shop for vehicles throughout the majority of their lifecycle, expanding our revenue


-----

streams along the value chain and also positioning ourselves to be the preferred provider of remarketing
services when the vehicles come off lease or roll out of the fleet. Our overall infrastructure and logistics
network allow us to efficiently cover all key locations and major transport hubs in the UK. Automotive
Services helps maximize the benefit of operational leverage and intragroup efficiencies derived from the
wide-ranging scope of services offered, benefitting both our customers as well as our own operations.

Automotive Services generates revenue in the form of service fees. In the 52-week period ended March 28,
2021, Automotive Services generated £12.5 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period
ended March 29, 2020: £22.6 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £19.1 million).

**Our Strengths**

We believe that, by virtue of the key strengths described below, we are well-positioned to benefit from
structurally favorable trends in the used vehicle market.

**_Leadership across Markets_**

We are a leading operator of digital used vehicle auctions in the UK and continental Europe and associated
automotive services across the UK. From continental Europe, we serve over 40 countries, leveraging our
ability to engage in cross-border activity across continental Europe. We believe our leading market positioning
and scale enable us to better serve used car buyers and sellers compared to many of our competitors as we are
able to price, source, inspect, refurbish, transport, service, market, arrange auctions and provide digital and
physical services and solutions in an efficient, comprehensive and effective way.

We believe our B2B Marketplace is the largest used vehicle auction operator across the UK and continental
Europe combined, with approximately £10 billion in gross merchandise value in connection with sales for the
fiscal year 2020. We believe that B2B Marketplace is the clear leader in the UK, having sold approximately
1.1 million vehicles in the UK in the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, as well as
approximately 400,000 vehicles sold in continental Europe in the same period. These attributes mean that we
can continuously meet the requirements of both professional vendors and buyers, including improved value,
liquidity, efficiency and choice, and are a key part of the reason that more than 25,000 active buyers used the
exchange in the fiscal year 2021. Through our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, our Automotive Services
offering in the UK and our brand WeBuyAnyCar, we come into contact with approximately one third of all
vehicles exchanged in the UK each year.

We believe that C2B Marketplace, through our brand WeBuyAnyCar, is the leading vehicle buying service in
the UK, purchasing and selling over 321,000 vehicles in the fiscal year 2020. On an annualized basis based on
trading in March, April and May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period, we purchased and
sold approximately 461,000 vehicles through WeBuyAnyCar. With greater than 22 million unique visitors to
its website in the fiscal year ended March 28, 2021 and having performed approximately 15.6 million valuations
online and purchasing vehicles at 357 physical sites, each as of and for the 52-week period ended March 28,
2021, we believe that C2B Marketplace is significantly larger and has a significantly greater presence than any
other vehicle buying service in the UK. C2B Marketplace’s leadership position is continuing to strengthen
with an increase in the number of repeat customers in recent years, demonstrating consumers’ trust in the
brand and satisfaction around the value attached to the vehicle disposal process. As of the date of this Offering
Memorandum, WeBuyAnyCar has over 100,000 Trust Pilot reviews with an average 4.6 rating.

In Automotive Services, we operate one of the largest automotive vehicle movement, logistics, storage, predelivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment capability in the UK. As of
March 28, 2021, we own the largest transporter fleet in the UK, comprising 901 trucks capable of providing
bulk vehicle movements, thereby connecting the physical marketplace and increasing the integration between
our divisions. We also offer the full range of single vehicle movement services to support customers through
the process of vehicle delivery, handover and collection. In the fiscal year 2021, we moved 2.4 million vehicles
(2020: 2.8 million), including 563,000 single vehicle movements, and our in-house and sub-contracted
transporter fleet completed 94% of transport arranged for customers by the UK Vehicle Remarketing division.
We offer the full range of single vehicle movement services to support customers through the process of
vehicle delivery, handover and collection.

We also operate one of the UK’s largest inspect and collect businesses with over 400,000 vehicle inspections
made in the fiscal year 2021, are one of the UK’s leading new vehicle storage handling and preparation
businesses and are among the UK’s leading de-fleet, refurbishment and alloy wheel businesses with more than
675,000 vehicles stored, refurbished and processed in the fiscal year 2021.


-----

**_Superior Business Model Addressing the Full Value Chain and Difficult to Replicate_**

We operate under a marketplace model and benefit from self-reinforcing dynamics where each of our business
lines feeds into and reinforces the others. Our business model enables us to extract intragroup efficiencies and
synergies derived from operating across almost all stages of the vehicle life-cycle, at high volumes sufficient to
provide a level of information, liquidity and market recognition that drives further volume growth.

Our B2B Marketplace operates vehicle auctions that bring together vendors with a highly fragmented and
diverse buyer base. Our large, robust and transparent digital platforms combined with our full suite of preand post-auction digital and physical value-added services provide an efficient marketplace to facilitate the
exchange of used vehicles. B2B Marketplace sold approximately 1.5 million vehicles across the UK and
continental Europe in the fiscal year 2020. This significant scale creates a virtuous business cycle by providing
access to a wide variety and large volume of vehicles through our auctions, thereby attracting more buyers to
our platform and enabling optimum pricing and quick throughput, which in turn attracts more sellers and
provides more volumes. Moreover, we obtain valuable insights for our pricing engines based on the
information we have available about a vehicle and its condition, color, auction sale price and bid levels. The
B2B Marketplace benefits from multiple sourcing channels targeting different types of vendors.

The C2B Marketplace creates a highly complementary and enhancing growth engine to that of the B2B
Marketplace. The B2B Marketplace provides WeBuyAnyCar with a highly efficient route to dispose of the
vehicles it purchases from consumers (typically within 10 days) and, through WeBuyAnyCar, we have the
ability to purchase a greater volume and variety of vehicles, which directly helps supply the B2B Marketplace.
The Vehicle Buying division provides significant volumes to the UK Vehicle Remarketing division, having
accounted for 35% of the vehicles sold through the Marketplace in the UK in the fiscal year 2021. This
synergistic model, which leverages WeBuyAnyCar’s market share within the framework of our wider
marketplace, creates a platform which we believe would be difficult to replicate.

Our ability to dynamically source used vehicles combined with our knowledge and insights on pricing and
other demand side dynamics enable us to find an optimum and tailored match for buyers and sellers swiftly,
which is key in driving profitability per vehicle. This is further strengthened by the additional services we offer,
which increase consumer and vendor experience as well as help us generate greater profitability per vehicle.

Our scaled B2B Marketplace and C2B Marketplace provides our pricing model with over six million relevant
historic used vehicle transactions. This data enables us to accurately and efficiently price vehicles both upon
sourcing and sale. This scale is further supported by our Automotive Services business line and our full suite
of pre- and post-auction digital and physical value-added services. This completes the value chain allowing us
to cover the full life-cycle, deepen relationships with vendors and customers and maximize profitability per
vehicle. Moreover, our Automotive Services business line and our value-added services enable us to record
information relating to vehicle condition, maintenance and upkeep, further contributing to the pricing model
and further supporting the reliability of pricing decisions.

With the launch of B2C Marketplace, outside the restricted group, we have further diversified our buyer and
vendor base as cinch acts as another buyer through our auction channel, thereby generating auction fees for
our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, as well as additional income for our Automotive Services division.
Furthermore, cinch also generates additional supply for the B2B Marketplace via part-exchange vehicles that
are remarketed by us and allow us to generate additional auction fees. See “Certain Relationships and Related
_Party Transactions—Agreements with cinch.”_


-----

As the scale of each of the business lines has grown and has reached greater volumes and touch points, it has
contributed to the further growth of each of the business lines in a virtuous cycle. We believe we are the only
operator of digital used vehicle auctions in the UK and continental Europe that offers the scale and the range
of services we provide. Our advantages in scale, reputation, relationships, access to proprietary data as well as
our established infrastructure and logistics network, which we believe would be difficult for a competitor to
replicate.

**_Resilient Financial Profile and Strong Cash Flow Generation_**

We believe that our scale, unique business model, reputation and robust financial policies have contributed
significantly to our long-term financial resilience, attractive growth and cash flow generation profile. Despite
turbulent times such as the global financial crisis of 2008, we were able to consistently maintain and grow
volumes and our EBITDA metric (as defined and prepared on the basis of the accounting policies of the
relevant parent entity at the time), with such metric having grown at a CAGR of 14.3% from the fiscal year
ended December 2004 to fiscal year ended March 2020 and such metric divided by vehicle volumes sold in the
respective trading year having grown from £37 per vehicle sold to £137 per vehicle sold over the same period,
as shown in the following chart.

Our business model’s resilience to market shocks can be further evidenced by our strong organic performance.
For example, during the period between 2008 and 2010, we were able to grow volumes by 66,000 vehicles and
the applicable EBITDA metric by £24 million in a market backdrop of reduced used car transactions in the
UK, which fell from 8.3 million in 2008 to 8.0 million in 2009 before recovering to 8.1 million in 2010. Despite
a market backdrop of reduced used vehicle transactions during the fiscal year 2021, our volumes between
July 2020 and December 2020 were higher compared to the period between July 2019 and December 2019. In
times of a consumer downturn and due to rate of loss in value generally associated with used vehicles, liquidity
is of paramount importance to businesses as well as consumers.

Our business is also highly cash generative, having generated £145.9 million, £175.1 million and £202.7 million
of COVID Adjusted Operating Cash Flow in the 52-week period March 31, 2019, the aggregated 52-week
period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, respectively. This strong cash
generation is the result of our ability to grow our IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA while following a
disciplined approach to capital expenditure with the majority of sites being held on long term leases (excluding
WeBuyAnyCar retail locations) and most of our transporters and properties being refinanced through sale
and leaseback. Adjusted cash conversion (measured by subtracting Underlying Cash CAPEX from IAS 17
COVID Adjusted EBITDA and comparing the result to IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA) was 84%, 86%
and 87% in the 52-week period March 31, 2019, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the
52-week period ended March 28, 2021, respectively.

**_Attractive, Resilient and Underpenetrated Market_**

We operate in the used vehicle market across the UK and continental Europe which has grown consistently
since 2012, driven by a relatively stable vehicle parc churn and growing vehicle penetration rates. Vehicle


-----

penetration rates are expected to continue to grow for most markets. In addition, the used car market is larger
and more stable than the new car market. The chart below sets out the volumes of used car sales and new car
sales in the UK between 2008 and 2020 as an example of the development of these market.

The European vehicle parc has exhibited a CAGR of approximately 1.7% over 2012 to 2019, currently
standing at approximately 320 million units as of 2020. As per projections from IHS, the European vehicle
parc is expected to exhibit approximately 0.8% CAGR over 2021 to 2026, driven by growth in the penetration
of vehicles per population. Assuming churn rates remain the same, this should support growth in the used car
market. See “Industry—Overview—UK and Continental European Vehicle Parc.”

In 2020, the European used car market was estimated to be worth €410 billion (Source: Roland Berger report
_(Apr-21)). Significant fragmentation of buyers and vendors across the UK and continental Europe helps to_
make exchanges a critical channel for both vendors and buyers. For example, the largest used car dealership in
the UK is limited to approximately 3% market share, while the largest continental European used car
dealership has a market share of less than 1% (Source: IHS and ICDP). In addition, online vehicle buying
services are still operating typically at low levels of overall market penetration (e.g., WeBuyAnyCar has ~4%
share of total UK used vehicle sales volumes, as of 2020).

The COVID 19 pandemic has also accelerated favorable structural trends affecting the markets in which we
operate. In particular, consumers have recently begun placing increased emphasis on the importance of
owning a car. This has been driven by a variety of different reasons, including people moving away from
urban areas due to the ability to work from home and a reluctance to rely entirely on public transport. In
addition, the lockdown measures imposed by governments and related closure of car dealerships has made
digital channels a principal means of conducting used car auctions. In particular, by the start of 2021 almost
all of our auctions were digital as the COVID 19 pandemic and related social distancing regulations accelerated
our digitalization plans and encouraged the adoption of digital auctions by our customers. This digital shift
allows us to reach a wider range of potential customers and has increased the amount of auctions being held,
reducing our daily sales’ costs and allowing us and our customers to receive more vehicle data. Finally, we also
benefit from increasing sales of used vehicles as government support and a push towards new technology,
including tighter emission controls, encourages vehicle owners to renew their vehicles, driving more exchanges.

**_Platform Ideally Positioned for Growth_**

We believe our business platform is strategically positioned for growth in our markets through market share
gain from the consumer to consumer (“C2C”) and part-exchange markets (whereby consumers “trade-in”
their used vehicle directly to a dealer). The growth of C2B Marketplace supports the growth of our B2B
channel as WeBuyAnyCar provides us with used vehicles that would otherwise go to C2C markets or partexchanges and allows us to supply a greater volume and variety of vehicles to our B2B Marketplace.

We believe we can drive higher volumes through our auctions through continued market share gain and
higher auction penetration in the UK and continental Europe. Our relationships with businesses such as
LeasePlan or CarNext, including entering into exclusive service agreements that provide support for our
multi-channel strategy, further enhance our sourcing capabilities and drive growth in the vehicle remarketing
segment. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Relationship with LeasePlan.”Moreover,
by leveraging our “One Europe” strategy via more seamless cross-border transactions, we believe we can
create a truly pan-European B2B marketplace for future growth.

In addition, COVID 19 restrictions have accelerated consumers’ willingness to adopt digital purchasing as a
means to buy a car from current low levels, favoring the growth of online B2C retailers, such as cinch. Our
relationship with cinch has increased supply for the B2B Marketplace via part-exchange vehicles that are
remarketed by us and allow us to generate additional auction fees. See “Certain Relationships and Related
_Party Transactions—Agreements with cinch.” Through cinch, we are also able to develop a B2C channel,_
which enhances our position as an end-to-end service provider. In particular, sales volumes for the B2C
channel increased from approximately 4,000 in October 2020 (based on a 7-day rolling annual run-rate) to
approximately 38,000 in May 2021.

**Our Strategies**

We seek to create value for stakeholders through organic growth, acquisitions and partnerships in the
automotive sector in the UK and continental Europe. We continue to work with major market participants to
develop and adapt integrated solutions to solve and meet the needs of the participants across the automotive
sector, maximizing value for all stakeholders. To achieve this goal, we are focused on enhancing our competitive
advantage as an integrated end-to-end service provider, further expanding internationally, strengthening our
infrastructure and logistics network, capitalizing on favorable industry trends, continuing to enhance our data
capabilities and improving our operational efficiencies, cash flow and leverage.

**_Enhance our competitive advantage across the value chain as an integrated end-to-end service provider_**

We plan to drive growth by increasing our B2B Marketplace and C2B Marketplace penetration to increase
transaction volumes and scale across our geographies. The increase in scale will serve to provide even deeper
access to vehicles, as well as more pricing and vehicle information, and is expected to continue to solidify our
position as a leading operator of digital used vehicle auctions across the UK and the continental European
countries in which we operate. We also expect to continue leveraging upon and investing in our UK and
continental European network and infrastructure.


-----

To further increase our scale, we intend to deepen our relationships with other participants in the used vehicle
ecosystem, including OEMs, leasing companies, finance companies and dealers, to improve access to used
vehicle supply and generate volumes. We plan to provide dealers with additional offerings that suit their
business models, to leverage the strength of WeBuyAnyCar’s brand to capture additional supply volumes as
consumers become increasingly willing to sell their vehicles through digital channels, and expand our reach to
serve customers through partnerships with other B2C platforms.

In order to maintain our competitive advantage across the value chain, we will leverage the close relationship
between our C2B Marketplace and B2B Marketplace and work on integrating further the insights and data
points we are able to collect at different stages, further supplemented by our data sharing agreement with
cinch. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Agreements with cinch.” Multiplying our
data touchpoints for vehicles entering our ecosystem will enable us to base our decisions on more precise and
efficient processes and pricing input.

We intend to continue to develop both our digital and physical service offerings to retain and grow the
customer base and deliver enhanced profitability. By increasing the penetration of value-added services over
time, we expect a compounding effect of fueling Marketplace growth by driving supply and buyer demand, as
the comprehensive end-to-end solutions significantly enhance user loyalty.

We also intend to further deepen the penetration of services provided by Automotive Services to continue to
improve relationships with vendors, both to provide additional vehicle information to benefit our other
divisions and to become the preferred choice for vehicle remarketing.

**_Further deliver on our international expansion strategy_**

We believe we are well positioned in Europe to become a truly pan-European leader in the used vehicle auction
market. Our “One Europe” strategy is focused on leveraging and optimizing our already existing capabilities
to provide more seamless cross-border transactions not only in countries where we have physical presence but
across the European continent. In continental Europe, which we believe is underpenetrated relative to more
developed markets such as the UK, we intend to grow our B2B Marketplace offering as well as our coordinated
logistics network and infrastructure to capture further market share and develop scale.

**_Strengthening our infrastructure and logistics network_**

As we look to increase our scale and continue to capture more volumes via our platforms, we will continue to
invest and strengthen our infrastructure and logistics capabilities in order to serve customers across the value
chain, while remaining asset light through the continued use of sale and leaseback transactions. We also
intend to develop and modernize our transport vehicles used for vehicle movement. Our aim is to remain a
major component of the UK used vehicle market backbone and extend this know-how to our other
geographies.

**_Capitalize on favorable structural industry trends to accelerate our growth_**

Online penetration for sales of used vehicles has grown significantly, particularly in the UK, in recent years
and the associated structural trends further accelerated during the COVID 19 pandemic. During the
COVID 19 pandemic, there has been a significant increase in online penetration for sales of used vehicles, as
physical venues were shut for lockdown periods and social distancing restrictions and health concerns
otherwise caused many consumers to avoid physical venues. Despite the recent acceleration in online
penetration growth, we believe the online used car market remains underpenetrated relative to other mass
retail markets such as markets for toys and games, consumer electronics and apparel.

Further enhancing our digital presence will also allow us to capitalize on additional structural trends that
could drive more volumes through our Marketplace and strengthen our positioning and market share on
both the supply and demand sides of the ecosystem. In particular, we believe that on the demand side
consumers will continue to favor used vehicles for individual transportation to avoid public transportation
systems, and that more vehicles will be necessary as consumers move away from city centers to areas where
public transportation is inconvenient or unavailable. On the demand side, we look to attract wider audiences
via our digital auctions with no limitations linked to historical physical sites.

Finally, we will seek to benefit from increasing sales of used vehicles as government support and a push
towards new technology, including towards electric and other alternative fuel sources for vehicles, encourages
vehicle owners to review their vehicles, driving more exchanges.


-----

**_Continue to enhance our data capabilities_**

Our business model is built on leveraging data and technology and we intend to continue to invest in our IT
infrastructure and data capabilities to scale up along with volume growth. We use data and technology
throughout our business, from providing instant price quotes and targeted marketing campaigns to valuation
tools, logistics and inventory management to optimization of refurbishment costs.

Through our end-to-end positioning we have access to one of the largest pools of real-time data.

As such, we are invested in ensuring that our IT infrastructure remains state-of-the-art to secure better
knowledge of our customers and their needs, which in turn is expected to enable us to develop better products
and more tailored service as well as more accurate pricing which is expected to help underpin our profitability.

**_Increase our operational efficiencies and drive strong cash flow and deleveraging_**

As we look to increase volumes flowing through our Marketplace, we believe we will have an opportunity to
improve our profitability per vehicle. Driving continued penetration of automotive services will help maximize
the benefit of operational leverage and intragroup efficiencies. Enhancing our data capabilities will allow us to
optimize pricing, leading to better unit economics, while we also look to ensure an optimal management of
our inventories to ensure a strong cash flow conversion at all times.

To support our strong cash generation, we will maintain our disciplined approach to cost management, which
proved to be effective in helping us navigate through the COVID 19 pandemic and its associated challenges,
maintaining an optimal capital structure and strong deleveraging profile while continuing in investing to grow
the business.

**_Recent Acquisitions and Dispositions_**

On April 22, 2021, we made a tactical acquisition of a third-party site in Corby, United Kingdom, for
£12.0 million. On May 12, 2021, we completed the sale of another site in Corby, United Kingdom, for
£23.4 million, having retained a lease with respect to such site and after previously purchasing the site for

(CP) Limited for a combined consideration of £80.0 million (the “Rockingham Acquisition”). Through the

**_Impact of COVID 19_**

Due to the unprecedented level of disruption to society and the automotive industry, including to car dealers,
leasing companies, fleet providers, original equipment manufacturers (“OEMs”), wholesale traders and private
consumers, as well as our employees and the way we operate our business, interactions at the Marketplace
were significantly reduced during the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021 with average weekly trading volume
dipping to 4,000 at the start of the quarter, compared to 29,000 at the start of the fourth quarter of the fiscal
year 2020. The changes in operating environment spurred by the COVID 19 pandemic have led us to accelerate
our shift towards a fully digital online business model with increased focus on the functionality and usability
of our digital platforms, as a result of which we were able to earn new contracts and increase our market share
in spite of the challenging market conditions. The scale of the transformation is demonstrated by the fiscal
year 2021 ending with 100% of UK auction sales having occurred online, compared to 37% in the fiscal year
2020.

In addition to the enforced cessation of physical auctions in the UK, we faced restrictions such as site closures
impacting the operation of the WeBuyAnyCar retail estate and recorded a reduction in the movement and
inspection of vehicles within Automotive Services. Our customers evolved their business models, for example
by motor dealers operating a click-and-collect process during 2020 to be able to better deal with social
distancing restrictions and, by August 2020, average weekly trading volumes bounced back up to 31,000.
With the continuing progress on vaccinations across European countries, and the UK in particular, as well as
governments lifting restrictions to public life, we expect the demand for our services to be increasing. The shift
towards a more digital operation model has, to an extent, mitigated the impact of COVID 19 and the lifting of
COVID 19 restrictions is expected to increase demand in the long term as dealers look to restock their
inventory.

_Impact on Operations_

We have been and actively continue to monitor the impact of the COVID 19 pandemic on our operations, and
our priority has been the safety of our employees and other stakeholders. As governments in the jurisdictions
where we operate introduced restrictions at the outset of the COVID 19 pandemic, we quickly ceased physical
auctions and introduced social distancing and other modifications to our ways of working to remain
compliant. In response to the closure of our physical auction sites, we adopted swift measures to significantly


-----

reduce cash outflows by reducing our operating cost and implementing cash control measures, with the aim of
maximizing our liquidity position. Specifically, we adopted the following measures, which were only necessary
during the time of the first lockdown in the UK during March 2020 to July 2020 and were not implemented
during the subsequent second and third lockdowns:

- successfully negotiated with debtors and creditors on payment terms;

- put on hold all non-essential and discretionary spend within the business, including any growth,
expansionary or investment capital expenditures and increased controls around the cash disbursement
process, including sign off by senior members of the finance team for any payments in excess of certain
reduced thresholds;

- negotiated tax deferrals with HM Revenue & Customs (“HMRC”) in respect of value-added taxes (“VAT”)
and employment taxes; and

- entered into arrangements with landlords to defer rent payments during the period of closure.

We also made furlough arrangements for those staff unable to work in the UK where we furloughed as much
as 80% of our staff at the peak of the COVID 19 pandemic in April 2020 and, in parallel, applied for employee
salary support schemes introduced by certain governments in continental Europe. Such schemes allow
companies to place employees on paid leave or on reduced working hours, with the difference to an employee’s
ordinary salary being partially reimbursed by the respective government. As of March 28, 2021, approximately
4% of our employees remained on short-term work. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 furlough
income across all jurisdictions totaled £35.5 million and rates relief totaled £8.3 million. As of March 28,
2021, remaining deferrals comprise VAT deferrals of £15.8 million, which are expected to be settled in full in
instalments during the fiscal year 2022. As a result of the numerous cost-cutting and transitory measures
taken at the beginning of the first lockdown in the UK, we came out of that lockdown with greater liquidity
compared to our liquidity going into such lockdown. From the end of the first lockdown in the UK, we have
managed to remain positive in terms of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA even in periods with government
restrictions comparable with the first lockdown in the UK. Given the success of our digital offering with our
clients and the level of profitability and efficiency achieved, we currently have no intention of reverting back
to our previous predominantly physical auction model.

_Impact on Results of Operations and Liquidity Update_

For the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17
COVID Adjusted EBITDA were £190.1 million and £204.1 million, respectively, reflecting an estimated
COVID 19 impact of £14.0 million in the fiscal year 2020. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021,
IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA were £168.0 million and £232.8 million,
respectively, reflecting an estimated COVID 19 impact of £64.8 million in the fiscal year 2021. For the 52-week
period ended March 31, 2019, we reported an operating profit of £100.2 million. For the unaudited aggregated
52-week period ended March 29, 2020, we reported an operating loss of £224.5 million. For the 52-week
period ended March 28, 2021, we reported an operating profit of £47.4 million. We had cash and cash
equivalents of £113.2 million and £247.2 million as of March 28, 2021 and March 29, 2020, respectively.

We seek to maintain sufficient amounts of liquidity with an appropriate balance of cash, debt and equity to
provide financial flexibility. On April 29, 2020, we entered into the Existing Liquidity Facility Agreement,
providing us with increased liquidity and capacity for future investment and vehicle buying. As of March 28,
2021, £110.7 million (2020: £2.3 million) was available for borrowing under the Existing Revolving Credit
Facility, in each case after giving effect to outstanding letters of credit.

_Impairment Review_

As of March 28, 2021, the intangible assets on our balance sheet totaled £1,937.9 million, including
£938.5 million in goodwill relating to the CA Acquisition. While goodwill impairment is tested annually, the
COVID 19 pandemic and its impact on our business constituted an impairment indicator that we assessed
with respect to all intangible assets as well as goodwill. The impairment review is performed on a “value-inuse” basis, which requires estimation of future net operating cash flows, the time period over which they will
occur, an appropriate discount rate and an appropriate growth rate. Any impairment charge is then recognized
in the income statement for any amount by which the carrying value of goodwill exceeds its recoverable
amount. As a result of our impairment review conducted as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic, we
recognized an exceptional goodwill impairment relating to the CA Acquisition in the amount of £266.4 million
in the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. The impairment charge thereby specifically represented a change


-----

in the timing of vehicle volumes and associated discounted cash flows, which were expected through the
Marketplace over the short term as economic activity recovers. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our
_Business—The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our_
_business, operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the_
_COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain” and “Operating and Financial Review—Factors Affecting Our Results of_
_Operations—COVID 19—Impairment Review.” We caution you that these impairment charges should not be_
regarded as an indication, forecast or representation by us or any other person regarding impairment charges
for any future period. See “Forward-looking Statements.”

**About Constellation Automotive**

Constellation Automotive Group Limited (the “Parent”) was incorporated as a private limited company under
the laws of England and Wales on June 10, 2019 in contemplation of the CA Acquisition. The Parent was
known as BBD Parentco Limited before it was renamed Constellation Automotive Group Limited on
October 26, 2020. The registered office of the Parent is Headway House, Crosby Way, Farnham, GU9 7XG,
United Kingdom.

Constellation Automotive Limited (“Constellation Automotive”) was incorporated as a private limited
company under the laws of England and Wales on June 10, 2019 in contemplation of the CA Acquisition.
Constellation Automotive was known as BBD Bidco Limited before it was renamed Constellation Automotive
Limited on October 23, 2020. Constellation Automotive is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Parent. The
board of directors of Constellation Automotive is our main board. The registered office of Constellation
Automotive is Headway House, Crosby Way, Farnham, GU9 7XG, United Kingdom.

Constellation Automotive Financing plc (the “Issuer”) was incorporated as a public limited company under
the laws of England and Wales on June 29, 2021 in contemplation of the Refinancing Transactions. The
Issuer is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Parent. The registered office of the Parent is Headway House,
Crosby Way, Farnham, GU9 7XG, United Kingdom.

**About TDR Capital**

TDR Capital is a leading private equity firm which managed funds of over €10 billion of committed capital as
of the end of 2020. It was founded in 2002 by Manjit Dale and Stephen Robertson, who were previously
partners at DB Capital Partners. TDR Capital has an experienced team of investment professionals and
operating partners and has a low-volume investment strategy based on principles developed by the investment
team over the past two decades. TDR Capital seeks to spend significant resources on each investment and to
focus on operational excellence through a tested and integrated operating partner model.

Intense pre-investment analysis and post-investment involvement mean that TDR Capital is selective, typically
making only one to three investments a year. TDR Capital takes an active role in overseeing the operations of
its investments, working in partnership with management through board representation and professional
support.

Act, or pursuant to an effective registration statement. See
“Transfer Restrictions.”

**No Prior Market . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no
established trading market. Although certain of the Initial
Purchasers have advised us that they intend to make a market in
the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may
discontinue market-making at any time without notice.
Accordingly, there is no assurance that an active trading market
will develop for the Notes.

**Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and
permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the
Exchange. There can be no assurance that the Notes will be
listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission
to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be
maintained.

**Use of Proceeds** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . We expect to use the gross proceeds from the Offering, together
with the proceeds from other Refinancing Transactions
described herein, to (i) repay in full the outstanding borrowings
under the Existing Facilities, (ii) make a distribution to the direct
parent company of the Parent and (iii) pay costs, fees and
expenses (including prepayment costs) incurred in connection
with the Refinancing Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.”

**Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture, the Notes and the Guarantees will be governed
by the laws of the State of New York. The Senior Facilities
Agreement, the Second Lien Facility Agreement and the
Intercreditor Agreement will be governed by English law. The
Security Documents will be governed by English law or the laws
of Jersey, as applicable.

retrospective approach with the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 16 recognized on adoption as an adjustment to opening

result, no IFRS 16 adjustments have been made to the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements. For all other
periods presented in the table above, we have made IFRS 16 adjustments representing the removal of IAS 17 operating lease

normalized period of trading. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the adjustments relating to COVID 19 are

quarter of the fiscal year 2021 (£43.9 million) with the results of operations for the first quarter of the fiscal year 2020
(£44.5 million) and the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2020 (£66.2 million), respectively, thereby presenting the results of
operations during a more normalized period of trading. For the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29,
2020, the adjustments relating to COVID 19 are calculated by adding back an amount of £11.3 million (based on management
forecasts using operating results for March 2020 immediately prior to lockdowns, reflecting restrictions on operating activities
due to COVID 19) and an amount of £2.7 million (representing provisions relating to bad debt and inventory). For the
52-week period ended March 31, 2019, no adjustments relating to COVID 19 were made.

**RISK FACTORS**

_An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the following risks,_
_together with the other information provided to you in this Offering Memorandum, in deciding whether to invest_
_in the Notes. The occurrence of any of the events discussed below could be detrimental to our financial_
_performance. If any of these events occur, the trading price of the Notes could decline, we may not be able to pay_
_all or part of the interest or principal on the Notes, and you may lose all or part of your investment. Additional_
_risks not currently known to us or which are presently deemed immaterial may also harm our business and affect_
_your investment._

_This Offering Memorandum contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual_
_results may differ significantly from the results discussed in such forward-looking statements. Factors that might_
_cause such differences include those discussed below. See “Forward-looking Statements.”_

**Risks Relating to Our Business**

**_The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our business,_**
**_operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the COVID 19_**
**_pandemic is uncertain._**

In December 2019, an outbreak of the novel strain of coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 (“COVID 19”) was identified
in Wuhan, China. This COVID 19 outbreak has since spread and grown globally, including in each of the
countries in which we operate, and was declared a global pandemic by the World Health Organization in
March 2020. Although the ultimate severity and impact of the COVID 19 pandemic remains uncertain, the
COVID 19 pandemic and measures taken to combat it have had, and are expected to continue to have, a
significant negative impact on the economy in the countries in which we operate and the automotive industry
as a whole. The measures taken to combat COVID 19 include restrictions on public life, curfews, forced
temporary business closures (including the closure of significant elements of our business) and lockdowns as
well as social distancing protocols and the general advice to stay at home given the health risks associated with
COVID 19. As a result, all aspects of our business have been, and we expect will continue to be, materially
negatively impacted.

In the used vehicle market, car registration agencies and car dealerships were temporarily closed, car dealers
sought to reduce their inventory and some consumers chose to delay or abandon car purchases. Due to the
unprecedented level of disruption to society and the automotive industry, including to car dealers, leasing
companies, fleet providers, original equipment manufacturers (“OEMs”), wholesale traders and private
consumers, as well as our employees and the way we operate our business, interactions at the Marketplace,
particularly at physical auction and logistics sites were significantly impacted during the fiscal year 2021 with
average weekly trading volume dipping to 4,000 at the start of the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021,
compared to 29,000 at the start of the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2020. In a number of countries our
physical auctions and other operating sites have been required to close as a result of government legislation,
as have many WeBuyAnyCar sites for periods of varying length. Interruptions to the businesses of our
customers (including OEMs, leasing companies, dealers and fleet providers) resulted in unpredictable and
reduced volumes of vehicles being handled by our Automotive Services division and a negative impact on
trading performance.

A significant proportion of our workforce (such as those involved in the physical movement of vehicles)
cannot work remotely and potentially face additional risks as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic. In addition,
some of our sites are visited by customers as part of their normal operations. We cannot guarantee that
measures we take in order to limit the risks posed to such individuals will be sufficient and we may be subject
to potential litigation or enforcement action as result of staff or customers alleging that our working practices
are unsafe in this regard. Such litigation or enforcement action could result in material financial cost and
damage to our reputation and brands.

On July 10, 2020, out of an abundance of caution, we proactively and successfully negotiated certain covenant
waivers with respect to certain of our existing debt facilities in order to mitigate the anticipated effects of the
COVID 19 pandemic. These waivers were extended on January 22, 2021. However, a prolonged negative
impact due to the COVID 19 pandemic or other factors may adversely affect our ability to comply with the
financial covenants included in the Senior Facilities Agreement or any other similar agreement, and there can
be no assurance that we would be able to successfully negotiate the covenant waivers with our lenders in such
an event. The breach of a financial or other covenant or the failure to meet any of the obligations under our


-----

financing agreements governing our debt may result in a default or event of default under such agreements,
which in turn could result in a number of adverse consequences, including cross-defaults, the acceleration of
the outstanding amounts requiring immediate repayment of the related debt in part or in whole, significant
increases in interest rates and other financing and reputational costs. There is also no guarantee that debt
financings will be available in the future to fund our obligations, or that they will be available on terms
consistent with our expectations.

The COVID 19 pandemic has caused, and is likely to continue to cause, severe economic, market and other
disruptions worldwide. It cannot be assured that conditions in the credit lending, capital and other financial
markets will not deteriorate as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic, or that our access to capital and other
sources of funding will not become constrained or expensive, or that the credit or capital markets will be
available in the future to fund our obligations. In addition, the terms of future debt agreements could include
more restrictive covenants or require incremental collateral, which may restrict our business operations or
make such debt unavailable due to our covenant restrictions then in effect. If we are unable to access the credit
or capital markets in the longer term, on commercially reasonable terms or at all, our ability to carry out
growth and business development initiatives would be limited, thereby potentially limiting our future growth
opportunities.

We also carry significant intangible assets on our balance sheet. As of March 28, 2021, the intangible assets
on our balance sheet totaled £1,937.9 million, including £938.5 million in goodwill relating to the CA
Acquisition. Pursuant to current accounting rules, we are required to assess goodwill and other intangible
assets for impairment at least annually or more frequently if impairment indicators are present. Impairment
indicators include, but are not limited to, significant underperformance relative to historical or projected
future operating results and negative industry or economic trends. If such events were to occur, the carrying
amount of our goodwill and other intangible assets may no longer be recoverable and we would be required to
record an impairment charge. The COVID 19 pandemic and its impact on our business initially constituted an
impairment indicator that we assessed and, accordingly, we recognized an exceptional goodwill impairment
of £266.4 million in the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. The impairment charge represented a change
in the timing of vehicle volumes and associated discounted cash flows, which were expected through the
Marketplace over the short term as economic activity recovers. See “Summary—Recent
_Developments—Impact of COVID 19—Impairment Review” and “Operating and Financial Review—Factors_
_Affecting Our Results of Operations—COVID 19—Impairment Review.”_

As a matter of ordinary business operations, we are subject to potential credit risk related to our buyer finance
services, BCA Partner Finance. The negative economic impact of the COVID 19 pandemic may increase such
risk. While we maintain a well-established credit scoring matrix it cannot be assured that buyers repay their
debt owed to us on a widespread and systemic basis over an extended period of time.

We have participated in available government schemes designed to support businesses negatively impacted by
the COVID 19 pandemic. These schemes include mechanisms to allow companies to place employees on paid
leave or on reduced working hours, with the difference to an employee’s ordinary salary being partially
reimbursed by the respective government. In the UK, we have furloughed as much as 80% of our staff at the
peak of the COVID 19 pandemic in April 2020, such number subsequently dropping below 60% by June 2020,
and as of March 28, 2021, approximately 4% of our employees remained on short-term work. In addition, we
have also applied for and made use of employee salary support schemes introduced by certain governments in
the UK and continental Europe.

While we are carefully tailoring our use of these COVID 19 prompted measures to ensure retention of the
necessary knowledge and expertise to support the business going forward, as a result of these measures, there
could be a loss of institutional knowledge, experience, and/or expertise which could limit our ability to manage
the business effectively, react to external developments, retain vendors and make necessary technological
developments. Similarly, these measures may negatively impact the morale of our workforce, leading to
voluntary departures of additional employees. In addition, there can be no guarantee that similar schemes
will be available in the future in the event of further COVID 19 or similar public health related disruption. In
the event of future disruption and in the absence of similar support schemes, related costs may be significantly
higher than experienced during the previous periods of COVID 19 restrictions with a negative impact on our
ability to operate.

The overall impact of the COVID 19 pandemic on our business remains uncertain and will ultimately depend
on a number of factors that cannot be accurately predicted at this time. These factors include, but are not
limited to, the duration (including the extent of any resurgence in the future) and the ultimate severity of the
COVID 19 pandemic, the timing of and manner in which containment efforts are reduced or lifted and the


-----

length of time it takes for normal economic and operating conditions to resume, which are all beyond our
knowledge and control. Moreover, there are no comparable recent events that provide us with guidance. For
these reasons, we cannot reasonably estimate the impact of the COVID 19 pandemic on our business with any
certainty nor can we provide any assurance that the COVID 19 pandemic will not continue to have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. To the extent the COVID 19
pandemic continues to adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations, it may also
have the effect of heightening other risks described in this section of this Offering Memorandum entitled
“Risk Factors,” including those relating to our high level of indebtedness, our ability to generate sufficient
cash flows to service our indebtedness, and our ability to comply with the covenants contained in the
agreements that govern our indebtedness, including the indenture governing the Notes.

In addition, as a consequence of the significantly increased volatility and instability experienced during
periods of challenging macroeconomic conditions, it is difficult for us to forecast demand trends. We may be
unable to accurately predict the extent or duration of cycles or their effect on our financial condition or result
of operations and can give no assurance as to the timing, extent or duration of the current or future
macroeconomic cycles. A decline in demand due to adverse macroeconomic conditions may also have an
adverse impact on the business of the automotive industry and require us to substantially increase the amounts
