of financial assistance, to carry on our operations.

**_We are exposed to general economic, political and regulatory conditions and risks in the countries in which we_**
**_have operations and customers._**

We operate in the UK and in a number of continental European countries while selling vehicles to buyers in a
wider geographic area. Consequently, our business and financial results are affected, directly and indirectly,
by global economic conditions, such as instability in credit markets, declining consumer and business
confidence, interest rates, volatile exchange rates, and other challenges such as uncertain or changing political
or regulatory environments.

A potential prolonged economic slowdown in the UK and continental Europe resulting from the COVID 19
pandemic poses a risk to our customers, our suppliers, our employees and the communities in which they and
we operate. The current status of the COVID 19 pandemic around the world remains serious, and while there
is cause for optimism (with the continuing progress on vaccinations across European countries and the UK in
particular), there can be no assurance that vaccinations are effective and reopening will not be reversed in
response to a resurgence in COVID 19 outbreaks. Negative economic developments, including due to global
or local recessions, higher unemployment rates, diminished levels of consumer confidence, declines in income
levels and the loss of wealth, have resulted in the past, and may result in the future, in decreased demand in the
automotive industry. The ongoing COVID 19 pandemic may be associated with further or continued decline
in economic activity and increase in unemployment levels which may negatively impact the demand for
vehicles from consumers and business users. Since we rely on strong demand for the used vehicle market, we
are particularly dependent on consumer confidence and spending power, two factors that are strongly
influenced by overall economic conditions.

Moreover, national and local governments may impose limitations and restrictions on the operation of our
business in response to any future COVID 19 resurgence, and the impact of those restrictions may have a
detrimental effect on our ability to operate (including but not limited to social distancing and other health and
safety related measures, and possibly preventing or restricting some elements of our business from trading at
all). Compliance with such regulations requires the application of financial and human resources and increases
costs to the potential detriment of our business. Failure by us to comply, or the perception of non-compliance,
with any such regulations may lead to enforcement action against us with possible financial costs and could
also damage our brands and reputation.

Although the used vehicle market has some countercyclical characteristics, adverse economic conditions in
the countries where we have operations may negatively impact our financial results, and that of our vendors
and buyers. Activity levels in the automotive industry can be affected by such factors as the availability of
consumer credit, the growth of average wages and the level of unemployment, among others, which in turn
could impact the volume of vehicles we handle. In addition, if OEMs in the UK were to experience declining
new vehicles sales, the used vehicle market could in turn be negatively impacted, which would affect our
Vehicle Buying division and Vehicle Remarketing division. Due to the relative size of our UK operations,
compared to our operations in continental Europe, we are more exposed to changes in the UK economic
environment.


-----

The wider geopolitical environment in the UK and continental Europe is also beyond our control. Our
business and operations are adversely affected by unstable or deteriorating international trade conditions. For
example, the withdrawal of the UK from the EU effective December 31, 2020 (commonly referred to as
“Brexit”) have resulted in substantial regulatory uncertainty regarding international trade and trade policy.
Moreover, our international operations are subject to risks associated with the prevailing local political,
economic and regulatory climate. For instance, it may be more difficult in certain jurisdictions for us to enforce
contracts, collect receivables, terminate labor contracts, receive dividends and transfer funds. In addition, we
may face risks associated with unexpected changes in the regulatory environment, particularly in relation to
complexity of domestic and international customs and tariffs, potentially adverse tax consequences,
restrictions on foreign trade or investment, currency exchange and capital controls, nationalization and
expropriation and cancelation of our contractual relationships without full compensation for loss. Any of the
aforementioned changes to general economic, political and regulatory conditions, and in particular any
changes in the regulatory environment and potentially adverse tax consequences as a result thereof, could
have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We are dependent on the supply of vehicles to the Marketplace._**

Our business is vulnerable to fluctuations in the supply of vehicles to our sales platforms, including our digital
and physical auction sites (together, the “Marketplace”), which in turn depends on a variety of factors. For
example, declines in demand in the automotive industry resulting from adverse macroeconomic conditions
have historically adversely impacted used vehicle trade-ins to dealers, which has in turn reduced our auction
volumes, as dealers represent a large proportion of our vendors. In addition, the supply of vehicles from
corporate vendors, including contract hire, leasing and finance companies, can also be affected by adverse
economic conditions if corporate vendors reduce the size of, or delay the renewal of, their fleets during an
economic downturn. OEMs have also in the past reduced the number of vehicles manufactured during periods
of macroeconomic decline, which, over time, can adversely affect the number of used vehicles in the market
and thus the supply of vehicles to the Marketplace.

Additionally, legislative and regulatory changes could adversely affect the supply of vehicles to the
Marketplace. Furthermore, the supply of vehicles could also decrease if our vendors elect to sell their vehicles
directly to our buyers, including private consumers. If, as a result of the foregoing factors or for any other
reason, the supply of vehicles to the Marketplace declines, our business, prospects, financial condition and
results of operations could be adversely affected.

Furthermore, our ability to provide a large, attractive offering of used vehicles within our Vehicle Remarketing
division depends on the number and quality of used vehicles we are able to purchase through WeBuyAnyCar,
and the public’s willingness to tender their vehicles to our Vehicle Buying division. There can be no assurance
that the supply of suitable vehicles at competitive prices will be sufficient to meet our needs and to continue to
grow our offering. In addition, difficulties in sourcing a suitable inventory of used vehicles may arise, among
others, due to errors from the proprietary pricing model we use to calculate purchase prices within
WeBuyAnyCar, or a failure to adjust our pricing model in order to meet the most recent market trends. If we
are unable to source a suitable inventory at competitive prices as a result of any of these factors, our business,
prospects, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.

**_We depend on a limited number of vendors for a substantial portion of the vehicles we sell._**

Historically, a limited number of vendors have collectively accounted for a substantial portion of the vehicles
sold through the Marketplace, notwithstanding the fact that WeBuyAnyCar (which sources vehicles from
individual consumers) contributed 35% of all vehicles we remarketed in the 52-week period ended March 28,
2021, thereby partially de-risking our supply. The majority of sales arrangements with our vendors do not
guarantee the provision of a minimum number of vehicles to us. Accordingly, we cannot give any assurance
that our largest vendors will continue to provide us with a supply of vehicles, or that we would be able to
replace the volumes of vehicles provided by these vendors were they to materially decrease. In addition, if one
or more of our vendors’ financial condition deteriorates, or if a vendor were to restructure its operations, our
loss of access to the vendor’s vehicles could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial
condition and results of operations.

**_Our business is vulnerable to declines in demand for used vehicles._**

If the demand for new or used vehicles decreases in the markets in which we operate, the volumes of, and the
prices paid for, vehicles sold through the Marketplace may decrease, which in turn could reduce our margins.
Although the used vehicle market has some countercyclical characteristics, no assurance can be given that


-----

such market remains stable in times of economic downturn. A decline in demand from our buyers could be
caused by a variety of factors, including adverse changes in macroeconomic conditions, such as stagnant
growth, a decline in disposable income or consumer confidence and restricted access to consumer financing.
High fuel prices may also disproportionately affect demand for vehicles with poor fuel-efficiency and lead to
a reduction in the miles driven per vehicle, which could affect the number of vehicles sold through the
Marketplace. Additionally, rising interest rates may depress sales of new or used vehicles because many
purchasers finance their purchases. Furthermore, adverse changes in the credit quality of our buyers, arising
from macroeconomic conditions or otherwise, could also lead to lower sales, as well as increase our
counterparty risk. Any reduction in demand for used vehicles caused by these or any other reason could have
a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We may be adversely affected by a general decline in vehicle ownership or sudden changes in demand for certain_**
**_types of used vehicles._**

Demand for our used vehicles may be adversely affected by trends that lead to an overall decline in demand
for vehicles. For example, environmental concerns surrounding certain types of vehicle (older diesel vehicles,
for example) or a growing share of younger people choosing not to purchase or lease their own vehicles,
opting for ride-hailing services, ride-sharing services, car rental services and public transportation instead.
These trends may continue or even intensify, in particular as urbanization continues and a growing share of
the population migrates to major cities. As a result, overall demand for vehicles, including for used vehicles,
may decline, which could adversely affect our business prospects.

Furthermore, demand for certain types of used vehicles may suddenly decline due to the introduction of
innovative technologies for new vehicles (e.g., autonomous driving systems). There is no guarantee that we
will be able to quickly source more innovative vehicles as it may take several years before they become available
in the used vehicle market. Consequently, sourcing and selling such vehicles may be more complex.

Likewise, actions by OEMs or car dealers may have a significant impact on demand in the used vehicle market.
If these parties decide to offer greater incentives for the sale of new vehicles (e.g., discounts or attractive
financing), or generally lower prices for new vehicles, this could make buying a new vehicle more attractive. As
a result, prices for used vehicles and our associated fees may decline. Prices may also decline due to insolvencies
of rental car companies or other companies with large fleets or an increased number of returns of leased
vehicles, which could result in oversupply. Conversely, any significant increase in market prices due to a scarcity
of used vehicles could impact our ability to source desirable inventory at acceptable prices and our volume
turnaround, which could have a material adverse effect on our continued growth and margins.

**_We face competition and may not be able to successfully adapt to industry changes._**

Across each of our divisions, we face competition from other market participants (both established and new
entrants). The Vehicle Buying division and the Vehicle Remarketing division face competition from other
vehicle buying and remarketing companies both in the UK and continental Europe. In the Automotive
Services division, we face competition from a broad range of competitors.

Due to the increasing use of the Internet and other technology as remarketing and distribution channels, we
also face increasing competition from online wholesale and retail vehicle selling platforms as well as from our
own vendors when they sell directly to end consumers rather than remarket vehicles through the Marketplace.
Increased competition could result in reduced profitability and/or loss of market share.

Our future success may be impacted by our ability to respond to evolving industry trends, changes in buyer
and vendor requirements and new technologies. Furthermore, some of our competitors may have greater
financial and marketing resources, may be able to respond more quickly to evolving industry dynamics and
changes in vendor or buyer requirements or may be able to devote greater resources to the development,
promotion and sale of new or emerging services and technologies. If we are unable to compete successfully or
to successfully adapt to industry changes, our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations
could be materially adversely affected.

**_A disruption in supply chains may adversely affect our Vehicle Remarketing division and Automotive Services_**
**_division._**

Our Vehicle Remarketing division and Automotive Services division offer a wide range of non-auction
services, such as inspection, appraisal, repair and refurbishment, storage and handling. These services expose
us to supply chain risks, as we are dependent on the availability of certain automotive parts and skilled labor


-----

to ensure that vehicles can move seamlessly along the automotive value chain, from collection through
inspection, repairs and onwards sale.

Any reduction, or any delays or disruptions, in the supply chains of the materials and components used by
our Vehicle Remarketing division or Automotive Services division could result in a significant disruption to
our operations and affect our ability to meet our commitments. Similarly, the lack of skilled labor to undertake
inspection, appraisal, repair and refurbishment, storage as well as handling services could result in a significant
disruption to our operations. These disruptions may result from many reasons, including increasing demands
for certain automotive parts, closures of suppliers’ plants or critical manufacturing lines due to strikes,
mechanical failures or breakdowns, electrical outages, fire, explosions, political upheaval, competition for
skilled labor as well as logistical complications resulting from severe weather or other natural disasters and
delayed customs processing. Financial difficulties of our major suppliers may also lead to delays in the delivery
of materials and components. The unavailability of any automotive parts or skilled labor required to deliver
our inspection, appraisal, repair and refurbishment, storage and handling services could cause our Vehicle
Remarketing division and Automotive Services division to incur significant delays. The risk of disruptions in
the supply of materials and components that we use is heightened due to the greater political, economic and
social instability created by Brexit, which may lead to further complications with respect to customs processing
and/or may lead to limited transportation infrastructure and difficulties in finding alternative reliable, costefficient and qualified suppliers that can freely move between the UK and continental Europe. Brexit and the
related restrictions on free movement of labor across the English Channel has also heightened the risk that
skilled labor may be unavailable. See “—We are exposed to general economic, political and regulatory conditions
_and risks in the countries in which we have operations and customers.”_

**_Our business is dependent on certain information and technology systems, and the failure to effectively maintain,_**
**_protect, develop or update these systems or cyber security attacks could have a negative impact on our business._**

Our business and financial performance depend on the effective operation of our information and technology
systems, increasingly including our cloud-hosted and digital selling platforms. It is therefore essential that key
systems, software and hardware are operational at all times. Substantially all of our remarketing buyers access
our systems via websites and/or mobile applications to view vehicles coming to auction prior to participating
in our auctions, and to participate in the various types of auctions and Bid Now/Buy Now sales themselves. In
addition, our customers also use WeBuyAnyCar’s online vehicle pricing quotation system to obtain a valuation
of their vehicle. We are therefore reliant on the operation of WeBuyAnyCar’s online platform, as well as a
number of mobile applications, which offer vehicle search functions, bidding features and access to live
information such as pricing, vehicle condition, and individual lot/auction timings. Our digital services are
accessed by a large number of users, often at the same time, and if user traffic increases, we may not be able to
scale our technology to accommodate increased capacity requirements, which may result in interruptions or
delays in service. The business is also reliant on the systems that power the Automotive Services division’s
remote operations, such as transporters, inspect and collect operatives, appraisers and imaging.

We rely on a large range of computer and other information systems which are essential to our operations and
which became even more important during the COVID 19 pandemic, when our operating model shifted
towards an online business. Accordingly, the continued and uninterrupted performance of those systems,
along with their development and implementation, are vital factors in the operation of our business. We
depend on our technical infrastructure for all aspects of the day-to-day management of our business and the
delivery of our services. Any material disruption to the operation of such infrastructure, including as a result
of legislative and regulatory changes regarding online sales and e-commerce, may materially and negatively
affect our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Interruptions in these systems,
whether due to system failures, computer viruses, software errors or physical or electronic break-ins, or other
factors could affect the security or availability of our products and services on our websites or mobile
applications and prevent or inhibit the ability of vendors and buyers to access our services.

Electronic break-ins and cyber security attacks continue to increase in both prevalence and sophistication
throughout the digital world with the potential to corrupt, affect or destroy key systems and data, including
the confidentiality, integrity and availability of our data and systems. Given that techniques used in these
break-ins and attacks change frequently and often are not recognized until launched against a target, it may
be impossible to properly secure our systems. In addition, technical advances or a continued expansion and
increased complexity of our digital offering could increase the likelihood of security breaches. The risk of
electronic break-ins and cyber security attacks includes breaches and attempted breaches not only of our own
products, services and systems, but also of those of our customers, employees, contractors, business partners,
and other third parties as well as of third-party systems on which we rely to operate our digital platforms.


-----

Successful breaches, employee malfeasance, or human or technological error could result in, for example,
unauthorized access to, disclosure, modification, misuse, loss, or destruction of our data or systems or those
of our customers or other third parties, theft of sensitive, regulated, or confidential data including personal
information and intellectual property, loss of access to critical data or systems through ransomware,
destructive attacks or other means, and business delays, service or system disruptions or denials of service. In
addition, the fast-paced, evolving, pervasive and sophisticated nature of certain cyber threats and
vulnerabilities, as well as the scale and complexity of the business and infrastructure, make it possible that
certain threats or vulnerabilities will be undetected or unmitigated in time to prevent an attack on one of our
customers and its customers. Furthermore, these risks will increase as we continue to shift of our operating
model towards an online business in response to the COVID 19 pandemic. Problems with the reliability,
availability or security of our systems and digital service offerings could harm our reputation, result in a loss
of vendors or buyers or necessitate additional costs, fines or penalties, any of which could harm our business,
prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Certain vendors, as a condition of operating through us, audit our information and technology systems.
These audits may require significant management time to address and could result in costly changes to
information and technology systems as a condition of continued operation. The loss of the supply of vehicles
from a vendor or the cost of changes to our information and technology systems following an audit could
have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Robust back office systems, including auction information systems, are also critical to our ability to attract
visitors to our websites. These systems are also imperative for the operation of our website and mobile
applications, pricing, third-party data feeds, customer service, internal and external communications,
procurement, logistics, administration and financial reporting. In addition, we are dependent on certain
third-party information and technology systems, particularly with respect to payment processing, vehicle
licensing checks and fraud detection. In particular, we face liability risks in connection with online credit card
fraud and problems adequately securing our payment systems, despite using market-standard protocols
designed to ensure enhanced security and strong identification for our customers when they use their debit or
credit cards for vehicle purchases. The failure or unavailability of any of our information and technology
systems to detect such type of fraud or other errors with respect to payment processing or vehicle licensing
checks could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of
operations.

Much of our physical information and technology infrastructure (including servers, website hosting, database
storage and wide area networks) is supplied by service providers via managed services contracts. Technical or
other service problems faced by our managed service providers could adversely affect the experience of our
vendors and buyers. Any financial or operational difficulties faced by our managed service providers or any of
the third-party service providers with whom they contract may have adverse effects on our business, the nature
and extent of which are difficult to predict. Furthermore, any disruption of the distribution channels or
networks used by our mobile applications could adversely affect the ability to access or update our mobile
applications, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and
results of operations.

Our success also depends on our continued innovation and ability to provide features that make our websites
and mobile applications user-friendly, particularly through the development of specific software and
applications under a variety of new platforms and operating systems, which are generally expected by users to
offer the same features or flexibility and to be as easily and intuitively operated as desktop interfaces. As
technology improves and as our operations grow in size, scope and complexity, we will need to improve and
upgrade our systems and infrastructure, which may require substantial financial, operational and technical
resources. Delays or difficulties in implementing new or enhanced systems may impair our ability to provide
digital services to our vendors and buyers or may reduce the effectiveness of digital auctions, which could
have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Acceptance of our digital platforms and mobile applications as suitable platforms for the sale and purchase of_**
**_used vehicles may decrease or fail to improve._**

The restrictions on physical sales activity (including physical auctions) due to the COVID 19 pandemic has
significantly increased the volume of vehicles traded digitally across the used vehicle market and via the
Marketplace. While the acceptance of our digital platforms has been strong by both buyers and vendors, there
is no guarantee that overall online acceptance in the used vehicle market will be maintained or increased. If
the acceptance of our digital offering decreases or fails to grow, we may not be able to achieve the future
growth we target.


-----

**_Our inventory and vehicles held on behalf of others may be damaged by extreme weather or other events outside_**
**_our control, and the insurance we carry may be inadequate._**

During the handling of new and used vehicles across the business, large numbers of vehicles are transported
and stored by us in both covered and open-air facilities. We are liable for the vehicles we own (the majority of
which are purchased through the Vehicle Buying division) and, in many cases, we are liable for the vehicles
supplied by vendors for auction through the Vehicle Remarketing division, as well as when we collect and
deliver vehicles through our logistics services. Extreme weather, such as hail storms, fire and flooding, which
has in the past damaged vehicles in our possession, natural disasters (such as extreme precipitation or extreme
temperature) or other catastrophic events (such as terrorism and large-scale accidents) may adversely affect
our physical facilities or damage vehicles awaiting sale or vehicles generally stored by us. Such risks are
particularly prevalent in respect of our open air facilities. In addition, there is no assurance that used vehicles
in our inventory will be properly protected (e.g., against theft or vandalism). This may result in an increase in
costs, delay or cancelation of auction sales, any of which could have a material adverse impact on our revenue
and profitability. Our failure to meet vendors’ or buyers’ demands in such situations could further adversely
affect our reputation, reduce customer satisfaction, damage relationships with both vendors and buyers and
result in a loss of future business.

We maintain insurance cover for risks including property damage, business interruption, employers and public
liability, as well as for certain other claims consistent with customary practice in the industry in which we
operate. However, claims not covered by our insurance or in excess of our insurance coverage may arise, such
as from a natural disaster, theft or other causes outside our control.

Moreover, we may be unable in future periods to obtain insurance coverage on acceptable terms, without
substantial premiums increase or at all, particularly if there is deterioration in our claim experience history. A
successful claim against us, which is not covered by or in excess of our coverage could have a material adverse
effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We are subject to complex taxation in multiple jurisdictions, in particular relating to valued-added taxes._**

We are subject to taxation in multiple jurisdictions, including in the UK and continental Europe. Because of
the complex interplay between our business and the various taxation regimes to which we are subject, the
provision made for taxes in the accounts involves a significant amount of judgement and uncertainty
regarding the interpretation of relevant facts and laws in the jurisdictions in which we operate. Changes to
existing tax laws or tax reporting obligations, or the introduction of new tax laws or obligations (for instance
with regards to online sales), in any of these jurisdictions could adversely impact our business, prospects,
financial condition and results of operations. The risks associated to unforeseen changes to existing tax laws
or tax reporting obligations are compounded by the uncertainty created by Brexit and legislatives changes in
connection thereto (see “—We are exposed to general economic, political and regulatory conditions and risks in
_the countries in which we have operations and customers”) and the shift of our operating model towards an_
online business in response to the COVID 19 pandemic (see “—The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will
_continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our business, operations, financial condition, operating results and_
_liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain”)._

Additionally, we are subject to complex laws and regulations in many countries involving VAT and other
indirect taxes. In the jurisdictions in which we operate, we are responsible for collecting any VAT amounts due
on the vehicles we sell, and we rely on our vendors to provide accurate and complete information relating to
the VAT status of each vehicle to enable us to calculate the amount of any VAT due. We also rely on purchasers
of our vehicles at auction to provide accurate information regarding their residency in order to assess
appropriate treatment of VAT for sales invoices. If a vendor or buyer provides incorrect or incomplete VATrelated information, or if we fail to implement or fully comply with local VAT rules and regulations, we may
be exposed to VAT claims and fines from relevant authorities.

In the ordinary course of our business, we are frequently subject to VAT and other tax audits by relevant
authorities throughout Europe, and these audits can relate to matters that arose many years in the past. The
outcome of these audits could result in additional VAT claims and/or regulatory actions against us, which
could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We may not successfully implement our strategic initiatives._**

Our future operating results are dependent, in part, on our success in implementing our strategic and tactical
initiatives. These initiatives are focused on enhancing our competitive advantage as an integrated end-to-end


-----

service provider, further expanding internationally, strengthening our infrastructure and logistics network,
capitalizing on favorable industry trends, continuing to enhance our data capabilities and improving our
operational efficiencies, cash flow and leverage.

These initiatives will require extensive planning and management attention and entail substantial execution
risk. Notably, our strategy is focused on meaningful growth of vehicle volumes transaction through our
marketplaces. Such volume growth requires simultaneous success in several different domains including:
(i) commercial success with vendors, so they supply higher volume to our marketplaces; (ii) maintained data
leadership in order for the marketplaces to provide efficient liquidity to all participants; (iii) digital product
leadership to make our integrated services offering the most relevant in the market; and (iv) best-in-class
logistics and services footprint to deliver an integrated end-to-end digital and physical service. Failure to
maintain our competitive advantages in any of these dimension could have a material could have a material
adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, new digital
platforms will also require substantial IT support and infrastructure and, as we grow, we will need to ensure
our back-office IT systems are integrated across our operations.

With respect to the Vehicle Buying division, our strategy places particular importance on expanding
WeBuyAnyCar’s operations. However, there can be no assurance that WeBuyAnyCar will continue to grow in
the UK. As we seek to expand car buying into new markets, we may also need to comply with unfamiliar
regulatory regimes. In addition, because car buying involves purchasing vehicles and holding them as
inventory until their sale (in contrast to our UK Vehicle Remarketing division and our International Vehicle
Remarketing division, which do not include WeBuyAnyCar’s operations, and do not take title to the majority
of vehicles that they sell), the expansion of such operations may increase our cash requirements and inventory
risk, thereby increasing our depreciation and impairment charges. Similarly, recalls by OEMs are a common
occurrence and have accelerated in frequency and scope in recent years. In case of such recalls, we may have to
temporarily remove the affected used vehicles from our inventory and may be unable to liquidate such
inventory in a timely manner or at all. The same may occur if regulatory changes (e.g., the introduction of
stricter emission standards) prevent consumers from driving certain used vehicles in cities or at all,
consequently reducing demand for the affected vehicles. If we are unable to sell the vehicles purchased at an
appropriate price, or at all, we may incur write-downs or our business, prospects, financial condition and
results of operations may be adversely affected.

In addition, the implementation of our strategic initiatives in certain international markets may not produce
the benefits achieved in markets where we already have established operations. Each new market that we enter
will require us to address the particular economic, currency, political and regulatory risks associated with that
new market, which may entail finding new partners, hiring and training new staff with local language skills
and an understanding of the local market, and learning the customs and cultures of the new country. These
processes can be difficult, costly and divert management and personnel resources. Additionally, our business
strategies may change from time to time, which could delay our ability to implement initiatives that we believe
are important to our business.

Our inability to successfully implement our strategic initiatives could result in, among others, the loss of
clients and personnel, the loss of market share, the impairment of assets and inefficiencies from operating in
new markets, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition
and results of operations.

**_We may be unable to successfully identify and acquire or integrate future acquisitions into our business._**

Our growth has been, in part, attributable to the acquisition of other businesses, and we may continue to
expand our business through acquisitions and other business combinations in the future. The success of our
acquisition strategy will depend on our ability to identify suitable acquisition candidates, to assess the value,
strengths, weaknesses, contingent or other liabilities and potential profitability of acquisition candidates, to
negotiate acceptable purchase terms, to obtain any necessary permits or approvals and to integrate the
operations of such businesses, once acquired. Successful integration of future acquisitions will depend on our
ability to effect any necessary changes in operations or personnel resulting from the acquisition. Acquisitions
may also expose us to new risks, including difficulties in integrating and operating businesses in countries that
are new to us, difficulties integrating acquired businesses in a cost-effective manner, unforeseen legal,
regulatory, contractual, employment or other issues or expenses arising out of an acquisition, potential
disruptions to our ongoing business caused by acquisitions, including pressure on management’s time and
resources, or an acquired business’ failure to meet our expectations or business plans. The occurrence of any


-----

of these risks could have an adverse impact on our ability to make acquisitions and may limit our growth,
which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of
operations.

**_We may not be able to provide financing in order to offer stock funding (trade finance) to registered dealers_**
**_through BCA Partner Finance or to repossess the financed vehicles serving as collateral._**

To support the attractiveness of our offering, we seek to help certain registered dealers in the UK by offering
stock funding (trade finance). To this end, we have entered into a £220 million non-recourse receivables facility
(the “Receivables Facility”) with a syndicate of banks, who provide the liquidity to support our BCA Partner
Finance business, of which £148.3 million was drawn as of March 28, 2021. If these banks are no longer
willing to provide financing to us or only grant such financing on disadvantageous terms, we may not be able
to offer attractive financing options to registered dealers. As a result, demand for our used vehicles may suffer
and we may not be able to grow our business as envisaged.

In addition, we use our sold vehicles as security when offering stock funding (trade finance) and cooperate
with third-party collection agents to repossess such vehicles, should registered dealers default on their
obligations. We may, however, not be able to locate the relevant vehicles and successfully repossess them (e.g.,
if they are transported outside the UK). Furthermore, the residual value of the repossessed vehicles may be
lower than anticipated (e.g., if they are involved in accidents), and we may not be able to take recourse against
the relevant car dealer. As a result, we may incur significant losses even where we use sold vehicles as security
for BCA Partner Finance. See “Business—Operations—Value-Added Services—Post-auction Services.”

**_We may not be able to protect our intellectual property rights._**

Our intellectual property rights include proprietary technology and software relating to digital auction systems
as well as trademarks, trade secrets, copyrights and other intellectual property. Our increased reliance in
recent years on proprietary Internet-based programs and technology have increased the relative importance
of intellectual property assets to our business. Our business and IT systems and other key proprietary
intellectual property generally are not protected by patents or registered design rights. As a result, we are
particularly reliant on trademarks, copyright, database rights, registered domain names and the law protecting
confidential information to protect our brands, technologies, software and databases. Although we have taken
steps to reduce these risks, these steps may be inadequate. Effective intellectual property protection also may
not be available in every country in which our services are offered, deployed or made available. Any significant
impairment of our intellectual property rights or any inability to protect our intellectual property rights could
have an adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Moreover, we may be required to spend significant funds on monitoring and protecting our intellectual
property rights and we may not be able to discover all infringements, misappropriations or other violations of
our intellectual property. If we initiate litigation against infringements of our intellectual property, such
litigation may prove costly and there is no guarantee that it will ultimately be successful and that the rulings
we obtain will adequately remedy the damage we have suffered. In addition, we provide certain information to
third-party service providers who help us assess the performance of our business (e.g., Google Analytics).
Consequently, we only have limited control to ensure that such information is not misused by such service
providers or passed on to third parties, including our competitors.

**_We may be accused of infringing on the intellectual property of third parties._**

As we utilize a variety of intellectual property for our business, vendors, regulatory authorities or other third
parties may allege that we infringe on their intellectual property, and we may therefore become subject to
allegations and litigation against us. Even unfounded allegations of infringement may adversely affect our
reputation and business and may require significant resources to defend against. If we try to obtain licenses
from such third parties to settle these disputes, there is no guarantee that such licenses will be available to us
on acceptable terms, or at all, in which case we may be required to alter our brands and change the way we
operate.

Furthermore, some of the agreements we enter into with third parties may contain clauses regarding the
protection of their intellectual property licensed to us. A violation of these clauses (e.g., the unauthorized
sub-licensing or disclosure of a confidential source code) may require us to pay significant penalties, prevent
us from utilizing such intellectual property in the future and result in litigation against us. In addition, some of
our proprietary technology was developed on the basis of proprietary and non-proprietary software licensed
from third parties. If these licenses were to be challenged or found invalid through litigation or other


-----

proceedings, we may not be able to continue to utilize such proprietary technology. In addition, the licensors
or other third parties may claim that the use of such technology is outside the scope of the relevant license and
therefore infringes upon their intellectual property.

**_We may be adversely affected by changes in laws and regulations, in particular those governing the trading of_**
**_used vehicles and the automotive industry in general._**

We are required to comply with a wide range of laws and regulations relating to, among other things, the
purchase and sale of used vehicles, the state of such vehicles, the use of the internet, online payments,
consumer protection, data protection as well as road traffic, environmental, planning and employment
matters, and the application of such laws and regulations by local authorities may vary.

We may face risks associated with unexpected changes in the regulatory environment, particularly in relation
to complexity of domestic and international customs and tariffs, potentially adverse tax consequences,
restrictions on foreign trade or investment, currency exchange and capital controls, nationalization and
expropriation and cancelation of our contractual relationships without full compensation for loss.

Any changes in the laws and regulations, applicable to our business and operations, including used vehicles in
our inventory, as well as the Marketplace, or changes to the application and interpretation of such laws and
regulations by authorities and courts, may adversely affect our operations (such as the supply of vehicles) or
may give rise to substantial compliance costs, adjustment expenses and other costs as well as fines in
connection with our business activities, or prevent us from executing our strategy as planned. Even legislative
initiatives and the corresponding public debates could result in significant uncertainty, regardless of whether
such initiatives ultimately become law. We must comply with such regulations to the extent they are applicable
to us as noncompliance could lead to the imposition of fines or other sanctions.

**_Our failure to prevent unauthorized access to personal data or otherwise process personal data in accordance_**
**_with applicable data protection laws could result in legal liability for, and reputational harm._**

We process and store personal data as part of our business, including in relation to our employees, vendors
and buyers. Strict data protection laws exist in both the UK and throughout continental Europe. These data
protection laws require us to ensure an appropriate level of security of personal data, having regard to the
possibility of damage to and the nature of the data. Failure to take appropriate information security measures
could result in personal data being processed in an unauthorized or potentially unlawful manner.

The General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) (the “GDPR”) and the UK Data
Protection Act 2018 significantly change the data protection landscape in the EU and the UK. Such laws and
regulations strengthen the rights of individuals (data subjects), impose stricter controls over the processing of
personal data by both controllers and processors of personal data and impose stricter sanctions with
substantial administrative fines and potential claims for damages from data subjects for breach of their rights.
The GDPR also offers data subjects the option to allow privacy organizations to litigate on their behalf,
including collecting potential damages, which may result in a substantial increase in claims being brought.
Should a serious data breach occur, the GDPR provides for increased obligations to notify regulators and
data subjects whose personal data has been compromised and may result in the imposition of significant
sanctions and penalties, which will require heightened escalation and notification processes with associated
response plans. Complying with all relevant data protection laws and regulation is relatively complex. We, or
the entities or businesses acquired by us, may have entered in the past or may enter in the future into
employment agreements or other types of material contracts that may not be compliant with applicable data
protection laws and regulations. Moreover, our customers frequently require that we demonstrate our
compliance with data protection laws as they deem appropriate with respect to any personal data we may
process on their behalf. Failure to demonstrate such compliance to their satisfaction may result in action
including, but not limited to, the loss of contracts with such customers.

The failure to comply with our obligations under applicable data protection laws could potentially result in us
being issued with undertakings, enforcement notices (the failure with which to comply would be a criminal
offence) and fines, as well as suffer damage to our brand and reputation, any of which could have a material
adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We are subject to a variety of laws and regulations across the jurisdictions in which we operate, some of which are_**
**_unsettled and still developing._**

Our operations are subject to compliance with extensive laws and regulations, both in the UK and across
continental Europe, including, but not limited to, laws relating to vehicle brokerages and auctions, currency


-----

reporting obligations, data protection, competition, consumer protection, advertising, the Internet, property
usage, money laundering, bribery and taxation. A failure to comply with these laws and regulations could
result in fines, criminal sanctions, liability to third parties, license revocation and reputational damage, which
in turn could adversely affect our ability to conduct our business as well as our profitability. Furthermore, if
laws and regulations are not enforced equally against our competitors in a particular market, our compliance
with laws and regulations may put us at a competitive disadvantage vis-à-vis non-complying competitors.

Changes in laws or regulations or the adoption of new laws and regulations applicable to us may also increase
the costs of providing services or limit our ability to expand our service offerings, any of which could adversely
impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. More stringent laws or
regulations may impose additional burdens on us, and it is difficult to predict the impact of new or amended
laws or regulations to which we may become subject. There is, and will likely continue to be, an increasing
number of laws, regulations and court decisions pertaining to the Internet and online commerce, which may
relate to liability for information retrieved from or transmitted over the Internet. For example, in certain
jurisdictions where we operate, local regulations impose restrictions on or prohibit credit and debit card
operations in order to protect the privacy and security of personal information that is collected, processed
and transmitted in or from the governing jurisdiction. The growth and development of online commerce has
also prompted calls for more stringent consumer protection laws and more aggressive enforcement efforts by
regulatory authorities that may impose additional burdens on online businesses generally.

Because of our relatively large physical property portfolio, we are also subject to the risk that we could be
compelled by government authorities to sell or vacate the property on which we operate or to make significant
changes to the operations and activities we undertake to comply with changes to planning regulations.

Furthermore, because of our international operations, the various regulatory regimes to which we are subject
may conflict so that compliance with the regulatory requirements in one jurisdiction may create regulatory
issues in another, thereby making compliance more difficult and increasing the costs of conducting our
business. In addition, if we were to expand into new countries, we could face legal, regulatory or tax
requirements with which we are not familiar.

Compliance with current or future laws and regulations to which we are subject could place significant
demands on our resources, as well as subject us to unforeseen and potentially adverse legal, regulatory or tax
consequences, which could adversely impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of
operations.

**_Our costs could materially increase._**

Our largest cost is payroll, driven primarily by the number of our employees and their wages and salaries. If
relationships with our employees were to deteriorate, we could experience strikes, unionization efforts or
other types of conflicts, which could lead to interruption to our operations and increased costs. In addition,
payroll costs could increase because we compete with other service providers to recruit and retain skilled
employees, which has become more challenging as a result of Brexit and the related restrictions on free
movement of labor across the English Channel. High employment levels can lead to scarcity of staff and a
corresponding increase in the wages and salaries necessary to attract and retain suitable employees may be
indispensable in the future. In addition, future legislative changes relating to the minimum wage could
necessitate an increase in payroll costs.

We also undertake significant marketing activities, in particular for our Vehicle Buying division, and any
increase in television, radio and Internet advertising rates could increase our operating expenses. Moreover,
we incur significant fuel, power and other consumable supply costs across our operations that may escalate
and there can be no assurance that our costs will not grow at a faster rate than our revenue. If we are unable
to pass on future cost increases to our vendors or buyers, our operating profit margin could be adversely
affected, which could adversely impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We rely on the strength of our brands, and the costs of maintaining and enhancing our brand awareness may_**
**_increase._**

Our brands, corporate image and reputation constitute a significant part of our value proposition. Our success
over the years has largely depended on our ability to develop our brands and corporate image as a leading
vehicle auction company in the UK and continental Europe. In addition, the WeBuyAnyCar consumer brand
in the UK is particularly important to the Vehicle Buying division, and the development of the WeBuyAnyCar
brand historically has required significant financial expenditure, particularly on marketing and advertising.


-----

In order to maintain WeBuyAnyCar’s reputation, we have to be able to respond to changes in marketing and
advertising rules, consumer sentiment and consumer preferences, all of which may change rapidly and as a
result of factors outside of our control. Our brands could be adversely affected by the actions of other
companies that damage the reputation of our industry as a whole, in particular in relation to the Vehicle
Buying division, as several companies operate under names similar to WeBuyAnyCar’s name. As we seek to
expand our operations, maintaining and increasing the awareness and perceived quality of our brands and
corporate image will be important to attract and expand our vendor and buyer base.

We use Internet search engines, in particular Google, to generate traffic to our websites. The purchase of
keywords consists of anticipating words and terms consumers will use to search on Internet search engines
and then bidding on those words and terms in the applicable search engine’s auction system. Search engines,
including Google, frequently update and change the logic that determines the placement and display of results
of a search, such that the purchased or algorithmic placement of links to our websites can be adversely
affected. Our positioning on a search engine’s search results depends on algorithms designed by the search
engine provider and are based on various criteria including, in particular, the historical level of traffic on our
websites. As a result, if search engine providers change their search algorithms in a manner that is
competitively disadvantageous to us, our ability to generate traffic to our websites would be harmed.
Furthermore, our mobile applications rely on app stores operated by third parties, in particular Apple, which
make mobile applications available for download. The structure of these app stores may change and
third-party operators may decide to exclude our mobile applications from their offering (e.g., if we do not
agree to changes in terms and conditions), which may adversely affect the availability of our mobile
applications. These operators may also charge us fees to list our mobile applications for download, which
could adversely affect our margins or result in us discontinuing to offer our mobile applications through
third-party app stores.

We will continue to invest in, and devote resources to, advertising and marketing, as well as other efforts to
preserve and enhance customer awareness of our brands. In particular, we expect to spend significant amounts
on television, radio and Internet advertising to support WeBuyAnyCar, which is a purely customer brand.
There can be no assurance, however, that our advertising campaigns will successfully maintain or enhance
customer awareness of our brands. Advertising campaigns may be ineffective and may even have adverse
effects on website traffic and brand perception as a result of factors potentially out of our control, such as
changes in consumer preferences and regulatory reforms impacting advertising and marketing rules. Even if
we are successful in our branding efforts, significant costs are incurred in order to develop, deploy and update
our advertising campaigns, and as a result our efforts may not be cost-effective because, among others,
assumptions regarding required customer acquisition costs and resulting revenue prove to be incorrect. In
addition, we cannot guarantee that our current marketing channels will continue to be effective, permissible
and generally available to us in the future. For television marketing, the program during which we broadcast
our commercials may not achieve the anticipated number of viewers. For our online marketing, the relevant
partners may be unable to deliver the anticipated traffic to our website and mobile applications. In particular,
the popularity of social media channels tends to fluctuate, making it difficult to predict which channels are
best suited to reach a mass audience. Moreover, any negative publicity may be accelerated through social
media (e.g., Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) due to its immediacy and accessibility as a means of
communication. Social media and websites immediately publish posts from users, often without filters or
checks on the accuracy of the content posted. New and existing customers value readily available information
concerning digital offerings and often act on such posts without further investigation or authentication.
Allegations against us may be posted on social media, in Internet chat rooms or on blogs or websites by
anyone on an anonymous basis. Any negative publicity, even if factually incorrect or based on isolated
incidents, or the failure to maintain or enhance customer awareness of our brands and generate demand in a
cost-effective manner could damage our reputation, diminish the strength of our brands, undermine the trust
and credibility we have established, have a negative impact on our ability to attract new or retain existing
customers and require us to spend significant time and money to address such negative publicity.

**_We may not be able to effectively communicate with our customers through email and other messages._**

We use newsletters (e.g., emails) as a free marketing tool to promote our digital and physical offering, website
and mobile applications. Our emails may, however, be shown as “spam”or given a lower priority, which could
reduce the likelihood of addresses opening or responding positively to them. Actions by third parties to
block, impose restrictions on, or charge for the delivery of, emails and other messages, as well as legal or
regulatory changes limiting our right to send such messages or imposing additional requirements, could impair
our ability to communicate with customers. If we are not able to use unpaid marketing tools in the form of
emails or other messages efficiently, this could impair our marketing efforts or make them more expensive if
we have to increase spending on paid marketing channels.


-----

Furthermore, malfunctions of our email and messaging services could result in erroneous messages being sent
and customers no longer wanting to receive any messages from us. Furthermore, our process to obtain consent
from visitors to our website and users of our mobile applications to receive newsletters and other messages
from us and to allow us to use their data may be insufficient or invalid or become so as result of regulatory or
legislative changes. As a result, such individuals or third parties may accuse us of sending unsolicited
advertisements and other messages, which could result in claims or regulatory action being brought against
us.

**_Dissatisfaction with our customer service could prevent us from expanding our business as intended._**

To provide customer service, we communicate via email and through our telephone hotlines. The satisfaction
of our customers depends in particular on the effectiveness of our customer service, in particular our ability
to deal with complaints (e.g., with respect to the quality of used vehicles, technical problems, payment and
shipping, defects and invoicing) in a timely and satisfying manner. Any unsatisfactory response or lack of
responsiveness (e.g., due to interruptions of our hotlines) could reduce customer satisfaction and loyalty and
therefore adversely affect our revenue and profitability.

**_We are exposed to risks associated with currency fluctuations._**

We report our results in pound sterling, and pound sterling is also our functional currency. However, we
conduct operations in the UK and continental Europe, as a result of which approximately 11% of our revenue
in the fiscal year 2021 was denominated in currencies other than pound sterling, with the significant majority
of this denominated in euro. Our results of operations may therefore be affected by both the transaction and
translation effects of foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations when we incur costs or earn revenue in a
currency other than the pound sterling. For example, because we report in pound sterling, our consolidated
results would be adversely affected by the depreciation of the euro relative to the pound sterling, as this would
result in reduced euro-denominated earnings, an effect which could increase were our European operations to
expand, and could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of
operations. In addition, we are subject to additional taxation as a result of any foreign exchange gain arising
in respect of the interest on our euro-denominated indebtedness, which could similarly have a material adverse
effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Environmental, health and safety risks could adversely affect our operating results and financial condition._**

We operate from multiple locations across the UK and continental Europe. Large numbers of vehicles are
stored and prepared for sale at these sites, and during that time releases of fuel, motor oil and other materials
may occur. In addition, members of the public and our employees come into close contact with vehicles
moving on or around our sites. Furthermore, our employed and contracted drivers collect and deliver large
numbers of vehicles across both the UK and continental Europe and our fleet of vehicle transporters carries
large numbers of vehicles annually. Consequently, our operations are subject to various environmental and
health and safety laws and regulations, including those governing the emission and discharge of pollutants
into the air and water, the generation, treatment, storage and release of hazardous materials and wastes and
the investigation and remediation of contamination, as well as regulations requiring adequate precautions to
prevent injuries arising from collisions and impacts with vehicles moving within our locations and on public
roads. For example, governments increasingly introduce low emission zones in certain geographical areas,
where the most polluting vehicles are regulated and vehicles with higher emissions, including vehicles in
support of the Automotive Services division, cannot enter, thereby limiting our operations. We may incur
expenditures relating to accidents causing injury to individuals, releases of hazardous materials, investigative,
remedial or corrective actions, claims by third parties and other environmental issues, and such expenditures,
individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial
condition and results of operations.

Our failure to comply with current or future environmental, health or safety laws or to obtain and comply
with permits required under such laws, could also subject us to significant liability or require costly
investigative, remedial or corrective actions, all of which could have a material adverse effect on our business,
prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Failure to attract and retain skilled technical employees and management personnel could harm our business._**

Our success is in part driven by the skills, experience and efforts of our management team and by the efforts,
ability and experience of key members of our management staff. The members of our senior management
team have extensive experience in the industry in which we operate and have skills that are critical to the


-----

operation of our business, including their relationships with, and understanding of the requirements of, the
relevant regulatory authorities in the industry in which we operate. We have implemented policies and
remuneration designed to retain and properly incentivize management; however, there can be no guarantee
that we will be able to attract and retain qualified candidates to replace or succeed members of senior
management, should the need arise. The loss of services of any of our management staff could significantly
weaken our management expertise and our ability to deliver our services efficiently and effectively, which
could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Because we operate in a rapidly changing and increasingly digitalized market, our success also depends to a
significant extent upon our ability to identify, attract, retain and motivate highly skilled and qualified technical
personnel. Our employees have specialized knowledge that is in high demand, and competition for suitably
qualified individuals with the relevant technical expertise in our industry and in the locations in which we
operate is intense and may further increase as more vehicle auction companies in the UK and continental
Europe shift their operating model towards an online business in response to the COVID 19 pandemic. We
have a dedicated team of data scientists and have been able to utilize our data pool to develop highly accurate
pricing capabilities based on age, mileage and condition, which permit us to maximize margins in real time. If
we are unable to identify, attract, develop, motivate, adequately compensate and retain well-qualified and
engaged personnel, or if existing highly skilled and specialized personnel leave us and successors or adequate
replacements are not readily available, we may not be able to manage our operations effectively, which could
cause us to suffer delays in new service offerings, experience difficulty complying with applicable requirements
or otherwise fail to satisfy our customers’ demands, which would have an adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.

The difficulties in identifying, attracting and retaining suitable management personnel and employees are
exacerbated as a result of Brexit and free movement complications in relation thereto, which make travel
between the UK and continental Europe more difficult. In addition, we bear the risk that our key management
and key personnel becomes infected with COVID 19, and the measures adopted in response to the COVID 19
pandemic could make the integration of newly hired personnel more challenging. See “—The COVID 19
_pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our business, operations, financial_
_condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain.”_

**_We are subject to a substantial number of non-terminable long-term leases._**

We lease the majority of our properties, primarily comprising properties in the UK, pursuant to long-term
leases. These leases do not include break clauses. As a result, if we ceased operations at properties which we
could not subsequently sublet, we would continue to incur significant lease payments on these properties.

In addition, as we continue to shift our operations towards a fully digital business model, we may be required
to adapt the use of some or all of our properties. We may also decide to dispose of certain of our properties or
may seek to terminate certain of our leases. Similarly, if and when business operations resume and return to
pre-pandemic levels (see “—The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant adverse
_effect on our business, operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of_
_the COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain”), we may also seek changes to our overall composition of portfolio of_
properties, or the related use thereof. Moreover, the current use of our properties may not necessarily be
appropriate or cost efficient for future operations. However, there can be no guarantee that it will be legally
permissible to change the use of our properties at such time or that we will be able to dispose of properties on
commercially reasonable terms or at all. Similarly, we cannot guarantee that we will be able to renegotiate
long-term leases, especially if we were to seek the termination of a lease that does not include a break clause.

**_We use standardized documents, contracts and terms and conditions, which may adversely affect our operations if_**
**_any agreement or clause were held to be invalid._**

We maintain relationships with a large number of vendors and buyers and, in this context, we regularly use
standardized terms and conditions, in particular in relation to the terms and conditions of sale and purchase
on our remarketing platforms and the terms and conditions applicable to WeBuyAnyCar customers.
Standardized terms and conditions have to comply with the statutory laws on general terms and conditions in
the different jurisdictions in which we operate, which means that in many jurisdictions they are subject to
intense scrutiny by the courts. The standard is even stricter if such terms and conditions are used vis-à-vis
private consumers, such as in our WeBuyAnyCar business. If standardized documents, contracts, or terms
and conditions we use contain provisions which are interpreted in a manner disadvantageous to us, or if any
clauses are held to be invalid and thus replaced by statutory provisions which are disadvantageous to us, a
large number of our contractual relationships could be affected. This could provide our counterparties with


-----

unexpected legal rights and remedies (e.g., withdrawal rights), cause us to incur unexpected expenses and
prevent us from operating our business as currently operated. In some cases, courts may even determine that
our standardized terms and conditions are generally invalid, and as a result we may not have entered into a
valid contractual relationship with the relevant counterparty.

**_We have several defined contribution pension schemes in certain continental European countries as well as two_**
**_defined benefit pension plans in the UK, some of which are in deficit._**

We participate in several defined contribution pension schemes in the UK and certain continental European
countries as well as two defined benefit pension plans in the UK. Our cash funding obligations are set in
accordance with applicable pension legislation, assessed on a triennial basis and required to be agreed between
us and independent trustees. Our cash funding obligations are further subject to increases in life expectancy.
Our total contribution to these defined contribution schemes in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021
was £6.4 million. We cannot guarantee that our future cash contributions will not undermine our capacity to
satisfy our debt obligations, including the Notes.

In addition, the two defined benefit pension plans in the UK are in deficit. As of March 28, 2021, the two
defined benefit pension plans in the UK had a deficit of £12.4 million (2020: £15.1 million). Plan liabilities, in
respect of defined benefit obligations, are calculated on a discounted basis using a discount rate which is set
with reference to corporate bond yields. If the plan assets underperform such yield, then this will create a
deficit. The trustees of each plan, and their advisors, carry out regular reviews of asset allocations within each
plan and consider the need to switch assets in line with the investment strategies. However, the plans hold only
a portion of assets as defensive assets (government and corporate bonds) and we cannot guarantee that the
level of investment risk is reduced appropriately as the maturity approaches for each plan.

Moreover, while we have contractual caps on the level of inflationary increases to be applied to pension
obligations in order to protect the plans from extreme inflation, our pension liabilities in deferment are linked
and subject to inflation. Accordingly, we cannot guarantee that an increase in inflation will not lead to an
increase in our pension deficit. Furthermore, plan assets are likely to decrease following an increase in the
interest rate. This is due to an increase in interest rates having the effect of a decrease in value of the defensive
assets held by the plans. While such risk is partially mitigated by the measurement of plan liabilities being
linked to bond yields, any decrease in interest rates has the effect of decreasing bond yields, which in turn
increases plan liabilities. Accordingly, the materialization of any of these risks, if significant, could adversely
affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Significant differences exist between certain accounting principles, such as IFRS 16 and IAS 17, which may be_**
**_material to investors’ assessments of our financial condition, and certain financial information in this Offering_**
**_Memorandum is derived from unaudited management accounts, which are not comparable to audited financial_**
**_information._**

IFRS 16 (Leases) became effective on January 1, 2019 and applies to the first full fiscal year commencing on
or after that date. Accordingly, we have applied IFRS 16 since the fiscal year 2020. We have adopted IFRS 16
under the modified retrospective approach on April 1, 2019, with the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 16
on adoption recognized as an adjustment to opening equity. Under this approach, comparative information
for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 is not restated and, as a result, no IFRS 16 adjustments have
been made to the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements. Accordingly, the financial information
included in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, the 2020
Predecessor Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information, may not be
comparable insofar as they relate to the application of IFRS 16 (Leases). See “Presentation of Financial and
_Other Information—IFRS Financial Information—Application of IFRS 16.”_

**_We have included in this Offering Memorandum certain unaudited adjusted data, which gives effect to the_**

**_in accordance with IFRS._**

We have included in this Offering Memorandum certain unaudited adjusted data, which gives effect to the

data) included in this Offering Memorandum have been prepared for information purposes only and have not


-----

been prepared in accordance with IFRS, U.S. GAAP or any other internationally accepted accounting
principles or audited or reviewed in accordance with any applicable auditing standards. These non-IFRS
measures and other information are not identified as accounting measures under IFRS and therefore should
not be considered as alternative measures to evaluate our performance. The non-IFRS measures and other

We have also included certain unaudited financial information prepared in accordance with IAS 17 (Leases),
which is an accounting standard that was superseded by IFRS 16. Such unaudited financial information has

(Leases), and has not been audited. As such, it is not comparable to the audited results due to adjustments
and should not be regarded as a substitute for the Consolidated Financial Statements or financial data

Moreover, some of the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is adjusted for the

Adjusted EBITDA is not comparable to the audited results and should not be regarded as a substitute for the

Moreover, IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA is included for, among other periods, the 53-week period ended

In addition, we have included certain unaudited aggregated financial information for the 52-week period

The foregoing financial data has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of
