**Overview**

We operate leading digital used vehicle marketplaces (both business to business (“B2B”) and consumer to
business (“C2B”)) in the UK and B2B marketplaces in continental Europe and are a leading provider of
associated automotive services, including vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet
management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. We have physical presence in 10 countries
across the UK and continental Europe as well as unmatched sourcing, data, technology and logistics
capabilities. As of March 28, 2021, our business comprises:

- a leading B2B digital used vehicle marketplace across the UK and continental Europe, which facilitated the
sale of approximately 1.5 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 1.2 million vehicles in the fiscal year
2021;

- a leading C2B digital used vehicle marketplace in the UK, WeBuyAnyCar, with sold volumes of 321,000
vehicles and 300,000 vehicles in the fiscal years 2020 and 2021, respectively, reflecting the COVID 19
restrictions on the business that now has an annualized run rate of 461,000 vehicles (based on trading in
March, April and May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period); and

- a leading automotive logistics service business in the UK, which moved more than 2.8 million vehicles in
the UK in the fiscal year 2020 and 2.4 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2021, and stored, refurbished and
processed more than 950,000 vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 675,000 in the fiscal year 2021.

We estimate that for the fiscal year 2020 we came in contact with approximately one in every three vehicles in
the UK (approximately 29 million touch points, of which approximately 13 million were unique vehicles out
of a vehicle parc of approximately 41 million, and including approximately 24 million digital touch points).
Through our digital used vehicle marketplaces (the “Marketplace”), we are a critical liquidity provider to the
used vehicles market across the UK and continental Europe, matching the complex requirements of both
vendors and buyers and also facilitating the purchase of individual vehicles from consumers. The Marketplace
facilitates speedy disposal of high volumes of vehicles and offers a broad range of consistently graded vehicle
stock, thereby providing efficiency, liquidity (i.e., fast disposal of vehicle stock) and choice. Moreover, we are
the UK’s leading provider of automotive services solutions.

By providing a full suite of auction and automotive services, we offer our customers solutions for almost all
stages of the vehicle life-cycle, beginning as soon as the new car arrives at the port. Our scope of services
provides synergistic benefits across our divisions, as our vehicle sales platforms, together with our automotive
services solutions, generate vehicle and pricing data used in both our vehicle remarketing and vehicle buying
operations.


-----

Throughout the COVID 19 pandemic, we have accelerated our digital transition and now transact digitally
almost 100% of our volumes through online channels. We integrate our digital and physical assets to provide
innovative multi-service solutions, maximizing speed, intelligence and performance across our comprehensive
offerings. In the fiscal year 2021, 100% (2020: 37%) of our auction volumes in the UK Vehicle Remarketing
division and 96% (2020: 84%) of our auction volumes in the International Vehicle Remarketing division were
transacted online, which is a testament to our successful shift towards a predominantly digital online business
model moving forward.

In the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021, we generated £253.1 million of IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA,
as compared to £232.8 million, £204.1 million and £174.4 million in the 52-week period ended March 28,
2021, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019,
respectively.

We operate through three main business lines: (i) the B2B Marketplace business line, which is comprised of
our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, our International Vehicle Remarketing division and our Vehicle Buying
division’s operations in continental Europe, (ii) the C2B Marketplace business line, which is WeBuyAnyCar,
our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in the UK, and (iii) the Automotive Services business line, which is
accounted for in our Automotive Services division.

- B2B Marketplace: B2B Marketplace is our core business that facilitates the exchange of used vehicles
between vendors and buyers through primarily digital auctions. As of March 28, 2021, our digital auctions
are supported by 21 physical sites in the UK (23 as of June 1, 2021) and 30 physical sites in continental
Europe at which vehicles are stored, inspected, repaired and refurbished.

B2B Marketplace (which excludes WeBuyAnyCar) does not take title to the majority of vehicles that it sells,
but instead serves as an agent between vendor and buyer and recognizes revenues through auction transaction
fees as well as fees for a suite of value-added digital and physical pre- and post- auction services such as
inspections, appraisals, repairs, refurbishment, imaging, storage and handling. We also purchase vehicles
directly from certain corporate vendors under outsourced remarketing contracts, whereby we directly buy our
vendors’ inventory and have discretion over the remarketing channel through which we sell the vehicle. B2B
Marketplace takes title to such vehicles until the time of resale and recognizes revenues for the full sale value
of the vehicle less the cost of acquisition. Vehicles acquired pursuant to outsourced remarketing contracts are
typically resold within 15 to 30 days of acquisition and in turn generate additional revenue above the auction
fees.

B2B Marketplace also includes our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in continental Europe, which is
focused on purchasing batches of vehicles primarily from corporates in continental Europe.

In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division generated £90.5 million
of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £116.3 million; 52-week
period ended March 31, 2019: £109.4 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division
sold approximately 867,000 vehicles (2020: 1,063,000 vehicles; 2019: 1,030,0000 vehicles). In the 52-week
period ended March 28, 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division generated £29.2 million of IAS
17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £34.2 million; 52-week period ended
March 31, 2019: £33.7 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division sold
approximately 334,000 vehicles (2020: 401,000 vehicles; 2019: 388,000 vehicles).

- C2B Marketplace: C2B Marketplace is our C2B vehicle buying business which operates in the UK through
WeBuyAnyCar. WeBuyAnyCar purchases used vehicles directly from consumers, leveraging its proprietary
online pricing quotation systems and efficient physical inspection processes to facilitate purchases from
such consumers. WeBuyAnyCar has carried out a total of 2.2 million vehicle purchases since its inception
in 2006, and in the fiscal year ended March 28, 2021, WeBuyAnyCar recorded more than 22 million unique
visitors to its website and performed approximately 15.6 million valuations online. As of March 28, 2021,
WeBuyAnyCar operates in 357 locations across the UK, which are located within an average drive time of
under 14 minutes to customers. In addition, WeBuyAnyCar offers swift services to its consumers, allowing
them to obtain a quote in under 60 seconds and to then subsequently receive monies for the purchase of
their vehicle within 30 minutes of the sale being concluded.

C2B Marketplace remarkets the vehicles it purchases exclusively through B2B Marketplace within
approximately 10 days and accounted for 35% of the vehicles sold in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division in
the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This allows us to actively manage the volumes and mix on the
Marketplace, while helping to de-risk the supply of vehicles to the auction.


-----

C2B Marketplace’s consistent and growing profitability over the past years demonstrates our ability to
generate “metal margin” (accounted for in our Vehicle Buying division) on C2B vehicles in addition to core
auction buyer fees (accounted for in our UK Vehicle Remarketing division). Vehicles sourced via our C2B
Marketplace therefore result in higher profitability per vehicle for the CA Group. Our sophisticated and
proprietary pricing mechanism and real-time market data enable us to more accurately price the purchase of
vehicles to generate a profitable onward sale. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Vehicle Buying
division generated £44.0 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29,
2020: £27.7 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £24.1 million), which was predominantly generated
through C2B Marketplace (i.e., WeBuyAnyCar).

- Automotive Services: Automotive Services provides vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery
inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. With our refurbishment
offering (which has a 250,000 yearly vehicle refurbishment capacity), we are able to bring vehicles to either
wholesale standard or a “Retail Ready” standard (which refers to vehicles that are cosmetically and
mechanically prepared to be immediately placed for sale to end consumers and are therefore particularly
attractive to online car dealers). These standards increase prices achieved at auction and render it simpler
for dealers to on-sell the vehicle to consumers. We seek to develop a relationship with vendors and endeavor
to act as a one-stop shop for vehicles throughout the majority of their lifecycle, expanding our revenue
streams along the value chain and also positioning ourselves to be the preferred provider of remarketing
services when the vehicles come off lease or roll out of the fleet. Our overall infrastructure and logistics
network allow us to efficiently cover all key locations and major transport hubs in the UK. Automotive
Services helps maximize the benefit of operational leverage and intragroup efficiencies derived from the
wide-ranging scope of services offered, benefitting both our customers as well as our own operations.

Automotive Services generates revenue in the form of service fees. In the 52-week period ended March 28,
2021, Automotive Services generated £12.5 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period
ended March 29, 2020: £22.6 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £19.1 million).

**Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations**

The COVID 19 pandemic has had and will continue to have a significant impact on our results of operations.
In addition, our revenue and profits are largely dependent on the supply of vehicles to the Vehicle Remarketing
and Vehicle Buying divisions, the demand for vehicles sold by the Vehicle Remarketing divisions and the
availability of vehicles which require services provided by the Automotive Services division. Our results of
operations are further impacted by our acquisitions, seasonality and currency translation. Below is a detailed
discussion of each of these factors affecting our results of operations.

**_COVID 19_**

_General Impact_

Due to the unprecedented level of disruption to society and the automotive industry, including to car dealers,
leasing companies, fleet providers, original equipment manufacturers (“OEMs”), wholesale traders and private
consumers, as well as our employees and the way we operate our business, interactions at the Marketplace
were significantly reduced during the fiscal year 2021 with average weekly trading volume dipping to 4,000 at
the start of the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021, compared to 29,000 at the start of the fourth quarter of
the fiscal year 2020. The changes in operating environment spurred by the COVID 19 pandemic have
accelerated our shift towards a fully digital online business model with increased focus on the functionality
and usability of our digital platforms, as a result of which we were able to earn new contracts and increase our
market share in spite of the challenging market conditions. The scale of the transformation is demonstrated
by the fiscal year 2021 ending with 100% of UK auction sales having occurred online, compared to 37% in the
fiscal year 2020.

In addition to the enforced cessation of physical auctions in the UK, we faced restrictions such as site closures
impacting the operation of the WeBuyAnyCar retail estate and recorded a reduction in the movement and
inspection of vehicles within Automotive Services. Our customers evolved their business models, for example
by motor dealers operating a click-and-collect process during 2020 to be able to better deal with social
distancing restrictions and, by August 2020, average weekly trading volumes recovered to 31,000. With the
continuing progress on vaccinations across European countries, and the UK in particular, as well as
governments lifting restrictions to public life, we expect the demand for our services increase. The shift towards
a more digital operation model has, to an extent, mitigated the impact of COVID 19 and the lifting of
COVID 19 restrictions is expected to increase demand in the long term as dealers look to restock their
inventory.


-----

_Impact on Results of Operations_

For the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17
COVID Adjusted EBITDA were £190.1 million and £204.1 million, respectively, reflecting an estimated
COVID 19 impact of £14.0 million in the fiscal year 2020. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021,
IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA were £168.0 million and £232.8 million,
respectively, reflecting an estimated COVID 19 impact of £64.8 million in the fiscal year 2021. For the 52-week
period ended March 31, 2019, we reported an operating profit of £100.2 million. For the unaudited aggregated
52-week period ended March 29, 2020, we reported an operating loss of £224.5 million. For the 52-week
period ended March 28, 2021, we reported an operating profit of £47.4 million. We had cash and cash
equivalents of £113.2 million and £247.2 million as of March 28, 2021 and March 29, 2020, respectively.

_Measures Taken in Response to the COVID 19 Pandemic_

We have been and actively continue to monitor the impact of the COVID 19 pandemic on our operations, and
our priority has been the safety of our employees and other stakeholders. As governments in the jurisdictions
where we operate introduced restrictions at the outset of the COVID 19 pandemic, we quickly ceased physical
auctions and introduced social distancing and other modifications to our ways of working to remain
compliant. In response to the closure of our physical auction sites, we adopted swift measures to significantly
reduce cash outflows by reducing our operating cost and implementing cash control measures, with the aim of
maximizing our liquidity position. Specifically, we adopted the following measures, which were only necessary
during the time of the first lockdown in the UK during March 2020 to July 2020 and were not implemented
during the subsequent second and third lockdowns:

- successfully negotiated with debtors and creditors on payment terms;

- put on hold all non-essential and discretionary spend within the business, including any growth,
expansionary or investment capital expenditures and increased controls around the cash disbursement
process, including sign off by senior members of the finance team for any payments in excess of certain
reduced thresholds;

- negotiated tax deferrals with HMRC in respect of VAT and employment taxes; and

- entered into arrangements with landlords to defer rent payments during the period of closure and took
rates relief where available.

We also made furlough arrangements for those staff unable to work in the UK where we furloughed as much
as 80% of our staff at the peak of the COVID 19 pandemic in April 2020 and, in parallel, applied for employee
salary support schemes introduced by certain governments in continental Europe. Such schemes allow
companies to place employees on paid leave or on reduced working hours, with the difference to an employee’s
ordinary salary being partially reimbursed by the respective government. As of March 28, 2021, approximately
4% of our employees remained on short-term work. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 furlough
income across all jurisdictions totaled £35.5 million and rates relief totaled £8.3 million. As of March 28,
2021, remaining deferrals comprise VAT deferrals of £15.8 million, which are expected to be settled in full in
instalments during the fiscal year 2022. As a result of the numerous cost-cutting and transitory measures
taken at the beginning of the first lockdown in the UK, we came out of that lockdown with greater liquidity
compared to our liquidity going into such lockdown. From the end of the first lockdown in the UK, we have
managed to remain positive in terms of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA even in periods with government
restrictions comparable with the first lockdown in the UK. Given the success of our digital offering with our
clients and the level of profitability and efficiency achieved, we currently have no intention of reverting back
to our previous predominantly physical auction model.

_Impairment Review_

As of March 28, 2021, the intangible assets on our balance sheet totaled £1,937.9 million, including
£938.5 million in goodwill relating to the CA Acquisition. While goodwill impairment is tested annually, the
COVID 19 pandemic and its impact on our business constituted an impairment indicator that we assessed
with respect to all intangible assets as well as goodwill. The impairment review is performed on a “value-inuse” basis, which requires estimation of future net operating cash flows, the time period over which they will
occur, an appropriate discount rate and an appropriate growth rate. Any impairment charge is then recognized
in the income statement for any amount by which the carrying value of goodwill exceeds its recoverable
amount. As a result of our impairment review conducted as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic, we
recognized an exceptional goodwill impairment relating to the CA Acquisition in the amount of £266.4 million


-----

in the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. The impairment charge thereby specifically represented a change
in the timing of vehicle volumes and associated discounted cash flows, which were expected through the
Marketplace over the short term as economic activity recovers. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our
_Business—The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our_
_business, operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the_
_COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain.” We caution you that these impairment charges should not be regarded as_
an indication, forecast or representation by us or any other person regarding impairment charges for any
future period. See “Forward-looking Statements.”

**_Seasonality_**

Due to seasonal trends influencing both vehicle supply and demand, our revenue and operating results have
varied, and likely will continue to vary, from quarter to quarter. For example, used vehicle sales in the UK
tend to increase during vehicle registration plate change periods in March and September of each year. In
March, in particular, new vehicle sales traditionally peak in the UK, and as a result, dealer vendors of the
Vehicle Remarketing division typically experience an increase in part-exchange volumes, which has a
subsequent effect of increasing sales through the Marketplace. Conversely, our revenue typically decreases
during the summer and in December, a seasonality pattern that is followed by sales in both the Vehicle Buying
division and the Automotive Services division. As a result of these fluctuations, our revenue tends to be lowest
in the quarter ending in December and highest in the quarter ending March. In addition, there is a reduced
level of activity during the Christmas and New Year holiday period.

**_Currency Translation_**

We report our results in pound sterling, and pound sterling is also the functional currency of our UK
operations. However, we conduct operations in the UK and continental Europe, as a result of which
approximately 11% of our revenue in the fiscal year 2021 was denominated in currencies other than pound
sterling, with the significant majority of this denominated in euro. We also conduct a limited number of
transactions in a small number of other currencies.

Exchange rates between the pound sterling and the euro have ranged from €1.1605 per pound sterling on
March 31, 2019 to €1.1176 per pound sterling on March 29, 2020 and €1.1691 per pound sterling on March 28,
2021. Typically, our costs in a currency other than the pound sterling are matched by corresponding revenue
in that same currency. Our results of operations may nevertheless be affected by the translation effects of
foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations on converting the results of these operations reported in currencies
other than the pound sterling to sterling for group consolidation.

**Factors Affecting Comparability**

**_Fiscal Year Accounting Periods_**

Our fiscal year accounting periods typically run from the calendar day following the previous fiscal year end
to a Sunday within seven days of March 31. For the fiscal years 2021, 2020 and 2019, the relevant Sundays
were March 28, 2021, March 29, 2020 and March 31, 2019. While the Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial
Statements and the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements comprise the 52-week period ended
March 28, 2021 (from and including March 30, 2020 to and including March 28, 2021) and the 52-week
period ended March 31, 2019 (from and including April 2, 2018 to and including March 31, 2019), respectively,
the Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements only comprise the 42-week period ended March 29,
2020 (from and including June 10, 2019 to and including March 29, 2020). As such, the Fiscal Year 2020
Consolidated Financial Statements are not comparable to the other Consolidated Financial Statements since
they only cover the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020, representing the period from the incorporation
date of the Parent on June 10, 2019.

In addition, due to the CA Acquisition, which completed on November 6, 2019, the Fiscal Year 2020
Consolidated Financial Statements do not reflect our trading results during the period from April 1, 2019 to
November 5, 2019. Below is an overview of the trading history covered by the Consolidated Financial
Statements.

- The Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the results of operations of BCA
Marketplace and its subsidiaries from and including April 2, 2018 to and including March 31, 2019.
Accordingly, the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements represent 52 weeks of trading,
reflecting our results of operations prior to the CA Acquisition.


-----

- The Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the results of operations of the Parent and
Constellation Automotive (which were incorporated for the purpose of facilitating the CA Acquisition
and, as such, are holding companies with no operations and no assets other than the shares held) from and
including the date of incorporation of the Parent on June 10, 2019 to and including March 29, 2020.
During the period from June 10, 2019 to the completion date of the CA Acquisition on November 6, 2019,
the Parent had no activities and had very limited financial results to report. Following the consummation
of the CA Acquisition on November 6, 2019, our financial results are consolidated at the Parent level.
Accordingly, the Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements represent 145 days of trading,
reflecting our results of operations after the CA Acquisition.

- The Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the results of operations of the Parent
group from and including March 30, 2020 to and including March 28, 2021. Accordingly, the Fiscal Year
2021 Consolidated Financial Statements represent 52 weeks of trading.

**_Cinch_**

During the fiscal year 2020, we incurred certain start-up costs with respect to cinch, which was sold to an
affiliate of a parent company of the Parent in September 2020. Accordingly, the financial information included
in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, the 2020 Predecessor
Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information, may not be comparable
insofar as they relate to cinch across these periods.

**_Application of IFRS 16_**

IFRS 16 (Leases) became effective on January 1, 2019 and applies to the first full fiscal year commencing on
or after that date. Accordingly, we have applied IFRS 16 since the fiscal year 2020. We have adopted IFRS 16
under the modified retrospective approach on April 1, 2019, with the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 16
recognized on adoption as an adjustment to opening equity. Under this approach, comparative information
for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 is not restated and, as a result, no IFRS 16 adjustments have
been made to the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements. Accordingly, the financial information
included in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, the 2020
Predecessor Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information, may not be
comparable insofar as they relate to the application of IFRS 16 (Leases).

Following the CA Acquisition, a purchase price allocation exercise was undertaken in order to identify the
fair value of the assets and liabilities acquired thereunder, in line with IFRS 3 (Business Combinations).
IFRS 3 requires the revaluation of IFRS 16 right of use assets and lease liabilities using a revised incremental
borrowing rate (“IBR”). The IBR we used for these purposes increased significantly following the CA
Acquisition as a result of the indebtedness incurred in connection therewith. Due to the significant change in
IBR used for the valuation of right of use assets and lease liabilities resulting from the CA Acquisition, the
full year IFRS 16 depreciation and interest included in our Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information
represents the aggregation of (i) the pre-CA Acquisition IFRS 16 depreciation and interest calculated with
reference to the original, pre-CA Acquisition IBR and (ii) the post-CA Acquisition IFRS 16 depreciation and
interest calculated with reference to the revised, post-CA Acquisition IBR. Accordingly, the financial
information included in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, the
2020 Predecessor Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information, may not
be comparable.

**Description of Key Income Statement Line Items**

**_Revenue_**

Revenue consists of revenue attributable to the Vehicle Remarketing division, the Vehicle Buying division and
the Automotive Services division. Revenue from the Vehicle Remarketing division predominantly represents
transaction fees earned from vehicles sold, as well as revenue from value-added services. This also includes the
proceeds from the sale of some vehicles sold under outsourced remarketing contracts where we obtain control
and take legal title to certain vehicles, and interest and loan origination fees earned in respect of vehicle
finance. Revenue from the Vehicle Buying division comprises the proceeds from the sale through the Vehicle
Remarketing division of vehicles purchased from members of the public as well as expedited payment fees.
Revenue from the Automotive Services division comprises fees charged in relation to automotive transport,
refurbishment, storage and fulfilment services.


-----

**_Cost of Sales_**

Cost of sales for the Vehicle Remarketing division primarily comprises the costs of providing auction related
services and includes the cost of the vehicle purchased, where we take control and legal title. For the Vehicle
Buying division, cost of sales primarily comprises the cost of the vehicle purchased, as well as the labor and
site costs of the purchasing locations and labor costs of the disposals team, net of transaction fees charged on
each vehicle purchased. Costs of sales for the Automotive Services division primarily comprises the costs
incurred in providing services to customers, including labor, equipment and parts.

**_Operating Costs_**

Operating costs consists of all costs included in operating profit that are not included in cost of sales.

**_Finance Income_**

Finance income comprises interest receivable on funds invested and foreign exchange gains on finance
balances.

**_Finance Costs_**

Finance costs comprise interest payable on borrowings, direct transaction costs, unwinding of the discount
on provisions and lease liabilities, net interest cost of defined benefit pension arrangements and foreign
exchange losses on finance balances.

**_Share of Loss of Equity-accounted Investments_**

Share of loss of equity-accounted investments comprises our losses in relation to our share of profits or losses
from entities where we have significant influence but not control or joint control, which is generally the case
where we hold between 20% and 50% of the voting rights.

**_Income Tax (Charge)/Benefit_**

Income tax (charge)/benefit is based on the profit/(loss) before income tax for the period and takes into
account taxation deferred because of timing differences between the treatment of certain items for taxation
and accounting purposes. Deferred tax is recognized, without discounting, in respect of all timing differences
between the treatment of certain items for taxation and accounting purposes which have arisen but not been
reversed by the balance sheet date, except as otherwise required by IAS 12 (Income Taxes), for example tax
losses where there is no expectation those losses can be utilized.

payment for group relief for less than 19.0% which increased the tax credit for the period. Excluding the
effect of these items would give an effective tax rate of 13.4% for the period.

ended March 31, 2019 to £89.1 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. This decrease was

March 29, 2020 (i.e., 145 days) compared to the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 (i.e., 52 weeks) as a

was primarily as a result of the shorter trading period captured in the results for the 42-week period ended
March 29, 2020 (i.e., 145 days) compared to the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 (i.e., 52 weeks) as a

_Revenue_

Revenue increased by £367.7 million, or 21.9%, from £1,676.3 million for the 210-day period ended
October 28, 2018 to £2,044.0 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. Revenue in the UK
Vehicle Remarketing division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by £155.8 million, or 23.1%, from
£675.3 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £831.1 million for the 219-day period ended
November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to growth in outsourced remarketing contracts and
increased supply of vehicles, particularly from the Vehicle Buying division. Revenue in the International
Vehicle Remarketing division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by £21.0 million, or 20.8%, from
£101.2 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £122.2 million for the 219-day period ended
November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to increased sold volumes and an increase in transport
and export services. Revenue in the Vehicle Buying division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by
£159.0 million, or 23.1%, from £688.4 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £847.4 million
for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to increased volume of
vehicles purchased and the continuing refinement of the valuation process. Revenue in the Automotive
Services division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by £31.9 million, or 15.1%, from £211.4 million
for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £243.3 million for the 219-day period ended November 5,
2019. This increase was primarily due to the supply of vehicles returning to expected levels, increased
opportunities for higher value refurbishment services and the continuing efficiencies resulting from providing
integrated services to the wider CA Group.

**_Fiscal Year 2021 compared to Unaudited Aggregated 52-week Period ended March 29, 2020_**

Revenue decreased by £50.6 million from £3,504.6 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended
March 29, 2020 to £3,454.0 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA
decreased by £22.1 million from £190.1 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29,
2020 to £168.0 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA
increased by £28.7 million from £204.1 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29,
2020 to £232.8 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021.

We commenced the fiscal year 2021 with all markets operating under varying national government restrictions
in response to the COVID 19 pandemic. Swift actions were taken to reduce costs and preserve cash, including
furloughing a significant number of employees and utilizing government initiatives to support employment
costs for employees who were not able to contribute to the ongoing operation of the business. Management
also negotiated with landlords to reduce or defer rental payments and temporarily ceased all consumer vehicle
buying activity.

Physical auctions and the WeBuyAnyCar retail estate closed with a resulting reduction in the movement and
inspection of vehicles within Automotive Services. During April 2021, all auctions took place on our online
platforms initially populated with vehicles that had been imaged and graded before lockdown. At
commencement of the restrictions, demand was greatest for vehicles at lower price points. Over 90% of the
transporter fleet was taken off the road, with the remaining vehicle moves taking place to support key workers
and provide services to organizations which were not able to cease operations, including for example the
transportation of ambulances for the NHS. Vehicles continued to arrive into the UK by ship, and these
vehicles were received and stored in line with working regulations. Trading was similarly impacted across
continental Europe with differing lockdown restrictions impacting sales and cross-border movements. The
magnitude of the COVID 19 impact on economic activity practically mitigated any post-Brexit trading impact
on the business.

As European countries began to ease restrictions and the UK government announced that car dealerships
could reopen from June 1, 2020, we saw demand increase across our online platforms and were able to
recommission our transport capabilities to support the vehicle logistics of vendors and buyers. Trading
rebounded in the second quarter of the fiscal year 2021 as restrictions were lifted and the workforce largely
returned from furlough. Strong stable pricing provided good operational efficiencies with predictable results
for buyers and sellers. Refreshed versions of BCA Live Online and the BCA Buyer mobile application provide
enhanced insight every time a buyer looks at, bids on or buys a vehicle. We were well placed to capitalize on
pent-up demand with all UK auctions fully digital, utilizing BCA Live Online and the BCA Buyer mobile
application.

At the end of the second quarter of the fiscal year 2021, we launched the “Retail Ready” digital sales channel
exclusively for trade customers to meet demand for high quality vehicles and to shorten inventory holding
times. The channel offers vehicles prepared cosmetically and mechanically to a new industry retail standard
allowing dealers to immediately place these vehicles onto their forecourt with little or no preparation and cost.


-----

The momentum continued into the third quarter of the fiscal year 2021 despite ongoing restrictions across
continental Europe and the introduction of tiered restrictions in the UK. Customers continued to develop
their online as well as click and collect capabilities in order to continue trading at scale in this environment.

It was not until the return of a stricter lockdown in the UK that spanned the whole of the fourth quarter of
the fiscal year 2021 that activity was again significantly suppressed. The impact on trading was far less than in
the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021, reflecting the adaptability and resilience of the used car sector and the
incremental developments to our digital capability. The end of the Brexit transition period on December 31,
2020 provided limited disruption in comparison to the impact of COVID 19 restrictions.

_Divisional Review_

UK Vehicle Remarketing

The division generated revenue of £1,308.9 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £90.5 million for the
52-week period ended March 28, 2021 compared to £1,377.1 million and £116.3 million for the unaudited
aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. The division’s volumes, revenues and Reported Adjusted
EBITDA were adversely impacted by the COVID 19 pandemic restrictions during the fiscal year 2021. Our
revenues are impacted by the mix of vehicles for which we take title, whereby the full auction price of vehicles
sold is recognized as revenue, and those where we serve as an agent between vendor and buyer, for which
revenues are recognized in relation to auction fees as well as fees for a suite of value-added digital and physical
pre- and post- auction services.

To enable vendors and buyers to continue to trade with confidence, UK Vehicle Remarketing accelerated its
digital transformation, trading fully online during the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 (2020: 37%).
After the temporary cessation of physical auctions at the end of the fiscal year 2020, the division commenced
first quarter trading using its existing online auction platforms, including BCA Buyer mobile application,
BCA Live Online and BCA Buy Now with vehicles that had been imaged and prepared prior to the
implementation of pandemic restrictions. Working practices were revised through April 2020 and May 2020,
so vendor vehicles could be received and processed in line with working regulations. When automotive
dealerships were allowed to reopen on June 1, 2020, the division saw strong demand and stable pricing which
continued into the third quarter of the fiscal year 2021, with record sales volumes in September 2020 of over
25,000 units per week for four consecutive weeks.

September 2020 saw the introduction of our “Retail Ready”sales channel. Utilizing our expertise in wholesale
vehicle storage and refurbishment has enabled the division to introduce and define “Retail Ready” as a new
vehicle condition standard. This digital channel hosts vehicles prepared cosmetically and mechanically,
covering the repair of bodywork dents, stone chips, paint repairs, wheels, glass and lights, interior upholstery,
and tire condition and compatibility checks. Once refurbished, the vehicles are fully retail valeted and come
with a valid service for at least three months or 2,000 miles, a valid Ministry of Transport (MOT) certificate
for at least 6 months and all auxiliary items such as Satellite Navigation SD cards and charging cables present.
This enables customers to immediately place these vehicles onto their forecourt with no preparation time and
cost required.

The business has undergone significant changes to sales day operations, and during the third quarter of the
fiscal year 2021, the UK Vehicle Remarketing division reorganized the workforce, resulting in redundancies of
certain branch based roles. The tiered restrictions in the UK during November 2020 and December 2020, and
the full lockdown across the UK in the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2021 did not impact the business as
severely as the initial lockdown as our customers had evolved their ability to operate with social distancing
and other restrictions in place.

Outsourced remarketing contract volumes have been impacted, reflecting reduced lease churn and de-fleet
activity throughout the fiscal year 2021.

BCA Partner Finance continues to support buyer demand in our marketplace with penetration at 10.6% of
UK Vehicle Remarketing sales funded by BCA Partner Finance (2020: 12.7%). The reduction in penetration
has been due to dealers taking a more conservative position on their volumes and also the level of government
support that has been available throughout the fiscal year 2021.

International Vehicle Remarketing

The division generated revenue of £190.1 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £29.2 million for the
52-week period ended March 28, 2021 compared to £201.0 million and £34.2 million for the unaudited


-----

aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. Availability of volumes was suppressed across Europe as
leasing companies and OEMs experienced delays in the return of financed vehicles and there was reduced
availability of new vehicles following COVID 19 disruptions. This was partially offset by some additional
international cross border buying activity undertaken in response to the various levels of supply and demand
seen across different markets, supported by our transport network of accredited partners. Average profitability
per vehicle increased driven by changes in country mix, in part reflecting the differing impacts of COVID 19
restrictions and increased export fee penetration.

In June 2020, the International Vehicle Remarketing division commissioned its first automated
inspection units in continental Europe, and at the end of the fiscal year 2021 were operating a number of
automated units in Denmark, France and the Netherlands. These drive-through units assess vehicle condition,
reducing the need for manual inspection and ensuring a consistent and accurate assessment.

The division also established a new vehicle reconditioning center in France in partnership with Emil Frey,
which began operation in August 2020. This facility offers refurbishment and grade enhancement to our
vendors, maximizing sales performance at auction.

Towards the end of the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2021, the division experienced renewed restrictions in
some of the markets in which it operates across Europe as national governments address increased COVID19
infection levels.

Vehicle Buying

The division generated revenue of £1,665.3 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £44.0 million for the
52-week period ended March 28, 2021 compared to £1,529.8 million and £27.7 million for the unaudited
aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. WeBuyAnyCar continues to maintain its place as a market
leading C2B business in the UK online direct car buying market. Revenue and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA
increased period-on-period driven by higher revenue per units sold partially offset by lower annual volume
sold. Despite the significant disruption to the division’s retail estate during the fiscal year 2021, with long
periods of enforced closure, the buying network continued to expand in order to provide convenience for
consumers ending the year with 357 sites (2020: 315). Vehicles are sold from sites across the UK Vehicle
Remarketing estate and now include three WeBuyAnyCar dedicated selling centers.

The division supplies a controlled and diverse range of vehicles across all makes and marques, to support the
UK Vehicle Remarketing division auction sales program. During the fiscal year 2021, WeBuyAnyCar delivered
a new record volume week and purchased its 2 millionth vehicle 15 years after commencing trading and only
four years after achieving the 1 millionth vehicle milestone. This accelerated volume is underpinned by the
continued growth in brand recognition and consumer trust from the public. Our Christmas Day TV
advertising campaign was met with strong consumer interest, with record festive period website visits. As the
brand builds the division is expanding the marketing and advertising channels across digital platforms
(Facebook, YouTube, etc.) to broaden engagement with a wider audience.

The move to 100% online auctions in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division, and the development of three
dedicated selling hubs means we are better able to track and analyze customer demand and ensure we are
servicing it appropriately. Inventory at March 28, 2021 was £107.0 million (March 29, 2020: £44.2 million),
reflecting the continued growth in the business compared with a period of inventory reduction in the prior
year as COVID 19 restrictions came into place.

Within continental Europe, Vehicle Buying has increased 17.4% on prior year as we have improved our market
intelligence enabling us to better identify vehicle demand. We continue to focus on opportunities to raise
awareness of auction, purchasing batches of vehicles that enrich the remarketing programs for both vendors
and buyers.

Automotive Services

The division generated revenue of £288.5 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £12.5 million for the
52-week period ended March 28, 2021 compared to £396.6 million and £22.6 million for the unaudited
aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. During the fiscal year 2021, the division was adversely
impacted by the COVID 19 restrictions in the UK, with the majority of vehicle movements restricted, most of
the fleet off the road and employees furloughed. The division did maintain some activity during COVID 19
restrictions, especially supporting key workers and the emergency services, including through the movement
of ambulances for the NHS.


-----

Government initiatives were used to support employment costs, and rent deferrals were negotiated with
landlords and finance companies. Activity began to recommence in June 2020, following the easing of
restrictions and reopening of car dealerships, with all business areas returning to profitability and delivering
higher margin work that could not be performed earlier in the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021. The division
continued to increase the penetration of internal moves and refurbishments for UK Vehicle Remarketing,
utilizing an increased transporter fleet following the strategic acquisition of used transporters from some
smaller distressed operators, driving increased internal efficiency and reduced costs.

Logistics continued to see strong demand from leasing companies for inspections and collections following
easing of lockdown restrictions, and vehicle flow efficiency returned to our Fleet Solutions and Vehicle
Services sites as dispatches to customers returned to normal levels post-lockdown.

During the fiscal year 2021, Fleet Solutions utilized the capability and expertise developed in preparing and
refurbishing fleet vehicles to establish and support the newly developed “Retail Ready” industry vehicle
standard. In order to support “Retail Ready,”we announced the development of the new 65-acre mega-center
in Bristol. Leveraging our strong and well established integrated capability has enabled the division to
accelerate the delivery of “Retail Ready” vehicles to support the new sales channel.

**_Unaudited Aggregated 52-week Period ended March 29, 2020 compared to Fiscal Year 2019_**

Revenue increased by £476.6 million from £3,028.0 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to
£3,504.6 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. IAS 17 Adjusted
EBITDA increased by £15.7 million from £174.4 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to
£190.1 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. IAS 17 COVID Adjusted
EBITDA increased by £29.7 million from £174.4 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to
£204.1 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020.

The period-on-period growth in revenue, IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA
has been driven by increased sales of vehicles by the Vehicle Buying division and strong performance in
outsourced remarketing contracts (where we typically account for the full vehicle value within revenue), which
continued to deliver growth in vehicle sold volumes. Increased sales, control over variable operating costs and
overhead efficiency from greater volume throughput contributed to IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA growth. This
strong trading performance has been delivered despite the disruption to trading during the latter half of
March 2020 and after taking into account additional provisions against vehicle values as a result of COVID
19.

During March 2020, national governments across Europe responded to the COVID 19 pandemic and
implemented restrictions including social distancing lockdown arrangements, resulting in a cessation of
physical auctions, the closure of the WeBuyAnyCar retail estate and a significant reduction in the movement
and inspection of vehicles within Automotive Services. This had a significant impact on financial performance
during March 2020, as a large element of our operating costs relate to payroll, property and transporter
leases. Given the speed at which restrictions were imposed, it was not possible to reduce costs at the same rate
as the reduction in operating activity. We furloughed over 80% of employees, and utilized government
initiatives across Europe to support employment costs, retail premises rents and business rates. Management
negotiated with landlords to reduce or defer rental payments, to maximize liquidity throughout the
restrictions. At the end of the fiscal year 2020, management recognized an exceptional COVID 19 related
goodwill impairment. This reflected the impact of the time value of money on earnings and growth, following
the suppression of our operational activities as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic.

_Divisional Review_

UK Vehicle Remarketing

The division generated revenue of £1,377.1 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £116.3 million for the
unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 compared to £1,242.5 million and £109.4 million
for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. The division traded strongly during the fiscal year
2020 despite the impact of the temporary cessation of physical auctions in March 2020 as a result of
government restrictions in response to the COVID 19 pandemic. Revenue increased as a result of increased
volumes including an extended sales program during the Christmas period. Auction activity throughout the
fiscal year 2020 was driven by strong volumes from the Vehicle Buying division (WeBuyAnyCar) and
outsourced remarketing contracts. This was supported by BCA Partner Finance penetration, which continues
to increase. The BCA Partner Finance proposition, which includes branded auctions, part-exchange financing


-----

and funding 100% of the hammer price plus fees and transport of purchases, continues to support dealer
customers through the liquidity it provides.

International Vehicle Remarketing

The division generated revenue of £201.0 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £34.2 million for the
unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 compared to £184.3 million and £33.7 million
for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. The division performed strongly in the period with
continued growth in remarketing volumes. Revenue for the fiscal year 2020 was driven by increased fees and
including a higher proportion of cross border sales. Strong performance in Denmark and the Netherlands
along with volume growth in Germany and France, contributed to an increase in revenue, IAS 17 Adjusted
EBITDA and IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA. Our Danish auction successfully transitioned to a fully
online auction program in fiscal year 2020. BCA Norway, which commenced trading in April 2019, generated
good volumes focusing on remarketing of electric vehicles, due to the high penetration of electric vehicles in
this region. Demand for cross-border sourcing of vehicles in Europe continued to rise period-on-period and is
supported by our transport network of accredited partners. From the second week of March 2020, national
restrictions for COVID 19 were implemented across Europe, starting with Italy and France, which were
amongst the first to implement full lockdown. While all European countries were impacted, those with lighter
social distancing measures, for example Denmark, Sweden, Netherlands and Germany, allowed trading at
greater scale through March 2020.

Vehicle Buying

The division generated revenue of £1,529.8 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £27.7 million for the
unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 compared to £1,219.8 million and £24.1 million
for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. WeBuyAnyCar maintained double-digit volume
growth with an expanded network of 315 sites providing increased convenience for consumers. During the
fiscal year 2020, a record 10,200 vehicles were purchased in a single week by WeBuyAnyCar. The division
supplied a controlled and diverse range of vehicles across all makes and marques, to support the UK Vehicle
Remarketing division auction sales program. Inventory as of March 29, 2020 was £44.2 million (March 31,
2019: £29.3 million), reflecting the continued growth in the business, offset by the impact of COVID 19
restrictions. In line with government guidelines WeBuyAnyCar closed its retail estate from March 23, 2020,
preventing the purchase of vehicles from consumers. The online channels of the UK Vehicle Remarketing
division have continued to sell vehicles that were already held by WeBuyAnyCar. At the period end
management made additional provisions against inventory given the price uncertainty as a result of the
COVID 19 pandemic and associated restrictions. European car buying operations were paused as the impact
of COVID 19 became evident, resulting in an operating loss due to costs associated with holding vehicles, and
the impact of vehicles sold below purchase price due to temporarily reduced demand.

Automotive Services

The division generated revenue of £396.6 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £22.6 million for the
unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 compared to £381.4 million and £19.1 million
for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. The division continued to increase the penetration
of internal moves and refurbishment completed for UK Vehicle Remarketing and WeBuyAnyCar, driving
increased internal efficiency and reducing costs. In the period since the CA Acquisition, the services business
performed well with increased demand for manufacturer accredited refurbishment capability.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

**_Liquidity_**

Liquidity describes our ability to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of our business
operations, including funding working capital and capital expenditure needs, servicing our indebtedness,
paying taxes and funding operating activities. Our primary sources of liquidity consist of (i) cash flows from
operating activities, (ii) borrowings under loan facilities and finance arrangements that we may incur from
time to time, (iii) issuances of debt securities and (iv) borrowings under bank overdrafts borrowings. A variety
of factors influence our financial condition and liquidity, including:

- a reduction in cash flows from operating activities due to, for instance, volume fluctuations in our business
and pricing pressures we face from our competitors;

- adverse working capital developments, including increases in non-collectible receivables (to the extent we
do not receive recourse through a vehicle held a security) and changes in supplier payment terms;


-----

- our inability to continue to borrow funds from financial institutions; and

- higher capital expenditures and funding requirements.

If our future cash flows from operating activities and other capital resources (including borrowings under the
Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility) are insufficient to pay
our obligations as they mature or to fund liquidity needs, we may be forced to:

- reduce or delay business activities, fixed costs and capital expenditure;

- sell assets;

- obtain additional debt or equity capital; or

- restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity.

As of March 28, 2021, after giving effect to the Refinancing Transactions, our primary financing arrangements
will be the Notes, the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility,
and we would have had £113 million of Adjusted Cash. See “Capitalization.”

Although we expect to have sufficient liquidity to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service needs for the
foreseeable future, no assurance can be given that we will generate sufficient cash flows from operating
activities or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to
pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund other liquidity needs.

No assurance can be given that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or
on satisfactory terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of our current or future indebtedness, including the
Notes and the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility, may
limit our ability to pursue any of these alternatives. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Financial Profile,
_Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees—We are subject to restrictive debt covenants that may limit our_
_ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and to pursue business opportunities and activities.”_

**_Capital Resources_**

We have significant leverage and debt service obligations. As of March 28, 2021, after giving effect to the
Refinancing Transactions, we would have had £1,760 million of Adjusted Total Debt, comprising the Notes,
the Senior Term Loan Facility and the Second Lien Facility, excluding finance leases and borrowings under
the Receivables Facility. As of March 28, 2021, we also had £40 million drawn under the Existing Revolving
Credit Facility. We do not expect to borrow cash under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Issue Date but
expect to utilize ancillary facilities and letters of credit under the Revolving Credit Facility for ordinary course
operations. In addition, as of March 28, 2021, we had borrowings under the Receivables Facility of
£148.3 million.

The Indenture governing the Notes, the Senior Facilities Agreement governing the Senior Term Loan Facility
and the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility Agreement governing the Second Lien Facility
and will contain, covenants significantly restricting our ability to, among others:

- incur or guarantee additional indebtedness;

- pay dividends or make other distributions or purchase or redeem our stock;

- make investments or other restricted payments;

- enter into agreements that restrict our restricted subsidiaries’ ability to pay dividends;

- transfer or sell assets;

- engage in transactions with affiliates;

- create liens on assets to secure indebtedness;

- impair security interests; and

- merge or consolidate with or into another company.

Each of the covenants is subject to a number of important exceptions and qualifications. These covenants
could limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs. The Senior Facilities Agreement
also contains a financial covenant requiring us to comply with a senior secured leverage ratio on the last day

of each period ending on a quarter. See “Description of the Notes,” “Description of Other Financial
_Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement”and “Description of Other Financial Arrangements—Second Lien_
_Facility Agreement.”_

We anticipate that our significant leverage will continue for the foreseeable future. Our high level of debt may
have important negative consequences for you. For further information, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to

**Working Capital**

We experience some seasonality with respect to our working capital. In particular, used vehicle sales in the UK
tend to increase during vehicle registration plate change periods in March and September of each year. In


-----

March, in particular, new vehicle sales traditionally peak in the UK, and as a result, dealer vendors of the
Vehicle Remarketing division typically experience an increase in part-exchange volumes, which has a
subsequent effect of increasing sales through the Marketplace. Conversely, our revenue typically decreases
during the summer and in December, a seasonality pattern that is followed by sales in both the Vehicle Buying
division and the Automotive Services division. As a result of these fluctuations, we experience seasonal swings
in our negative working capital and our negative working capital tends to decline in the quarter ending in
December and to increase in the quarter ending March. See “— Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—
_Seasonality.”_

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk**

Our activities expose us to a variety of financial risks: market risk (including foreign exchange and interest
rate risk), credit risk and liquidity risk. The responsibility for monitoring the effectiveness of risk management
is carried out by the board of the Parent.

**_Market Risk_**

Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices (principally exchange rates and interest rates) will affect
our income or the value of our holdings of financial instruments.

**_Foreign Exchange Risk_**

We operate in the UK and continental Europe (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal,
Spain, Denmark, Norway, Poland, Sweden, and Switzerland) and are therefore exposed to foreign exchange
risk. Foreign exchange risk arises primarily on recognized assets and liabilities and net investments in foreign
operations. These overseas operations’ revenues and costs are mainly denominated in the currencies of the
countries in which our operations are located. The most significant of these is the euro.

We do not have significant transactional foreign currency cash flow exposures. We monitor our exposure to
currency fluctuations on an ongoing basis. We maintain part of our debt in euro to reflect the currency in
which our revenue is generated.

We have not hedged profit translation exposures. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, we did not
have any hedges in place.

In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, if pound sterling had strengthened by 10% on average against
the euro with all other variables held constant, Reported Adjusted EBITDA for the year would have been
£3.8 million lower (2020: £1.3 million lower) as a result of a reduction of the equivalent value in pound
sterling of profits denominated in euro.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Our interest rate risk arises from our borrowings. Interest rates have been historically low and stable in terms
of both LIBOR and EURIBOR rates and consequently no structured hedging has been implemented in the
current period. We will continue to monitor interest rates and assess the requirement for hedging in the future.
All of our finance leases are at fixed rates of interest.

In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, if the average rate on floating rate borrowings had been 50 basis
points higher with all other variables held constant, post-tax profit for the period would have been £5.7 million
lower (2020: £6.6 million lower).

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to meet its
contractual obligations and arises principally through trade receivables from customers and cash balances.


-----

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that we will not be able to meet our financial obligations as they fall due. We monitor
forecasts of our liquidity requirements to ensure we have sufficient cash to meet operational needs while
maintaining sufficient headroom on our undrawn committed borrowing facilities at all times so that we
minimize the risk of breaching borrowing limits or covenants on any of our borrowing facilities. Such
forecasting takes into consideration our debt financing plan and covenant compliance requirements on our
borrowings. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we meet all liabilities from intercompany loans.
Our liability for operating expenses is monitored on an ongoing basis to ensure cash resources are adequate to
meet liabilities as they fall due.

**Critical Accounting Estimates and Judgments**

The preparation of our consolidated financial statements under IFRS requires us to make estimates,
judgements and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of
contingent assets and liabilities. Estimates and judgements are evaluated continually and are based on
historical experience and other factors including expectations of future events that are believed to be
reasonable under the circumstances. Actual results may differ from these estimates, with any changes arising
being recognized in the period in which the change in estimate is made or the final result determined.

**_Income Tax_**

_Taxation_

Accruals for current tax and amounts payable under local indirect taxes such as sales taxes and VAT are based
on management’s interpretation of country specific tax law, and require judgements about the likelihood that
tax positions taken will be sustained. Management estimates the amount of taxes payable based upon their
analysis and determines whether provision should be made for potential settlement of disputed positions
which are under negotiation. Any estimated exposure to interest on tax liabilities is provided for in the related
tax amount.

_Deferred Tax_

Deferred tax assets and liabilities represent management’s best estimate in determining the amounts to be
recognized. When assessing the extent to which deferred tax assets should be recognized, consideration is
given to the timing and level of future taxable income.

**_Trade and Other Receivables_**

Loss allowances for trade receivables due from customers under BCA Partner Finance arrangements are
recognized under the expected credit loss model on initial recognition of the receivable. Management are
required to develop estimates of credit risk using the best available information about past events, current
conditions and forecasts of economic conditions. BCA Partner Finance receivables are asset backed, providing
a level of protection based on the value and recovery of the asset. Management apply judgement in assessing
whether there is a significant change in credit risk which would impact the expected credit loss allowance
recognized.

**_Lease Liabilities_**

Management use a lease specific incremental borrowing rate to discount the future lease liabilities, where the
interest rate implicit in the lease is not readily available. Using an incremental borrowing rate requires
management to estimate the rate of interest that would be paid to borrow over a similar term, and with similar
security, the funds necessary to obtain an asset of a similar value to the right of use asset in a similar economic
environment.

**_Acquisitions_**

For all acquisitions in the period, management are required to apply judgement to determine the business
combination accounting, and in relation to the identification of separable assets and liabilities arising on
acquisition.

Management make estimates of future cash flows to value the assets and make estimates in determining the
useful economic life of intangible assets.


-----

**_Intangible Assets_**

An impairment review has been conducted on all goodwill and intangible assets held by the CA Group. The
impairment review is performed on a value in use basis, which requires estimation of future net operating cash
flows, the time period over which they will occur, an appropriate discount rate and an appropriate growth
rate. Specifically, the future cash flows are sensitive to the assumptions made about the revenue growth,
profitability margin(s) and the long-term growth rate of the relevant market. Given the degree of subjectivity
involved, actual outcomes could vary significantly from these estimates.

**_Pension Obligations_**

The CA Group’s net retirement benefit obligation, which is reviewed by management using assessments from
independent actuaries each period, is based on key assumptions, including discount rates, inflation, future
salary increases and pension costs. These assumptions may be different to the actual outcome.
