**Overview**

**_UK and Continental European Vehicle Parc_**

We operate in the UK and continental Europe used vehicle market. The number of vehicles in operation (the
“vehicle parc”) across the UK and continental Europe has grown consistently since 2012, driven by a relatively
stable vehicle parc churn and growing vehicle penetration rates. Vehicle penetration rates, defined as number
of vehicles in circulation per capita in a country, are expected to continue to grow for most markets.

The European light vehicle parc grew at a CAGR of approximately 1.7% between 2012 and 2019, and currently
stands at approximately 320 million units (for the year 2020). According to IHS, the European light vehicle
parc is expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 0.8% between 2021 and 2026, driven by growth in the
penetration of vehicles per population, with new additions to the vehicle parc in particular of battery electric
vehicles and plug-in hybrid vehicles.

Since the onset of the COVID 19 pandemic, the importance of vehicle ownership for consumers has been
strengthened (see “—Key Trends”.) The below chart shows the evolution of the European light vehicle parc
between 2012 and 2020, and projections between 2021 and 2026:

_Source: IHS database[(1)]._

(1) “Other Europe” represents Sweden, Switzerland, Denmark, Austria, Belgium, Greece, Romania, Ireland, Bulgaria, Finland,
Hungary, Czech Republic, Portugal, Latvia, Lithuania, Croatia and Estonia.

Sales of new cars eventually translate into used car transactions through used car churn. Used car churn,
which is used as a measure of annual turnover in the ownership of cars in operation, varies by geography. In
the UK market, for the fiscal year 2019, used car churn stood at approximately 23%, compared to
approximately 13% in the continental European market, in line with customary trends. As a result, used car
transaction volumes as a proportion of the total vehicle parc are higher in the UK than in continental Europe.

We believe that the growing popularity of PCP (Personal Contract Purchase) plans among new car sales has
contributed to an increased visibility and rates of churn in the UK. An increasing amount of cars coming off
PCP plans offers a stream of supply for the used car market, many of which are transacted via exchanges such
as Constellation’s B2B Marketplace.

In addition, used car churn across the UK and continental Europe is impacted by a number of key factors.
These include:

- Maturing leases and other finance agreements;

- Changing consumer preferences;


-----

- Necessary cost of repairs as vehicles age, as well as warranty expirations;

- Tax and regulatory changes such as low emission restrictions and fees related thereto;

- Dealer and OEM finance offers and promotions;

- Rental and car sharing fleets, which typically churn vehicles at a faster rate than vehicles in private
ownership, according to IHS;

- Insurance cost, safety, recalls, reliability and technological improvements

Used vehicle churn is a key factor of our business model. Given the graduated auction fee structure is relatively
insensitive to vehicle price, the business model is more dependent on the volume of vehicles going through the
marketplace than the overall value of the vehicles.

**_UK and Continental European Used Car Market_**

The continental European used car market was estimated by Roland Berger to be valued at €410 billion for the
year 2020. The total volume of used car sales in Europe amounted to approximately 45 million cars during the
same period, of which approximately 84% were derived from continental Europe and the remainder from the
UK, according to IHS.

Moreover, annual sale volume movements in the used car market have been proportionally lower than in the
new car market, as the used car market is far less sensitive to economic downturns than the new car market,
due in part to the greater size of the used car market and the fact that certain periods of economic stress can
be a driver of used car transactions, such as de-fleeting of underutilized car rental fleets or consumers trading
down cars. For example, new car sales in the UK were more volatile between 2008 and 2020 than used car
sales, with a peak-to-trough maximum variance of approximately 39% compared to approximately 13% for
used car sales during the same period.

_Source: IHS._

**_Impact of the COVID 19 Pandemic on the Used Car Market_**

From the end of the first quarter of 2020, the UK and continental European used car markets were impacted
by the temporary closure of bricks and mortar dealerships as a result of lockdown measures and forced
temporary business closures resulting from the COVID 19 pandemic. Following the introduction of these
lockdown measures, the used car markets in the UK, France, Germany and Italy recorded a significant decline
through March and April 2020. However, volumes began to recover strongly from early June 2020, as
lockdown restrictions gradually started to ease in these regions. The German market suffered from another
sharp downturn as a result of the renewed lockdown imposed in December 2020, but the latest data from
Indicata indicates that volumes have recovered close to pre-COVID levels. In France, despite a recovery from
a trough in April 2020, French used car sale volumes have remained below pre-COVID 19 levels. The latest
trading data from Indicata indicates that used car volumes in Italy and the Netherlands have recovered to
pre-COVID levels.

In our largest market, the UK, used car sales suffered a year-on-year decline of approximately 11% in the
fiscal year 2020, to approximately 7.4 million in 2020 from approximately 8.3 million in 2019, according to
IHS, driven by mandatory retail closures during periods of lockdown. Despite the ongoing global pandemic,
the UK recorded periods of strong recovery when such restrictions were subsequently lifted and retailers


-----

reopened, driving monthly used car transaction volumes from July to October 2020 above those for the same
period in 2019 and demonstrating the continued strong demand for used cars by end consumers. The
continued strength of demand for used cars throughout this period is also evidenced by the fact that average
transaction prices remained above pre-pandemic levels from July to October 2020, during which retailers were
open. The impact on the used car market of the varying forms of lockdown from November 2020 to
April 2021 was less severe than the initial lockdown from March 2020 to June 2020, primarily due to the
increased use by dealers of click-and-collect channels, which they were able to develop and improve during the
periods of mandatory closures from March 2020. Following the easing of COVID 19-related restrictions and
the reopening of retailers on April 12, 2021 in the UK, used car transactions have bounced back strongly, as
evidenced by the chart below:

_Source: Indicata Market Watch (Edition 16, May 2021), SMMT._

The used car market, especially in the UK, is expected to remain strong in the near-term, supported by renewed
appetite for individual vehicle ownership (Source: Roland Berger). Moreover, an increased amount of
household savings accumulated through the COVID 19 pandemic bolsters the consumption outlook (Source:
_HSBC)._

Vehicle parc growth rates in key markets across Europe are expected to grow at CAGR ranging from 0.5% to
1.8% between 2021 and 2026 (Source: IHS).

**Used Vehicle Market Ecosystem**

Our UK Vehicle Remarketing and International Vehicle Remarketing divisions, which trade under the BCA
brand name, as well as WeBuyAnyCar, our C2B Marketplace business line which represents our Vehicle
Buying division’s operations in the UK, constitute significant parts of the value chain within which we are
active, as illustrated by the below chart:

_Source: Management Information._

Market participants include:

   - Vendors, who are looking to dispose of vehicles, and are divided into the below groups:

     - Corporate fleet, including finance and leasing companies (looking to dispose over-age or overmileage vehicles, repossessed vehicles, off-lease vehicles, including vehicles after PCP plans);


-----

     - Dealers and car supermarkets (looking to move unwanted part-exchange stock or liquidate aged
inventory);

     - OEMs (looking to dispose vehicles after corporate fleet or other ownership); and

     - C2B marketplaces or vehicle buying platforms (consumer-facing companies that seek to liquidate
stock purchased directly from consumers).

   - Marketplaces and exchanges, which comprise of firms looking to enable vendors to sell used vehicles to
a variety of buyers, as well as to provide a logistics solution from sellers to buyers;

   - Classifieds, which comprise of online automotive classified websites that generate leads for traditional
dealers, car supermarkets and consumers looking to dispose of used vehicles, and provide purely
advertising and lead-generation services without end-to-end transaction capabilities;

  - Trade Buyers, who comprise of mainly professional players, including traditional dealers, car
supermarkets and online B2C players; and

   - Consumers, who comprise of private individuals looking to buy or dispose of vehicles, and who may
also trade vehicles amongst themselves (C2C transactions), in addition to the other channels described
above.

Marketplaces and exchanges are at the center of the used car value chain, offering transparency, speed,
certainty and liquidity for both vendors and buyers. They form a key part of the fleet management
infrastructure for vendors by outsourcing non-core competencies and helping to extract maximum value
quickly, as well as representing a significant channel for buyers, driven by their ability to offer on-market
pricing and maximum choice of vehicles on used vehicle marketplaces. A significant fragmentation of buyers
and vendors across the UK and continental European markets enhances the prominence of used car
marketplaces as a critical channel for transactions. By way of illustration, the largest used car dealership in the
UK has a market share of approximately 3%, while the largest European used car dealership has a market
share inferior to 1%.

Leading marketplaces could be seen to benefit from self-reinforcing dynamics whereby as they grow in both
scale and geographic breadth, their attractiveness to both buyers and vendors increases, which in turn
reinforces their leadership position. By adding ancillary services such as logistics, vehicle refurbishment and
buyer financing, among others, an automotive marketplace can also strengthen the attractiveness of its
services to its customers and thereby increase customer stickiness, while also growing the level of profit
achieved per vehicle transacted through its platform. A key success factor for a leading automotive
marketplace is also having a reliable and diverse source of vehicles flowing through its platform.

Our Marketplace is a key participant in the used car market value chain throughout both the UK and
continental Europe. Notably, in the UK, we came into contact with approximately 13 million unique vehicles
in the fiscal year 2020, representing approximately one in three of all registered cars in the UK.

WeBuyAnyCar, our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in the UK, is a leading online C2B used vehicle
buying company, with more than 2.2 million cars bought since its inception and 461,000 vehicles purchased
and sold annually, on an annualized run-rated basis based on March, April and May 2021. WeBuyAnyCar
provides UK Vehicle Remarketing with used vehicles that would otherwise go to C2C markets or partexchanges. Once acquired on the WeBuyAnyCar platform, the purchased vehicles are sold through the
auctions conducted by UK Vehicle Remarketing, with an acquisition to sale cycle of approximately 10 days,
on average (fiscal year 2020, which is representative of our ordinary course business operations in a steady
state). WeBuyAnyCar provided approximately 35% of the UK Vehicle Remarketing sale volumes in the fiscal
year 2021.

Our integrated suite of services, both transactional (such as auctioning and vehicle buying) and transactionenabling (such as refurbishment, transport, valuation and other services) places us at the center of the
automotive value chain.

**Key Trends**

**_Increased consumer perception of the importance of car ownership_**

Partly as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic, consumers now place an increased emphasis on the importance
of car ownership. This has been driven by a variety of different reasons, including a demographic move away
from urban areas due to the ability to work from home and a decline in the use of public transport and shared


-----

mobility (Source: BCG report). According to the OC&C survey (2021), the number of non-drivers who
definitely expect to own a car in the future has risen by 21% in the UK since 2019, and 40% of drivers in the
UK and Italy also stated that the COVID 19 pandemic has increased the importance they place on car
ownership. This is also true of younger drivers, with the proportion of drivers aged 18 to 29 against car
ownership falling from 11% to 5% during the same period.

**_Digitalization of the used car value chain_**

The used car value chain has long been reliant on physical transactions via bricks and mortar institutions, and
has also had a very low digital penetration relative to other industries. However, the change towards an online
business model has been accelerated, in particular as a result of and in response to the COVID 19 pandemic,
which forced businesses and consumers to resort to online channels while traditional retailers were closed.
This trend towards an increased digitalization has impacted both the B2B and B2C channels:

_B2B Channels_

The changes in operating environment spurred by the COVID 19 pandemic have led us to accelerate our shift
towards a fully digital online business model with increased focus on the functionality and usability of our
digital platforms, with a 100% online penetration in UK Vehicle Remarketing and an online penetration in
excess of 90% in International Vehicle Remarketing, in each case in the fiscal year 2021. Increasing online
penetration of auctions presents a unique opportunity to increase the cost efficiency of used car marketplaces
and facilitates a more flexible utilization of real estate. In addition, digitalization also increases businesses’
resilience in the event of further lockdowns as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic or other adverse economic
conditions by continuing to trade largely online. Lastly, the digitalization of the used car value chain also
bolsters operators’ data collection and analytics capabilities thanks to the higher number of transactions
concluded online. This trend is likely to disproportionately benefit large players, such as ourselves, for two
reasons. Firstly, because of their broader geographical presence, as digital auctions increase the scope to pair
buyers and sellers that are located far away from one another, and such pairing requires significant logistical
capabilities. Secondly, because of their overall scale and data infrastructure, since small players are less likely
to have the digital expertise and scale to support the costs of digital investments.

_B2C Channels_

Trends resulting from the COVID 19 pandemic have also accelerated consumers’ willingness to accept digital
purchasing as a means to buy a car, which has historically been at very low levels according to Roland Berger.
This trend has facilitated the growth of online B2C retailers, such as cinch, with an increase in transparency
and convenience for consumers buying used cars, thereby potentially helping increase used car churn over
time, as well as an increase in the demand for the sourcing of high quality used cars from vehicle exchanges
such as ours, and in turn the demand for high quality used cars from vehicle buying platforms.

**_Continued structural growth opportunity for digital vehicle purchasing platforms_**

There is significant potential for vehicle buying platforms to continue to increase their penetration of the
large, fragmented and sometimes inefficient C2C and part-exchange segments of the used car market. As the
growth of platforms such as WeBuyAnyCar in the UK and other C2B sourcing businesses in parts of
continental Europe have shown, such vehicle buying platforms offer a convenient, transparent and efficient
way for consumers to sell their cars. With consumers becoming increasingly comfortable using online channels
for car transactions (Source: Roland Berger) and with such vehicle buying services still typically operating at
low levels of overall market penetration, we believe that leading vehicle buying platforms can continue to
exhibit structural growth.

**_Technological and regulatory changes driving faster vehicle churn_**

The pace of both technological and regulatory changes in the European automotive market has substantially
increased in recent years. A confluence of technological changes, such as more cost efficient batteries and
advancement of automotive sensors, and regulatory measures, such as EU-wide fleet emission legislation to
reduce light vehicle CO2 emissions has resulted in the rapid advancement of light vehicle technology on offer
to consumers. In addition, other car technologies, such as autonomous driving features and advanced car
connectivity, are rapidly evolving. To seek up-to-date technology and adapt to changing regulation, consumers
therefore have an increasing number of reasons to change their choice of vehicle on a more regular basis.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We operate leading digital used vehicle marketplaces (both business to business (“B2B”) and consumer to
business (“C2B”)) in the UK and B2B marketplaces in continental Europe and are a leading provider of
associated automotive services, including vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet
management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. We have physical presence in 10 countries
across the UK and continental Europe as well as unmatched sourcing, data, technology and logistics
capabilities. As of March 28, 2021, our business comprises:

- a leading B2B digital used vehicle marketplace across the UK and continental Europe, which facilitated the
sale of approximately 1.5 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 1.2 million vehicles in the fiscal year
2021;

- a leading C2B digital used vehicle marketplace in the UK, WeBuyAnyCar, with sold volumes of 321,000
vehicles and 300,000 vehicles in the fiscal years 2020 and 2021, respectively, reflecting the COVID 19
restrictions on the business that now has an annualized run rate of 461,000 vehicles (based on trading in
March, April and May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period); and

- a leading automotive logistics service business in the UK, which moved more than 2.8 million vehicles in
the UK in the fiscal year 2020 and 2.4 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2021, and stored, refurbished and
processed more than 950,000 vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 675,000 in the fiscal year 2021.

We estimate that for the fiscal year 2020 we came in contact with approximately one in every three vehicles in
the UK (approximately 29 million touch points, of which approximately 13 million were unique vehicles out
of a vehicle parc of approximately 41 million, and including approximately 24 million digital touch points).
Through our digital used vehicle marketplaces (the “Marketplace”), we are a critical liquidity provider to the
used vehicles market across the UK and continental Europe, matching the complex requirements of both
vendors and buyers and also facilitating the purchase of individual vehicles from consumers. The Marketplace
facilitates speedy disposal of high volumes of vehicles and offers a broad range of consistently graded vehicle
stock, thereby providing efficiency, liquidity (i.e., fast disposal of vehicle stock) and choice. Moreover, we are
the UK’s leading provider of automotive services solutions.

By providing a full suite of auction and automotive services, we offer our customers solutions for almost all
stages of the vehicle life-cycle, beginning as soon as the new car arrives at the port. Our scope of services
provides synergistic benefits across our divisions, as our vehicle sales platforms, together with our automotive
services solutions, generate vehicle and pricing data used in both our vehicle remarketing and vehicle buying
operations.

Throughout the COVID 19 pandemic, we have accelerated our digital transition and now transact digitally
almost 100% of our volumes through online channels. We integrate our digital and physical assets to provide
innovative multi-service solutions, maximizing speed, intelligence and performance across our comprehensive
offerings. In the fiscal year 2021, 100% (2020: 37%) of our auction volumes in the UK Vehicle Remarketing
division and 96% (2020: 84%) of our auction volumes in the International Vehicle Remarketing division were
transacted online, which is a testament to our successful shift towards a predominantly digital online business
model moving forward.

In the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021, we generated £253.1 million of IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA,
as compared to £232.8 million, £204.1 million and £174.4 million in the 52-week period ended March 28,
2021, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019,
respectively.

We operate through three main business lines: (i) the B2B Marketplace business line, which is comprised of
our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, our International Vehicle Remarketing division and our Vehicle Buying
division’s operations in continental Europe, (ii) the C2B Marketplace business line, which is WeBuyAnyCar,
our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in the UK, and (iii) the Automotive Services business line, which is
accounted for in our Automotive Services division.

- B2B Marketplace: B2B Marketplace is our core business that facilitates the exchange of used vehicles
between vendors and buyers through primarily digital auctions. As of March 28, 2021, our digital auctions
are supported by 21 physical sites in the UK (23 as of June 1, 2021) and 30 physical sites in continental
Europe at which vehicles are stored, inspected, repaired and refurbished.


-----

B2B Marketplace (which excludes WeBuyAnyCar) does not take title to the majority of vehicles that it sells,
but instead serves as an agent between vendor and buyer and recognizes revenues through auction transaction
fees as well as fees for a suite of value-added digital and physical pre- and post- auction services such as
inspections, appraisals, repairs, refurbishment, imaging, storage and handling. We also purchase vehicles
directly from certain corporate vendors under outsourced remarketing contracts, whereby we directly buy our
vendors’ inventory and have discretion over the remarketing channel through which we sell the vehicle. B2B
Marketplace takes title to such vehicles until the time of resale and recognizes revenues for the full sale value
of the vehicle less the cost of acquisition. Vehicles acquired pursuant to outsourced remarketing contracts are
typically resold within 15 to 30 days of acquisition and in turn generate additional revenue above the auction
fees.

B2B Marketplace also includes our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in continental Europe, which is
focused on purchasing batches of vehicles primarily from corporates in continental Europe.

In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division generated £90.5 million
of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £116.3 million; 52-week
period ended March 31, 2019: £109.4 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division
sold approximately 867,000 vehicles (2020: 1,063,000 vehicles; 2019: 1,030,0000 vehicles). In the 52-week
period ended March 28, 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division generated £29.2 million of IAS
17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £34.2 million; 52-week period ended
March 31, 2019: £33.7 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division sold
approximately 334,000 vehicles (2020: 401,000 vehicles; 2019: 388,000 vehicles).

- C2B Marketplace: C2B Marketplace is our C2B vehicle buying business which operates in the UK through
WeBuyAnyCar. WeBuyAnyCar purchases used vehicles directly from consumers, leveraging its proprietary
online pricing quotation systems and efficient physical inspection processes to facilitate purchases from
such consumers. WeBuyAnyCar has carried out a total of 2.2 million vehicle purchases since its inception
in 2006, and in the fiscal year ended March 28, 2021, WeBuyAnyCar recorded more than 22 million unique
visitors to its website and performed approximately 15.6 million valuations online. As of March 28, 2021,
WeBuyAnyCar operates in 357 locations across the UK, which are located within an average drive time of
under 14 minutes to customers. In addition, WeBuyAnyCar offers swift services to its consumers, allowing
them to obtain a quote in under 60 seconds and to then subsequently receive monies for the purchase of
their vehicle within 30 minutes of the sale being concluded.

C2B Marketplace remarkets the vehicles it purchases exclusively through B2B Marketplace within
approximately 10 days and accounted for 35% of the vehicles sold in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division in
the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This allows us to actively manage the volumes and mix on the
Marketplace, while helping to de-risk the supply of vehicles to the auction.

C2B Marketplace’s consistent and growing profitability over the past years demonstrates our ability to
generate “metal margin” (accounted for in our Vehicle Buying division) on C2B vehicles in addition to core
auction buyer fees (accounted for in our UK Vehicle Remarketing division). Vehicles sourced via our C2B
Marketplace therefore result in higher profitability per vehicle for the CA Group. Our sophisticated and
proprietary pricing mechanism and real-time market data enable us to more accurately price the purchase of
vehicles to generate a profitable onward sale. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Vehicle Buying
division generated £44.0 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29,
2020: £27.7 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £24.1 million), which was predominantly generated
through C2B Marketplace (i.e., WeBuyAnyCar).

- Automotive Services: Automotive Services provides vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery
inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. With our refurbishment
offering (which has a 250,000 yearly vehicle refurbishment capacity), we are able to bring vehicles to either
wholesale standard or a “Retail Ready” standard (which refers to vehicles that are cosmetically and
mechanically prepared to be immediately placed for sale to end consumers and are therefore particularly
attractive to online car dealers). These standards increase prices achieved at auction and render it simpler
for dealers to on-sell the vehicle to consumers. We seek to develop a relationship with vendors and endeavor
to act as a one-stop shop for vehicles throughout the majority of their lifecycle, expanding our revenue
streams along the value chain and also positioning ourselves to be the preferred provider of remarketing
services when the vehicles come off lease or roll out of the fleet. Our overall infrastructure and logistics
network allow us to efficiently cover all key locations and major transport hubs in the UK. Automotive
Services helps maximize the benefit of operational leverage and intragroup efficiencies derived from the
wide-ranging scope of services offered, benefitting both our customers as well as our own operations.


-----

Automotive Services generates revenue in the form of service fees. In the 52-week period ended March 28,
2021, Automotive Services generated £12.5 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period
ended March 29, 2020: £22.6 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £19.1 million).

**History**

We have a history dating back to our first auction in 1946. Since then, we have undergone a number of
changes in ownership and also shifted our strategic focus in an effort to adapt to changes in the post-factory
automotive market. We have gradually expanded our operations through a mix of organic developments and
selective, value-enhancing strategic acquisitions, including WeBuyAnyCar (2013), Ambrosetti (2016) and
Supreme Wheels (2017). In 2019, we were acquired by TDR Capital, who believed in our potential to become
a truly pan-European leader in the used vehicle auction market and saw an opportunity to drive efficiencies
by digitalization of the used vehicle market, thereby strengthening the cash generative nature of our business
and building a platform for growth across our marketplaces. Under TDR Capital’s ownership, we continue to
focus on growing the breadth and scale of our services offering to build a more complete and integrated
automotive services solution across the life-cycle of the vehicle.

**_Superior Business Model Addressing the Full Value Chain and Difficult to Replicate_**

We operate under a marketplace model and benefit from self-reinforcing dynamics where each of our business
lines feeds into and reinforces the others. Our business model enables us to extract intragroup efficiencies and
synergies derived from operating across almost all stages of the vehicle life-cycle, at high volumes sufficient to
provide a level of information, liquidity and market recognition that drives further volume growth.

Our B2B Marketplace operates vehicle auctions that bring together vendors with a highly fragmented and
diverse buyer base. Our large, robust and transparent digital platforms combined with our full suite of preand post-auction digital and physical value-added services provide an efficient marketplace to facilitate the
exchange of used vehicles. B2B Marketplace sold approximately 1.5 million vehicles across the UK and
continental Europe in the fiscal year 2020. This significant scale creates a virtuous business cycle by providing
access to a wide variety and large volume of vehicles through our auctions, thereby attracting more buyers to
our platform and enabling optimum pricing and quick throughput, which in turn attracts more sellers and

The C2B Marketplace creates a highly complementary and enhancing growth engine to that of the B2B
Marketplace. The B2B Marketplace provides WeBuyAnyCar with a highly efficient route to dispose of the
vehicles it purchases from consumers (typically within 10 days) and, through WeBuyAnyCar, we have the
ability to purchase a greater volume and variety of vehicles, which directly helps supply the B2B Marketplace.
The Vehicle Buying division provides significant volumes to the UK Vehicle Remarketing division, having
accounted for 35% of the vehicles sold through the Marketplace in the UK in the fiscal year 2021. This
synergistic model, which leverages WeBuyAnyCar’s market share within the framework of our wider
marketplace, creates a platform which we believe would be difficult to replicate.

Our ability to dynamically source used vehicles combined with our knowledge and insights on pricing and
other demand side dynamics enable us to find an optimum and tailored match for buyers and sellers swiftly,
which is key in driving profitability per vehicle. This is further strengthened by the additional services we offer,
which increase consumer and vendor experience as well as help us generate greater profitability per vehicle.

Our scaled B2B Marketplace and C2B Marketplace provides our pricing model with over six million relevant
historic used vehicle transactions. This data enables us to accurately and efficiently price vehicles both upon
sourcing and sale. This scale is further supported by our Automotive Services business line and our full suite
of pre- and post-auction digital and physical value-added services. This completes the value chain allowing us
to cover the full life-cycle, deepen relationships with vendors and customers and maximize profitability per
vehicle. Moreover, our Automotive Services business line and our value-added services enable us to record

information relating to vehicle condition, maintenance and upkeep, further contributing to the pricing model

We believe that our scale, unique business model, reputation and robust financial policies have contributed
significantly to our long-term financial resilience, attractive growth and cash flow generation profile. Despite
turbulent times such as the global financial crisis of 2008, we were able to consistently maintain and grow
volumes and our EBITDA metric (as defined and prepared on the basis of the accounting policies of the
relevant parent entity at the time), with such metric having grown at a CAGR of 14.3% from the fiscal year
ended December 2004 to fiscal year ended March 2020 and such metric divided by vehicle volumes sold in the
respective trading year having grown from £37 per vehicle sold to £137 per vehicle sold over the same period,
as shown in the following chart.

Our business model’s resilience to market shocks can be further evidenced by our strong organic performance.
For example, during the period between 2008 and 2010, we were able to grow volumes by 66,000 vehicles and
the applicable EBITDA metric by £24 million in a market backdrop of reduced used car transactions in the
UK, which fell from 8.3 million in 2008 to 8.0 million in 2009 before recovering to 8.1 million in 2010. Despite
a market backdrop of reduced used vehicle transactions during the fiscal year 2021, our volumes between
July 2020 and December 2020 were higher compared to the period between July 2019 and December 2019. In
times of a consumer downturn and due to rate of loss in value generally associated with used vehicles, liquidity
is of paramount importance to businesses as well as consumers.

Our business is also highly cash generative, having generated £145.9 million, £175.1 million and £202.7 million
of COVID Adjusted Operating Cash Flow in the 52-week period March 31, 2019, the aggregated 52-week
period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, respectively. This strong cash


-----

generation is the result of our ability to grow our IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA while following a
disciplined approach to capital expenditure with the majority of sites being held on long term leases (excluding
WeBuyAnyCar retail locations) and most of our transporters and properties being refinanced through sale
and leaseback. Adjusted cash conversion (measured by subtracting Underlying Cash CAPEX from IAS 17
COVID Adjusted EBITDA and comparing the result to IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA) was 84%, 86%
and 87% in the 52-week period March 31, 2019, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the
52-week period ended March 28, 2021, respectively.

**_Attractive, Resilient and Underpenetrated Market_**

We operate in the used vehicle market across the UK and continental Europe which has grown consistently
since 2012, driven by a relatively stable vehicle parc churn and growing vehicle penetration rates. Vehicle
penetration rates are expected to continue to grow for most markets. In addition, the used car market is larger
and more stable than the new car market. The chart below sets out the volumes of used car sales and new car
sales in the UK between 2008 and 2020 as an example of the development of these market.

The European vehicle parc has exhibited a CAGR of approximately 1.7% over 2012 to 2019, currently
standing at approximately 320 million units as of 2020. As per projections from IHS, the European vehicle
parc is expected to exhibit approximately 0.8% CAGR over 2021 to 2026, driven by growth in the penetration
of vehicles per population. Assuming churn rates remain the same, this should support growth in the used car
market. See “Industry—Overview—UK and Continental European Vehicle Parc.”

In 2020, the European used car market was estimated to be worth €410 billion (Source: Roland Berger report
_(Apr-21)). Significant fragmentation of buyers and vendors across the UK and continental Europe helps to_
make exchanges a critical channel for both vendors and buyers. For example, the largest used car dealership in
the UK is limited to approximately 3% market share, while the largest continental European used car
dealership has a market share of less than 1% (Source: IHS and ICDP). In addition, online vehicle buying
services are still operating typically at low levels of overall market penetration (e.g., WeBuyAnyCar has ~4%
share of total UK used vehicle sales volumes, as of 2020).

The COVID 19 pandemic has also accelerated favorable structural trends affecting the markets in which we
operate. In particular, consumers have recently begun placing increased emphasis on the importance of
owning a car. This has been driven by a variety of different reasons, including people moving away from
urban areas due to the ability to work from home and a reluctance to rely entirely on public transport. In
addition, the lockdown measures imposed by governments and related closure of car dealerships has made
digital channels a principal means of conducting used car auctions. In particular, by the start of 2021 almost
all of our auctions were digital as the COVID 19 pandemic and related social distancing regulations accelerated
our digitalization plans and encouraged the adoption of digital auctions by our customers. This digital shift
allows us to reach a wider range of potential customers and has increased the amount of auctions being held,
reducing our daily sales’ costs and allowing us and our customers to receive more vehicle data. Finally, we also
benefit from increasing sales of used vehicles as government support and a push towards new technology,
including tighter emission controls, encourages vehicle owners to renew their vehicles, driving more exchanges.

The track record of our senior management in delivering cost-effective organic scale growth and successfully

We have also created a strong culture of innovation and transparency, winning a number of industry awards

**_Platform Ideally Positioned for Growth_**

We believe our business platform is strategically positioned for growth in our markets through market share
gain from the consumer to consumer (“C2C”) and part-exchange markets (whereby consumers “trade-in”
their used vehicle directly to a dealer). The growth of C2B Marketplace supports the growth of our B2B
channel as WeBuyAnyCar provides us with used vehicles that would otherwise go to C2C markets or partexchanges and allows us to supply a greater volume and variety of vehicles to our B2B Marketplace.

We believe we can drive higher volumes through our auctions through continued market share gain and
higher auction penetration in the UK and continental Europe. Our relationships with businesses such as
LeasePlan or CarNext, including entering into exclusive service agreements that provide support for our
multi-channel strategy, further enhance our sourcing capabilities and drive growth in the vehicle remarketing
segment. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Relationship with LeasePlan.”Moreover,
by leveraging our “One Europe” strategy via more seamless cross-border transactions, we believe we can
create a truly pan-European B2B marketplace for future growth.

In addition, COVID 19 restrictions have accelerated consumers’ willingness to adopt digital purchasing as a
means to buy a car from current low levels, favoring the growth of online B2C retailers, such as cinch. Our
relationship with cinch has increased supply for the B2B Marketplace via part-exchange vehicles that are
remarketed by us and allow us to generate additional auction fees. See “Certain Relationships and Related
_Party Transactions—Agreements with cinch.” Through cinch, we are also able to develop a B2C channel,_
which enhances our position as an end-to-end service provider. In particular, sales volumes for the B2C
channel increased from approximately 4,000 in October 2020 (based on a 7-day rolling annual run-rate) to
approximately 38,000 in May 2021.

**Our Strategies**

We seek to create value for stakeholders through organic growth, acquisitions and partnerships in the
automotive sector in the UK and continental Europe. We continue to work with major market participants to


-----

develop and adapt integrated solutions to solve and meet the needs of the participants across the automotive
sector, maximizing value for all stakeholders. To achieve this goal, we are focused on enhancing our competitive
advantage as an integrated end-to-end service provider, further expanding internationally, strengthening our
infrastructure and logistics network, capitalizing on favorable industry trends, continuing to enhance our data
capabilities and improving our operational efficiencies, cash flow and leverage.

**_Enhance our competitive advantage across the value chain as an integrated end-to-end service provider_**

We plan to drive growth by increasing our B2B Marketplace and C2B Marketplace penetration to increase
transaction volumes and scale across our geographies. The increase in scale will serve to provide even deeper
access to vehicles, as well as more pricing and vehicle information, and is expected to continue to solidify our
position as a leading operator of digital used vehicle auctions across the UK and the continental European
countries in which we operate. We also expect to continue leveraging upon and investing in our UK and
continental European network and infrastructure.

To further increase our scale, we intend to deepen our relationships with other participants in the used vehicle
ecosystem, including OEMs, leasing companies, finance companies and dealers, to improve access to used
vehicle supply and generate volumes. We plan to provide dealers with additional offerings that suit their
business models, to leverage the strength of WeBuyAnyCar’s brand to capture additional supply volumes as
consumers become increasingly willing to sell their vehicles through digital channels, and expand our reach to
serve customers through partnerships with other B2C platforms.

In order to maintain our competitive advantage across the value chain, we will leverage the close relationship
between our C2B Marketplace and B2B Marketplace and work on integrating further the insights and data
points we are able to collect at different stages, further supplemented by our data sharing agreement with
cinch. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Agreements with cinch.” Multiplying our
data touchpoints for vehicles entering our ecosystem will enable us to base our decisions on more precise and
efficient processes and pricing input.

We intend to continue to develop both our digital and physical service offerings to retain and grow the
customer base and deliver enhanced profitability. By increasing the penetration of value-added services over
time, we expect a compounding effect of fueling Marketplace growth by driving supply and buyer demand, as
the comprehensive end-to-end solutions significantly enhance user loyalty.

We also intend to further deepen the penetration of services provided by Automotive Services to continue to
improve relationships with vendors, both to provide additional vehicle information to benefit our other
divisions and to become the preferred choice for vehicle remarketing.

**_Further deliver on our international expansion strategy_**

We believe we are well positioned in Europe to become a truly pan-European leader in the used vehicle auction
market. Our “One Europe” strategy is focused on leveraging and optimizing our already existing capabilities
to provide more seamless cross-border transactions not only in countries where we have physical presence but
across the European continent. In continental Europe, which we believe is underpenetrated relative to more
developed markets such as the UK, we intend to grow our B2B Marketplace offering as well as our coordinated
logistics network and infrastructure to capture further market share and develop scale.

**_Strengthening our infrastructure and logistics network_**

As we look to increase our scale and continue to capture more volumes via our platforms, we will continue to
invest and strengthen our infrastructure and logistics capabilities in order to serve customers across the value
chain, while remaining asset light through the continued use of sale and leaseback transactions. We also
intend to develop and modernize our transport vehicles used for vehicle movement. Our aim is to remain a
major component of the UK used vehicle market backbone and extend this know-how to our other
geographies.

**_Capitalize on favorable structural industry trends to accelerate our growth_**

Online penetration for sales of used vehicles has grown significantly, particularly in the UK, in recent years
and the associated structural trends further accelerated during the COVID 19 pandemic. During the
COVID 19 pandemic, there has been a significant increase in online penetration for sales of used vehicles, as
physical venues were shut for lockdown periods and social distancing restrictions and health concerns
otherwise caused many consumers to avoid physical venues. Despite the recent acceleration in online


-----

penetration growth, we believe the online used car market remains underpenetrated relative to other mass
retail markets such as markets for toys and games, consumer electronics and apparel.

Further enhancing our digital presence will also allow us to capitalize on additional structural trends that
could drive more volumes through our Marketplace and strengthen our positioning and market share on
both the supply and demand sides of the ecosystem. In particular, we believe that on the demand side
consumers will continue to favor used vehicles for individual transportation to avoid public transportation
systems, and that more vehicles will be necessary as consumers move away from city centers to areas where
public transportation is inconvenient or unavailable. On the demand side, we look to attract wider audiences
via our digital auctions with no limitations linked to historical physical sites.

Finally, we will seek to benefit from increasing sales of used vehicles as government support and a push
towards new technology, including towards electric and other alternative fuel sources for vehicles, encourages
vehicle owners to review their vehicles, driving more exchanges.

**_Continue to enhance our data capabilities_**

Our business model is built on leveraging data and technology and we intend to continue to invest in our IT
infrastructure and data capabilities to scale up along with volume growth. We use data and technology
throughout our business, from providing instant price quotes and targeted marketing campaigns to valuation
tools, logistics and inventory management to optimization of refurbishment costs.

Through our end-to-end positioning we have access to one of the largest pools of real-time data.

As such, we are invested in ensuring that our IT infrastructure remains state-of-the-art to secure better
knowledge of our customers and their needs, which in turn is expected to enable us to develop better products
and more tailored service as well as more accurate pricing which is expected to help underpin our profitability.

**_Increase our operational efficiencies and drive strong cash flow and deleveraging_**

As we look to increase volumes flowing through our Marketplace, we believe we will have an opportunity to
improve our profitability per vehicle. Driving continued penetration of automotive services will help maximize
the benefit of operational leverage and intragroup efficiencies. Enhancing our data capabilities will allow us to
optimize pricing, leading to better unit economics, while we also look to ensure an optimal management of
our inventories to ensure a strong cash flow conversion at all times.

To support our strong cash generation, we will maintain our disciplined approach to cost management, which
proved to be effective in helping us navigate through the COVID 19 pandemic and its associated challenges,
maintaining an optimal capital structure and strong deleveraging profile while continuing in investing to grow
the business.
