**Operations**

We operate through three main business lines: (i) the B2B Marketplace business line, which is comprised of
our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, our International Vehicle Remarketing division and our Vehicle Buying
division’s operations in continental Europe, (ii) the C2B Marketplace business line, which is WeBuyAnyCar,
our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in the UK, and (iii) the Automotive Services business line. These
business lines are interlinked, with the Vehicle Remarketing divisions re-selling all of the vehicles acquired by
the Vehicle Buying division and the Automotive Services division providing vehicle movement, logistics,
storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment services. Our
divisions are also interlinked through end-to-end data flows, in order to optimize the platform. At each vehicle
touch point throughout the value chain, data on the vehicle is collected which informs decisions on value,
condition and refurbishment requirements. We have a dedicated team of data scientists and have been able to
utilize their data pool to develop highly accurate pricing capabilities based on multiple vehicle parameters,
including age, mileage, color and condition, which enables us to maximize margins in real time. Today, more
than 6 million historic used vehicle transactions feed our pricing model, which empowers the broader
platform.

We have physical sites spanning the UK and across nine continental European countries, including in
Germany, France, the Netherlands, Denmark, Spain, Sweden, Portugal, Italy and Norway, but serve
customers across an even wider region. In the fiscal year 2020, we exported more than 70,000 vehicles from
our International Vehicle Remarketing division, to over 40 different countries. The diagram below sets out the
geographic presence of our physical remarketing operations as of March 28, 2021:

Constellation Sites

**_Vehicle Remarketing_**

Vehicle Remarketing is comprised of the UK Vehicle Remarketing division and the International Vehicle
Remarketing division. Together, these divisions operate close to accessible transport routes and facilitate the
exchange of used vehicles, having sold 1.2 million, 1.5 million and 1.4 million vehicles in the fiscal years 2021,
2020 and 2019, respectively (with fiscal year 2021 being the period most adversely affected by the COVID 19
pandemic). In the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021, Vehicle Remarketing sold 1.4 million vehicles. Vehicle
Remarketing generated IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £119.7 million in the 52-week period ended March 28,
2021. Vehicle Remarketing operates primarily on an agency basis (in such role, taking no title or inventory
risk to the vehicles it transacts), except for our outsourced remarketing contracts which allow us to selectively
secure batches of supply. Vehicle Remarketing generates its revenue through a mix of vehicle transaction fees
and value-added service fees.

During the fiscal year 2020, approximately 37% of UK auctions were transacted online, however, by the start
of the fiscal year 2021 all our UK auctions were digital as the COVID 19 pandemic and related social
distancing regulations accelerated our digitalization plans and encouraged the acceptance of digital auctions
by our customers. While we retain the option to conduct one-off physical auctions for certain customers, we
will continue to focus on digital auctions. As a result, many of our physical sites are now being used for the
provision of storage and refurbishment services to our customers in support of our digital auctions. In
addition, the digital shift has increased auction capacity, reduced our daily sales’ costs and provides us with
more data.


-----

**_Auctions_**

Auctions are our core business activity. We auction vehicles of all ages and types, principally cars and light
commercial vehicles (“LCVs”), selling 1.4 million vehicles in the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021, a period
adversely impacted by the COVID 19 pandemic, compared to 1.5 million in the fiscal year 2020. As part of
our auctions, transaction fees are charged per vehicle sold through the Marketplace and are received from
both buyers and vendors, with the vast majority generated from buyers. Vehicle Remarketing does not take
title to the majority of vehicles (with title instead passing from the vendor directly to the buyer).

Online auctions are conducted as real time online auction sales with the auctioneer providing descriptions to
the buyers and coordinating the auction. We also offer “eBay-style” longer-term online auctions in which
users can either purchase vehicles from our online catalogue at a pre-determined asking price (a “Buy Now”
service) or bid on vehicles during auctions that run for pre-set periods of time (a “Bid Now”service). Auctions
are conducted daily and both vendors and buyers benefit from their 24/7 access to online bidding and the
ability to search and compare vehicles from multiple locations and in multiple languages.

Auctions can be accessed using BCA Live Online or the BCA Buyer mobile application.

_BCA Live Online_

BCA Live Online broadcasts live video and audio to remote bidders via the Internet using technology
developed in-house, allowing online bidders to compete in real time.

Buyers can pre-plan their auction activity using our catalogue previews and the vehicle tracking functionality
on our BCA Buyer mobile application, allowing buyers to track in real-time when a vehicle will be up for live
auction. During a sale, a live messaging service allows buyers to engage directly with the auctioneers and there
is capability to follow up to four auction sales simultaneously. If buyers are unable to attend a given auction,
they are also offered the option to place concealed proxy bids, allowing them to place a set bid for a particular
vehicle in advance, prior to the end of the relevant auction.

BCA Live Online also allows potential buyers to view, bid on and ultimately purchase vehicles at auctions
across Europe from one location, eliminating the need to travel to physical auction sites.

_BCA Buyer Mobile Application_

Our BCA Buyer mobile application integrates with BCA Live Online to allow industry buyers to manage
their selections and bidding across platforms. Simple vehicle tracking takes the guesswork out of auction
timings, with prompted notifications automatically sent to buyers whose targeted vehicle is ten lots away. The
use of our BCA Buyer mobile application has increased over the past two years and it now offers the same
functionalities as BCA Live Online, including full bidding, buying, delivery, collection and payment journeys.

**_Vendors_**

The UK Vehicle Remarketing division’s vendors are divided into five main groups: (i) dealers, comprising 23%
of our volume for the fiscal year 2021, (ii) vehicle buying, comprising 35% of our volume for the fiscal year
2021, (iii) OEMs, comprising 7% of our volume for the fiscal year 2021, (iv) corporates, which include leasing
companies and OEM finance companies, comprising 21% of our volume for the fiscal year 2021 and (v) trade
and others, comprising 15% of our volume for the fiscal year 2021.

The majority of used vehicles in the wholesale market in key European geographies is generated by OEMs
and corporates, although there are some country-specific differences.

The majority of our sales arrangements with our vendors are framework agreements, renewed annually and
provide only pricing and service levels. The framework agreements do not guarantee the provision of a
minimum number of vehicles to us and typically do not commit the vendor to exclusively supply vehicles to
us. Nevertheless, we have a track record of vendor retention. As of March 28, 2021, we held long-term client
relationships with an impressive track record of retention of our customers; by vehicles sold, 13 of our top 18
vendors (excluding WeBuyAnyCar) have each worked with us for five or more years and ten of them have
worked with us for over ten years. In particular, for the fiscal year 2021, of the top 18 vendor relationships
(excluding WeBuyAnyCar) 77% of volume was contributed by vendors with a relationship over ten years.

_Dealers_

Dealer vendors are comprised of a large number of franchised and non-franchised dealers. Dealers typically
sell vehicles obtained through part-exchanges from consumers, as well as over-age stock that is no longer
suitable for their retail showrooms. As a result, dealers sell vehicles through us that typically are more than
five years old.


-----

_WeBuyAnyCar_

WeBuyAnyCar sells all of its vehicles through the Marketplace. See “—Vehicle Buying.” The age of vehicles
we sell varies widely.

_OEMs_

OEMs typically use the Marketplace to dispose of demo fleets, buy-backs from rental companies and
management vehicles. As a result, the vehicles sold by OEMs through us tend to be among the youngest sold
through the Marketplace and usually are less than two years old.

_Corporates_

Corporate vendors, including contract hire, leasing and finance companies, typically dispose of end-of-lease
or repossessed vehicles through the Marketplace. Leasing company vendors in particular typically seek to
liquidate vehicles that they no longer seek to lease (and thus view as liabilities) as quickly as possible through
the Marketplace. The supply of vehicles from corporate vendors is affected by the number of vehicles that
have reached the end of the life of their relevant underlying contracts (which are typically three to five years in
duration), and reflects the number of vehicles taken onto contract by such corporate vendors’ customers in
preceding years.

_Trade and others_

Trade and others are comprised of other companies that do not fall into the other main categories, such as
public sector suppliers, owned fleet and various other independent sellers of vehicles.

**_Buyers_**

Our buyer base is highly fragmented, comprising more than 25,000 active trade buyers (i.e., buyers who use
remarketing channels to source used vehicle inventory and intend to resell the purchased vehicle) as of
March 28, 2021. Our trade buyers are divided into two main groups: (i) franchised dealers, who use the
Marketplace and vehicles obtained from part-exchanges as a source to supplement inventory, and
(ii) independent dealers and wholesale traders. Our independent dealer buyers will make use of remarketing
companies for a constant supply of vehicles. Wholesale traders are dispersed through a large number of
individual and small companies which source vehicles from auctions and act as middlemen on behalf of other
buyers.

**_Value-Added Services_**

In addition to our core auction business, Vehicle Remarketing provides a wide spectrum of supplemental,
value-added digital and physical pre- and post-auction services to both vendors and buyers, ranging from
upstream services to pre-auction preparation and marketing products to post-auction logistics services. These
services enable vendors to select from a range of services to enhance the marketability of vehicles, thereby
facilitating their disposal process, while also improving the information available to buyers. Value-added
services have the additional benefit of enhancing customer retention rates within Vehicle Remarketing, as our
customers are able to obtain the wide range of services from a single source, as opposed to having to turn to
different providers for each service which results in additional costs and lead times to disposal. Value-added
service fees are charged depending on the particular type of service sold by Vehicle Remarketing. Some of the
value-added services within Vehicle Remarketing are also offered on a standalone basis as part of our
Automotive Services division, thereby affording us flexibility as to whether these services should be offered as
part of our remarketing offering or separately and allowing us to offer more bespoke solutions to our
customers based on their specific needs.

The chart below shows our services across the post-factory automotive market value chain.


-----

_Upstream Services_

In order to help dealers manage their part-exchanges, we have developed BCA Dealer Pro, an online
application that organizes and improves various stages of the part-exchange process. BCA Dealer Pro also
assists dealers in disposing of their vehicles through the Marketplace quickly and seamlessly, as the data
captured by BCA Dealer Pro is easily integrated into our auction platforms. The key services addressed by
BCA Dealer Pro are:

- data capture facilitating valuation—identifying the vehicle, conducting an appraisal, capturing retail-quality
images and obtaining an accurate valuation;

- stock management—managing dealer stock and inter-dealer allocations, providing data analysis tools and
retail inventory data feeds and assisting in stock liquidation and stock replacement;

- remarketing services—managing logistics, sales preparation and demand data;

- buyer services—providing transparent pricing, logistics and vehicle preparation; and

- merchandising—offering digital content upload, key retailing data, imaging and video.

In continental Europe, we have developed MarketPrice, a service that provides dealers with a valuation for
their part-exchange vehicles. MarketPrice is available at no charge to dealers, in exchange for a commitment
to sell part-exchange vehicles through the Marketplace. While BCA Dealer Pro and MarketPrice generate
relatively low revenue and are offered prior to any decision to sell a vehicle through the Marketplace, we
believe these online tools help to develop our relationship with vendors and incentivize them to provide
vehicles to the Marketplace for sale. We believe that vendors using these online applications are more likely to
subsequently provide a greater proportion of their vehicles to the Marketplace for sale, thus increasing the
number of vehicles sold through the Marketplace.

_Pre-auction Services_

Once a vendor has decided to sell a vehicle through the Marketplace, we provide vendors with a fully integrated
vehicle pre-auction service.

We offer vehicle collection and transportation services, primarily in the UK, to move vendors’ vehicles to the
Marketplace (or, if requested, to third-party de-fleeting locations). We also provide vendors with storage
services prior to the auction. Moreover, we organize both single and multiple vehicle collections, varying
pricing depending on the distance and number of vehicles moved. We utilize a combination of our own fleet
of transporters and contracted plate drivers, as well as third-party companies (that provide their own
transporters and plate drivers).

When a vehicle arrives at our facilities, we undertake a standardized appraisal of the vehicle’s condition to
help the vendor set an appropriate reserve price and ensure an accurate and consistent vehicle description is
provided to auction participants. Depending on a vehicle’s condition, Vehicle Remarketing offers a range of
services to vendors designed to improve a vehicle’s condition and maximize its resale value, as many buyers
seek ready-to-retail vehicles. For more extensive repair needs, Vehicle Remarketing offers Smart Repair, our
repair service that includes cosmetic improvements, body work, dent repair, light mechanical repair, glass
repair and tire replacement.

Following any valet or repair services performed on a vehicle, we are able to capture high-quality photographs
and video for display on BCA Auction View, the online search tool used by buyers across the Marketplace.


-----

BCA Auction View provides our buyers with free access to the search capability, including all vehicles
scheduled for sale through the Marketplace. We have organized our search function to allow potential buyers
to search and view vehicles by make, age, grade, fuel, color, transmission and several other criteria. In addition,
BCA Auction View provides users with comprehensive vehicle data, including images, videos and appraisal
reports. Our video streaming and software development subsidiary, AutosOnShow, further enhances our
offering by providing imaging services to dealers following the sale of a vehicle, thereby allowing such dealers
to market the vehicle with their own branding prior to taking physical delivery of the vehicle.

Through BCA Assured, we provide buyers with additional comfort on the condition of vehicles that would
typically be sold “as seen” at our auctions. BCA Assured is a 40+point mechanical appraisal carried out by
certified technicians on all vehicles within certain mileage and ownership conditions. During the appraisal,
our technicians asses each vehicle in accordance with a comprehensive auction grid that takes into account a
number of cosmetic and technical requirements and produce an imaging suite, following which our dedicated
algorithm grades each vehicle for valuation purposes. The BCA Assured check is offered as an additional
service that accompanies a bid and is designed to give potential buyers confidence to buy despite an inability
to road test vehicles. The BCA Assured inspection covers a wide range of checks from condition of tires, to
engine performance and brake checks. Buyers of BCA Assured-covered vehicles have the earlier of 48 hours
or 500 miles to contact us if a vehicle’s condition has been misreported, with our dispute resolution team
working with buyers to resolve any claims.

_Post-auction Services_

Following a vehicle’s sale, we provide buyers with both storage and delivery services to the vehicle’s final
destination.

Through BCA Partner Finance, we offer stock funding (trade finance) to certain registered dealers in the UK,
which incrementally enhances the liquidity of the buyer base, thereby stimulating further demand within the
Marketplace. For eligible customers, our buyer finance services can be used to fully fund vehicle purchases of
all grades, including auction costs and ancillary fees. Typically, we provide finance support to established
buyers that are pre-approved and have a specified credit limit. As a result, and due to our close relationship
with these buyers and the use of our proprietary credit scoring process, we are well-positioned to assess the
credit risk of our borrowers and as such default rates and bad debt for BCA Partner Finance is low.

Financing is provided for an initial period of 60 days, with a possible 60-day extension, and is secured by the
financed vehicle (in the form of a security marker on such vehicle) as well as personal guarantees. If a dealer
defaults on its interest or principal payment, we have the right to recover the financed vehicle. However,
typically, we receive repayment once a vehicle is re-sold by the buyer.

Part-funding for BCA Partner Finance is provided by the Receivables Facility, as defined in and described
under “Description of Other Financial Arrangements—Receivables Facility Agreement.”

**_Vehicle Buying_**

Our Vehicle Buying division operates primarily in the UK as part of the C2B Marketplace, through
WeBuyAnyCar, but also operates in continental Europe, where it focuses on purchasing batches of vehicles
from corporates as part of the B2B Marketplace. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Vehicle
Buying division generated IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £44.0 million.

**_WeBuyAnyCar_**

In the UK, we conduct our Vehicle Buying operations through our trusted digital brand, WeBuyAnyCar. The
service has over 100,000 Trust Pilot reviews, and an overall “Excellent” rating, which is testament to the
strength and reputation of the WeBuyAnyCar brand. WeBuyAnyCar purchases and thereby provides us with
used vehicles owned by private consumers that would otherwise be destined for the consumer-to-consumer or
part-exchange markets. Through our online pricing quotation system and our 357 physical locations across
the UK as of March 28, 2021, we purchase any used vehicle owned by a private consumer, irrespective of
vehicle make, model, age or condition after having done our customary vehicle inspections. In the fiscal year
2021, a period adversely impacted by the COVID 19 pandemic, WeBuyAnyCar purchased and sold 300,000
vehicles from consumers in the UK. Run-rate total number of vehicles purchased and sold through
WeBuyAnyCar are estimated to be approximately 461,000 vehicles (based on trading in March, April and
May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period).


-----

Our Vehicle Buying division targets sellers who are seeking a fast, safe and convenient alternative to sell their
used vehicles at a competitive price. We also provide sellers with a quick source of liquidity.

_WeBuyAnyCar Sale Process_

WeBuyAnyCar’s website (www.webuyanycar.com) is the first point of interaction for most of the Vehicle
Buying division’s sellers. We have built and continue to maintain the WeBuyAnyCar brand through television,
radio and Internet advertising campaigns. WeBuyAnyCar’s website attracted approximately 22.7 million
unique visitors in the fiscal year 2021. The website’s key feature is its ability to use a proprietary pricing engine
that analyzes various vehicle parameters to provide an initial valuation of a vehicle virtually instantly. As a
result, we believe that WeBuyAnyCar is able to provide competitive valuations to its sellers.

In the fiscal year 2021, WeBuyAnyCar provided a total of 15.6 million valuations. Having obtained an initial
valuation of their vehicle online, potential sellers are invited to schedule an appointment at one of
WeBuyAnyCar’s 357 retail branches located across the UK, with appointments available as early as the same
day. Potential sellers may also bring their vehicles direct to a WeBuyAnyCar branch, without first accessing its
website, to obtain a quote on their vehicle.

WeBuyAnyCar’s branches are open for both online appointments and walk-in valuations up to seven days a
week, and on average a WeBuyAnyCar customer lives within a 14-minute drive of a WeBuyAnyCar branch.
At the in-branch appointment, a WeBuyAnyCar representative inspects the vehicle to confirm that the online
description and specifications provided by the potential seller (if applicable) were accurate and checks for
other mechanical and cosmetic damage to the vehicle. The WeBuyAnyCar representative then issues a final
offer price to the potential seller to buy the vehicle. The entire in-person sale process is typically completed
within 30 minutes. After a seller accepts WeBuyAnyCar’s offer price, WeBuyAnyCar cross-checks the vehicle
against vehicle databases and confirms the seller’s ownership. WeBuyAnyCar then arranges for the transfer of
ownership and payment of the agreed purchase price for the vehicle is made by bank transfer. For an
additional fee, WeBuyAnyCar will make an expedited payment transfer of the net purchase payment to the
seller. WeBuyAnyCar deducts a transaction fee from the final sale price paid to the sellers of the vehicles it
purchases.

All of the vehicles purchased by WeBuyAnyCar are sold through the UK Vehicle Remarketing division.
WeBuyAnyCar is the UK Vehicle Remarketing division’s largest vendor, providing 35% of the vehicles sold
through us in the fiscal year 2021. In the fiscal year 2020, which is representative of our ordinary course
business operations in a steady state, vehicles in the UK were onwards sold within approximately 10 days
through the UK Vehicle Remarketing division, while in the fiscal year 2021, as a result of the COVID 19
pandemic, onwards sales took place at an average of approximately 20 days.

**_Continental Europe_**

In continental Europe, our Vehicle Buying division focuses on purchasing batches of vehicles from corporates,
providing a controlled supply, adding mix and diversity to auction inventory in the International Vehicle
Remarketing division.

**Automotive Services**

In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Automotive Services division generated IAS 17 Adjusted
EBITDA of £12.5 million.

With a national network of sites, the Automotive Services division brings together our automotive vehicle
movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting and refurbishment
services, providing a comprehensive suite of services in an integrated manner. The division continues to
increase the penetration of internal moves and refurbishment completed for the UK Vehicle Remarketing
division and WeBuyAnyCar, driving increased internal efficiency and reducing costs. Under our Automotive
Services division, we aim to act as a one-stop shop for the passage of vehicles throughout their life and
capture auction volumes earlier in the life-cycle by working directly with specific vendors, such as fleet
providers and OEMs. By locking in a relationship with vendors at the start of the car’s life cycle, we not only
expand our opportunity for revenue streams along the value chain but also place ourselves to be a potential
route of remarketing when the vehicle comes off lease or rolls out of the fleet.

As part of the Automotive Services division, we handle bulk vehicle movements to and from ports,
manufacturing centers, pre-delivery inspection facilities, storage and refurbishment centers, auction sites and
dealerships, on behalf of our third party customers, the UK Vehicle Remarketing division, BCA Partner


-----

Finance customers and WeBuyAnyCar. Collected vehicles are driven on transport vehicles to secure central
hub locations and the movement between hubs is performed by the transporter fleet. This hub and spoke
network reduces driver hours, the risks to vehicles, general wear and tear and allows us to maximize the use of
capacity in under-utilized or empty return legs. In addition, movement between hubs can occur overnight
when the road network is less congested and external customers’ sites are not operational.

Continued investment has resulted in a modern and efficient fleet of transporters, improving operational
comfort for our employees and reliability for our customers. As of March 28, 2021, we operated a leading UK
transporter fleet, comprising 901 trucks capable of providing bulk vehicle movements, thereby connecting the
physical marketplace and increasing the integration between our divisions. In the fiscal year 2021, our in-house
transporter fleet and sub-contractors organized by us moved 1.8 million vehicles in bulk and accounted for
94% of transport arranged by the UK Vehicle Remarketing division. We also offer single vehicle movements,
customer handover specialists and vehicle inspection and collection services as well as trade plate movements
for LCVs. In the fiscal year 2021, our single vehicle movements amounted to a further 563,000 vehicles moved.

Furthermore, as part of our Automotive Services offering, we provide new vehicle support to customers from
factory gate or port of entry to fleet or retail availability. Such services include reception, customs management
and handling at port or factory gate, pre-delivery inspection and new vehicle preparation, accessory fitment
and customization, warranty and servicing as well as storage and compound management.

We also offer specialist services in fleet management, de-fleet and refurbishment. Our fleet management
expertise gives us the capabilities to offer customers full service fleet management solutions, providing
consistently high levels of customer service and peace of mind for fleet customers, including (i) booking,
management and administration, (ii) preparation, maintenance and storage, (iii) document management and
reporting and (iv) handover, inspection and collection services. Our de-fleet and refurbishment services include
(i) inspection and estimation services, (ii) refurbishment, (iii) service and warranty, (iv) studio quality imaging,
(v) valet and secure storage and (vi) wheel refurbishment. These services are delivered to consistent standards,
at scale, and cost-effectively. In the fiscal year 2021, we utilized the capability and expertise developed in
preparing and refurbishing fleet vehicles to establish and support the newly-developed “Retail Ready”industry
vehicle standard. “Retail Ready”vehicles are cosmetically and mechanically prepared to be immediately placed
for sale to consumers and are therefore particularly attractive to online car dealers.

Some of our services within the Automotive Services division are also cross-sold to our UK Vehicle
Remarketing division, thereby affording us flexibility as to whether these services should be directly offered to
the customer or cross-sold to another division and allowing us to offer more bespoke solutions to our
customers based on their specific needs.

**Information Technology**

We depend on our IT function to support our operating divisions and our back-office functions. We maintain
a large number of IT staff across the UK and continental Europe, which are organized into the following
areas: Technology Operations, Product, Information Security & Business Continuity, Enterprise Applications,
Transport & Logistics, Architecture, CTO and Portfolio Management. These teams cover all operating
divisions, both in the UK and continental Europe. We also rely on a small number of strategic partners to
supply, deliver and support some of our key technologies, supplementing our internal teams capabilities and
providing us with capacity and flexibility to adapt with business demand. Our technology is split between
hosted third-party data centers and public cloud infrastructure. Our systems and products consist of a mixture
of commercial off-the-shelf and bespoke developed platforms, and are categorized as follows:

- Digital auctions: our digital auctions are focused on the development of our end-to-end auction e-commerce
journey. Our core Auction Information System (the “AIS”) is used to manage vehicles through the physical
processes at our physical remarketing locations, manage physical stock, compound management, sale
channel allocation, bid management and, within the UK, for invoicing to customers. The AIS integrates
with our other information technology systems and products.

The main buyer interfaces are the BCA Auction View website and the BCA Buyer mobile application in the
UK and the pan-European e-commerce Platform (PEEP) in continental Europe. These allow buyers to
search our stock, manage their interest, purchases and payments online and link seamlessly with our online
auction system, BCA Live Online, which provides real-time online buying to all our auctions. These systems
support buyers in their local language, currency and delivery requirements and can be provided as White
Label, which are vendor-branded auction platforms.


-----

- Inspections, appraisal and valuations: we are focused on the development and maintenance of our range of
tools to capture vehicle condition for inspection, appraisal and valuation purposes at different parts of the
group such as WeBuyAnyCar, dealer and online part-exchanges, lease collections, fleet returns and
remarketing locations. We are working to bring these tools into a common system that can provide all the
data required for the entire vehicle journey at the first touch point.

- Vehicle lifecycle management: through BCA Dealer Pro, we provide a toolset that allows us and our large
corporate vendors to manage vehicles in the transition between the de-fleet and remarketing stages of their
lifecycle, streamlining processes and providing data-driven insights that enable better decision-making for
the customer and ensures easy integration into our suite of products and services.

- Transport and logistics: the specialist transport systems that underpin our cross-divisional logistics capability
are key to maximizing our efficiency in order to meet the needs of our customers and of our divisions. Our
transport and logistics products support the planning, optimization and orchestration of both singlevehicle and multi-vehicle movements, both intra-divisionally and to or from external customers.

- WeBuyAnyCar: we have developed a suite of bespoke products that allow for the smooth and efficient
operation of the WeBuyAnyCar business from the point at which a customer visits our website to the
moment the purchase is completed and monies are transferred. These products provide the website and
valuation and quoting system, as well as the various tools in use across the retail estate with which the
WeBuyAnyCar staff assesses, values and purchases vehicles from the general public.

- BCA Partner Finance: we use a commercial, off-the-shelf software that is integrated within our AIS and
allows us to provide finance for qualifying customers and the purchases they make.

**Marketing**

**_Vehicle Remarketing_**

The main purpose of the marketing team is to promote the Marketplace and its related services to both
vendors and buyers in collaboration with the sales and operational teams. Customer service is part of the
function. In addition, our sales teams seek to maintain and develop relationships with existing vendors.

Our Vehicle Remarketing divisions trade under the BCA brand name, which is well known in the UK, having
traded for more than 70 years. Our efforts at maintaining and promoting our brand are focused on growing
BCA brand awareness in continental Europe and raising awareness of the breadth of our products and services
portfolio.

Vehicle Remarketing targets buyers to purchase vehicles across its digital platforms and holds an extensive
database of historic customer-buying behavior and preferences. Buyers are targeted based on their existing
and potential purchasing opportunity across the facets of vehicle make, model, age, mileage, type, price,
location, sales and channel characteristics. Vehicle Remarketing’s marketing campaigns integrate print and
digital media, direct mail and e-mail marketing and telemarketing, as appropriate.

New developments across Vehicle Remarketing’s digital channels increase the opportunity to sell vehicles
online by providing greater confidence to potential online buyers. We continually develop new products and
services for use by both vendors and buyers. Digital initiatives include improved vehicle imagery and data for
search functions and improved user experience for online and mobile applications. Value-added services such
as BCA Dealer Pro and BCA Partner Finance have also expanded Vehicle Remarketing’s product marketing
capability.

Vehicle Remarketing has an extensive database of vendor, buyer and vehicle transactional data. This data
provides insight on auction pricing trends and assesses other trends within the Marketplace, providing greater
insight on product value-add and buyer behavior, thereby creating opportunities to attract new customers and
optimize the performance of the Marketplace.

**_Vehicle Buying_**

The Vehicle Buying division’s marketing strategy focuses on driving volume growth and strengthening brand
reputation through a variety of tools, such as search engine marketing (“SEM”), conversion rate optimization,
relationship marketing and commercial analytics. Maintaining and increasing WeBuyAnyCar’s brand strength
is a key marketing goal of the Vehicle Buying division.

The Vehicle Buying division conducts advertising campaigns on TV, radio and the internet to increase web
traffic by vehicle owners looking to dispose of their vehicles. It also has a strong relationship with Google and


-----

has benefited from priority access to performance enhancing SEM-beta programs. The Vehicle Buying
division regularly analyses its media spend across TV, radio and the Internet to increase the efficiency of these
marketing activities.

**Intellectual Property**

Our intellectual property rights include proprietary technology and software relating to digital auction systems
as well as trademarks, trade secrets, copyrights and other intellectual property. Our increased reliance in
recent years on proprietary Internet-based programs and technology have increased the relative importance
of intellectual property assets to our business. Our business and IT systems and other key proprietary
intellectual property generally are not protected by patents or registered design rights. As a result, we are
reliant on trademarks, copyright, database rights, registered domain names and the law protecting confidential
information to protect our brands, technologies and databases.

**Real Estate**

The majority of our operating properties in the UK (excluding WeBuyAnyCar retail locations) are subject to
long-term leases, which are recognized under IFRS 16 in our results of operations. The retail locations
operated by WeBuyAnyCar are small in size and are typically subject to a contractual term of less than
five years in duration. We also hold limited freehold properties in the UK. In continental Europe, our real
estate holdings comprise a mix of freehold and leasehold properties. In new markets, we tend to seek shorterterm leases to afford ourselves with greater operational flexibility.

**Health and Safety**

We are committed to providing a safe working environment wherever we operate, employing a proactive
network of health and safety professionals who deliver training and share knowledge and experience with the
aim of fostering best practice and ensuring consistently high standards of safety across our group. Health and
safety managers and committees are responsible for monitoring and reporting adherence to our health and
safety protocols to their divisional leaders.

The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant impact on our business with regards
to the health and safety of our employees, customers and suppliers. We are committed to ensuring that our
working environments are safe and the measures taken in response to the COVID 19 pandemic meet the
requirements in each of the jurisdictions in which we operate.

Our operations are subject to various health, safety and environmental laws and regulations in the jurisdictions
in which we operate, including those governing the emission and discharge of pollutants into the air or water,
the generation, treatment, storage and release of hazardous materials and wastes and the investigation and
remediation of contamination. Large numbers of vehicles are stored and prepared for sale at our facilities and
during that time releases of fuel, motor oil and other materials may occur. Furthermore, at our physical
locations, our employees come into close contact with moving vehicles.

**Environmental, Social and Governance**

With respect to environmental, social and governance matters, we have worked with Transport for London to
run ultra-low emission compliant auctions to highlight the launch of the low emission area in London. We
have seen an increase in the numbers of vehicles that are electric or hybrid coming into auctions, and in 2021
we switched the UK Vehicle Remarketing division to an electricity supplier which provides 100% renewable
electricity generated from wind, hydro and solar power (commencing October 1, 2021). Furthermore, our
transporter fleet includes trucks equipped with automatic gear changing systems that assist the driver by
selecting the most appropriate and efficient gear.

We have committed to charitable causes through fundraising activities and donations including a virtual oneday charity cycle and providing financial support to Ben, a non-profit organization supporting automotive
industry employees. We have significantly increased our number of mental health first aiders, partnering with
Mental Health England. We also have a strong focus on improving the capability of our people through
providing career development opportunities and ongoing training, offering our employees counselling and
well-being support through our new employee assistance programme and online well-being center.

We have in place a robust framework of governance and compliance underpinned by core values, abiding by
enhanced annual reporting disclosure obligations placed upon portfolio companies and private equity in
conformity with “The Walker Guidelines.” The six “Wates Principles” are key areas of focus for us, including:


-----

purpose and leadership, board composition, directors’ responsibilities, opportunity and risk, remuneration,
and stakeholder relationships and engagement. In addition, we encourage diversity and are committed to
providing equal opportunities within the workplace.

**Insurance**

The principal risks covered by our insurance policies relate to property damage, business interruption,
employers and public liability and certain other claims consistent with customary practice in the industry in
which we operate. We purchase our insurance through well-known providers. We have not had any material
insurance claims, nor have we suffered any material loss following any uninsured claim, in the fiscal years
2021, 2020 and 2019.

**Employees**

For the year ended March 28, 2021, we had an average of 7,365 employees, of which 6,440 were based in the
UK. We also use a number of self-employed drivers for the provision of transport services within our
Automotive Services division.

We are subject to various laws that regulate wages (including minimum wage laws), hours, benefits and other
terms and conditions relating to employment in the various countries in which we operate, and we provide
benefits to employees as required by applicable law.

We are committed to supporting our staff throughout their careers and provide training to a number of our
employees through our graduate development program and apprenticeship opportunities. We strive to make
working for our group rewarding in every sense. We always target competence and potential in our recruiting
process, and then support our employees with the training and development necessary to reach their full
potential. We also use bonus schemes as a part of employee compensation to incentivize efficiency, with
performance-based bonuses representing significant components of the compensation for many managementlevel employees.

We participate in several defined contribution pension schemes in the UK and in certain continental European
countries as well as two defined benefit pension plans in the UK. The two defined benefit pension plans in the
UK provide benefits based on final pensionable salary, are registered with HMRC and comply with the
regulatory framework published by the UK pensions regulator. Benefits are paid to the members from a
separate fund administered by independent trustees.

Our total contribution to these defined contribution schemes in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021
was £6.4 million. As of March 28, 2021, the two defined benefit pension plans in the UK had a deficit of
£12.4 million (2020: £15.1 million). See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business—We have several
_defined contribution pension schemes in certain continental European countries as well as two defined benefit_
_pension plans in the UK, some of which are in deficit.”_

**Litigation**

We have been and, from time to time, may continue to become party to claims, proceedings and lawsuits
incidental to the ordinary course of our business.

We are not currently involved in any other legal or arbitration proceedings that are expected to have a material
adverse effect on our financial position and, to our knowledge, no such legal or arbitration proceedings are
currently threatened.

**CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS**

We enter into transactions with our shareholders and other entities owned by, or affiliated with, our direct
and indirect shareholders in the ordinary course of business on fair terms and at arm’s length. These
transactions include, among others, professional advisory, consulting and other corporate services. The
following discussion is a brief summary of certain material arrangements, agreements and transactions we
have with related parties, including our ultimate shareholders, management personnel and cinch.

**Key Management Personnel**

**_Management Compensation_**

We provide our key management personnel with short-term employee benefits and post-employment benefits.
See “Management—Compensation.”

**_Management Incentive Program_**

Selected key employees of our management, including the members of the Executive Board, have been
provided an opportunity to make an indirect investment alongside TDR under the existing management
equity program (the “Management Incentive Program”). As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the
managers participating in the Management Incentive Plan held less than 2% of the capital stock in the Parent.
This investment is held indirectly via a management holding company. See “Principal Shareholders.”

**Agreements with cinch**

During the fiscal years 2019 and 2020, we developed cinch in-house as an online classifieds business. During
the fiscal year 2020, cinch was sold to an affiliate of a parent company of the Parent in September 2020.
Subsequently, the cinch entities received further investment from our common parent company to transform
them from a classifieds business to a fully transactional online B2C marketplace for used vehicles.

On October 23, 2020, we entered into various operational agreements with cinch on arm’s length terms. Under
such agreements, we have agreed to grant cinch priority access to purchase our “Retail Ready” vehicles at a
fixed price. Such “Retail Ready”vehicles refers to cosmetically and mechanically prepared vehicles that can be
immediately sold by cinch through their consumer car-buying platform. Any “Retail Ready” vehicle passed
over by cinch is then made available to cinch partner dealers and then sold through our Bid Now platform or
in an open auction.

In addition, we have entered into an agreement to purchase part-exchange vehicles from cinch at a predetermined price. Under this arrangement cinch is required to purchase the vehicle from its customers at the
valuation price specified by our proprietary BCA DealerPro software. We purchase vehicles from cinch for a
price equal to 97.5% of the part-exchange valuation offered to cinch’s customers, provided that the BCA
DealerPro software was used to calculate the value of the customer’s vehicle at the time of first valuation.

We also benefit from a synergetic data-sharing agreement with cinch, which takes the form of a reciprocal
license.

Furthermore, we have entered into service agreements and vehicle sales agreements pursuant to which we
provide certain automotive services (such as vehicle storage, vehicle delivery and vehicle handover to cinch
customers) as well as professional services (such as financial and tax services, payroll and HR support, data
protection and IT services), and pursuant to which we act as exclusive remarketing agent for vehicles cinch
wants to dispose of, as applicable.

**Agreements with LeasePlan**

In December 2020, British Car Auctions Limited (“BCA”) entered into a services agreement with
LeasePlan UK Limited, a subsidiary of LeasePlan Corporation N.V., the largest indirect shareholder of which
is an affiliate of investment funds managed by TDR.

Under the terms of the agreement, BCA provides fully outsourced and managed services in relation to all
de-fleeting vehicles of LeasePlan UK Limited on arm’s length terms. The services are fulfilled through BCA
sub-contracting to BCA Outsource Solutions Limited (“BCAOS”) in respect of the acquisition of the bulk of
the de-fleeting vehicles. BCAOS then sells the vehicles on through a multi-channel remarketing program.


-----

Exceptions to this acquisition arrangement are (i) the driver sales program, which is fulfilled by BCA
Remarketing Solutions Limited (“BCARS”) under a separate agreement completed in May 2021 (at which
time the existing driver sales agreement between BCARS and LeasePlan UK Limited was terminated) and
(ii) vehicles which do not meet the purchasing criteria of BCAOS and so are not eligible for acquisition by
BCAOS. Under the terms of the agreement, BCA remarkets those ineligible vehicles via auction and takes
flash title at the point of sale at auction. In addition, to support BCA and BCAOS, BCA Logistics Limited
provides logistics services on an exclusive basis in respect of LeasePlan’s de-fleeting vehicles. The agreement
includes certain mutual indemnity provisions, including indemnities for any damage or loss resulting from a
breach of any obligations relating to intellectual property rights, data protection and confidentiality clauses
contained in the agreement.

**DESCRIPTION OF OTHER FINANCIAL ARRANGEMENTS**

**Senior Facilities Agreement**

The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for credit facilities in the amount of a £785,000,000 (equivalent)
senior term loan facility (the “Senior Term Facilities”), which will be drawn in full by way of pound sterling
and/or euro denominated cash advances in connection with the Transaction and a £250,000,000 senior
multicurrency revolving credit facility (the “Revolving Credit Facility”). The Senior Term Facilities are to be
used for the refinancing and discharge of existing indebtedness of the Parent and its restricted subsidiaries, to
make a distribution to the direct parent company of the Parent and to fund transaction costs. The Revolving
Credit Facility may be drawn by way of cash advances or the issue of letters of credit or ancillary facilities.
The Revolving Credit Facility is to be used for the refinancing an discharge of existing indebtedness of the
Parent and its restricted subsidiaries, to fund transaction costs and the general corporate purposes and
working capital purposes of the Parent and its restricted subsidiaries.

In addition, the Parent may elect to request additional facilities either as a new facility or as additional
tranches of the Senior Facilities (the “Senior Incremental Facilities”). The Parent and the lenders in respect of
the Senior Incremental Facilities may agree to certain terms in relation to the Senior Incremental Facilities,
including the margin and the termination date (subject to parameters as set out in the Senior Facilities
Agreement). The indebtedness incurred under the Senior Incremental Facilities must be otherwise permitted
under the Senior Facilities Agreement.

**_Maturity and Availability_**

The Senior Term Facilities mature on the date falling 84 months after Issue Date. The Revolving Credit
Facility matures on the date falling 66 months after Issue Date. The Revolving Credit Facility is available to be
drawn from and including closing date to and including one (1) month prior to its maturity date.

**_Interest and Fees_**

Loans under the Senior Term Facilities initially bear interest at a per annum rate to be determined. Loans
under the Revolving Credit Facility initially bear interest at a per annum rate to be determined and (in the case
of utilizations in euro) EURIBOR or (in the case of utilizations in U.S. dollar) LIBOR or (in the case of
utilizations in pound sterling) SONIA, as applicable.

The margin for each loan under the Senior Term Facilities and the Revolving Credit Facility will be
subject to adjustment by reference to the applicable consolidated senior secured leverage ratio.

The margin on any loans under a Senior Incremental Facility will be agreed between the Parent and the
relevant lenders.

If EURIBOR, LIBOR or SONIA (as applicable) is less than zero, EURIBOR, LIBOR or SONIA (as
applicable) shall be deemed to be zero in respect of any loan under the Senior Facilities Agreement.

Commitment fees are payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving Credit
Facility for the relevant periods set out in the Senior Facilities Agreement at a rate of 30% of the applicable
margin. Generally, the commitment fee is payable quarterly in arrear, on the last day of availability of the
Revolving Credit Facility and if cancelled, on the cancelled amount of the relevant lender’s commitment
under the Revolving Credit Facility at the time such cancelation is effective.

Default interest is calculated as an additional 1% per annum on any overdue amount. The Parent is also
required to pay (or procure the payment of) customary agency and arrangement fees in connection with the
Senior Facilities.

**_Repayment_**

All outstanding amounts under the Senior Facilities are required to be repaid on the relevant maturity
dates referred to above. Loans under the Revolving Credit Facility must be repaid on the last day of the
interest period relating thereto, subject to a netting mechanism against new loans under the Revolving Credit
Facility to be drawn on such date.

The termination date in respect of a Senior Incremental Facilities will be the date agreed between the
Parent and the relevant lenders.


-----

**_Prepayment_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement allows for voluntary prepayments (subject to a minimum amount and
certain conditions). A voluntary prepayment of the Senior Term Facilities, or an amendment of its terms, in
each case in connection with a re-pricing in the first six months after closing date may trigger a prepayment
fee as set out and calculated in the Senior Facilities Agreement.

The Senior Facilities Agreement also permits each lender to require the mandatory prepayment of all
amounts due to that lender upon a change of control of the Parent or a sale of the whole or substantially the
whole of the business and assets of the restricted group. Pursuant to the asset disposition covenant, the Senior
Facilities Agreement also requires the Parent to prepay the Senior Facilities with the net proceeds received
from certain disposals (subject to certain exceptions and reinvestment rights).

**_Guarantees_**

The Senior Facilities are guaranteed by the Guarantors and the Issuer.

The Senior Facilities Agreement includes a “Guarantor Coverage Threshold” (being, subject to certain
exceptions, the requirement that the consolidated EBITDA of the Guarantors represents not less than 80% of
the consolidated EBITDA of the restricted group excluding any member of the restricted group that is not
required to become a guarantor in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles). If the Guarantor
Coverage Threshold is not met when tested by reference to delivery of the annual financial statements of the
Parent for the relevant year, within 60 days each Material Company that is not already a guarantor (together
with such other members of the restricted group as necessary) shall become guarantors under the Senior
Facilities Agreement in order to meet the Guarantor Coverage Threshold at that time. “Material Company”
is generally defined under the Senior Facilities Agreement to include, among other things, any member of the
restricted group that is incorporated or established in a Security Jurisdiction and that has earnings before
interest, tax, depreciation and amortization representing more than 5% of consolidated EBITDA of the
restricted group. “Security Jurisdiction” is defined in the Agreed Security Principles as being (i) England and
Wales, and (ii) any other jurisdiction in which, based upon the most recent annual financial statements
delivered under the Senior Facilities Agreement, members of the restricted group incorporated in that
jurisdiction (disregarding the earnings from ordinary activities before interest, taxation, depreciation,
amortization and exceptional items (calculated on the same basis as Consolidated EBITDA, mutatis mutandis)
(“Jurisdiction Entity EBITDA”) of any such member of the restricted group that generates negative
Jurisdiction Entity EBITDA) account for 15 per cent. or more of consolidated EBITDA of the restricted
group. The Agreed Security Principles provide that no member of the restricted group incorporated or
established outside of a Security Jurisdiction shall be required to provide any guarantee or security (unless
such member is a borrower of a Senior Facility) and no member of the restricted group shall be required to
provide any security in respect of any shares or other ownership interests held in any member of the restricted
group incorporated or established outside of a Security Jurisdiction or any member of the restricted group
which is not an obligor under the Senior Facilities Agreement.

**_Security_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement is secured by the same security interests granted as security for the
Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Security—The Collateral.”

**_Representations and Warranties_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain customary representations and warranties (subject to
certain exceptions and qualifications and with certain representations and warranties being repeated),
including status, binding obligations, non-conflict with other obligations, power and authority, validity and
admissibility in evidence and authorizations, governing law and enforcement, insolvency, no default, no
misleading information, financial model and accounts, disputes and litigation, compliance with laws,
environmental compliance, taxation, security and indebtedness, title to assets, share capital, pensions,
intellectual property, group structure, pari passu ranking, sanctions and anti-corruption laws and insurances.

**_Covenants_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain of the incurrence covenants and related definitions
(with certain adjustments) that are included in the section entitled “Description of the Notes—Certain
_Covenants”_


-----

The Senior Facilities Agreement also requires certain members of the restricted group to observe certain
affirmative covenants, including covenants relating to maintenance of authorizations, compliance with laws,
environmental compliance, payment of taxes, preservation of intellectual property, pari passu ranking, funding
of pensions, maintenance of insurances, further assurance with respect to security interests granted, sanctions
and anti-corruption, access upon an event of default, maintenance of a credit rating, maintenance of
Guarantor Coverage Threshold on an annual basis (see “—Guarantees” above), as well as a limitation on
speculative hedging transactions.

In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement contains a financial covenant for the benefit of the lenders
under the Revolving Credit Facility (see “—Financial Covenant”).

Certain of the covenants under the Senior Facilities Agreement will be suspended including upon an
initial public offering where the consolidated senior secured leverage ratio is equal to or less than 3.50:1, or
upon the Parent receiving Investment Grade Status (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement).

The Senior Facilities Agreement also contains an “information covenant” under which, among other
things, the Parent is required to deliver to the Senior Facilities Agent annual financial statements, quarterly
financial statements, an annual budget and compliance certificates. In addition, the Parent may be requested
to hold an annual presentation pursuant to the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement.

**_Financial Covenant_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement requires, for the benefit of the lenders under the Revolving Credit
Facility that the consolidated senior secured leverage ratio in respect of each period of twelve months ending
on any quarter date (the “Consolidated Senior Secured Leverage Ratio”) shall not be greater than 9.50:1.00 for
any quarter date ending on or about 30 March 2022 and 30 June 2022, and not greater than 9.25:1.00 for any
quarter dates ending on 30 September 2022 and thereafter, provided that this financial covenant is only to be
tested if on the last day of such period, the amount drawn loans under the Revolving Credit Facility is greater
than 40% of the total Revolving Credit Facility commitments.

The Parent is permitted (subject to certain conditions) to prevent or cure breaches of the Consolidated
Senior Secured Leverage Ratio covenant by applying a “cure” amount (generally, amounts received by the
Parent in cash pursuant to any new equity or permitted subordinated debt) as if consolidated EBITDA had
been increased by such amount or consolidated senior secured leverage had been reduced by such amount.
There is no requirement to apply any cure amount in prepayment of the Revolving Facilities. No more than
four different cure amounts may be taken into account prior to the maturity date of the Senior Facilities
Agreement and cure amounts in consecutive financial quarters are not permitted.

**_Events of Default_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains a limited number of events of default (misrepresentation,
unlawfulness, invalidity, rescission and repudiation, and (for the benefit of the lenders under the Revolving
Credit Facility only) a failure to comply with the financial covenant ), subject in certain cases to agreed grace
periods and other qualifications. Additionally, the Senior Facilities Agreement has events of default
substantially similar to those applicable to the Notes, subject to certain cases to agreed grace periods and
other qualifications.

**_Governing Law_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement is governed by English law.

**Second Lien Facility Agreement**

The Second Lien Facility Agreement provides for a second lien term loan credit facility in the amount of
£325,000,000 (the “Second Lien Facility”). The Second Lien Facility is to be used for the refinancing and
discharge of existing indebtedness of the Parent and its restricted subsidiaries, to make a distribution to the
direct parent company of the Parent, to fund transaction costs and as to any remaining balance the general
corporate purposes and working capital purposes of the Parent and its restricted subsidiaries.

In addition, the Parent may elect to request additional facilities either as a new facility or as additional
tranches of the Second Lien Facility (the “Second Lien Incremental Facilities”). The Parent and the lenders in
respect of the Second Lien Incremental Facilities may agree to certain terms in relation to the Second Lien
Incremental Facilities, including the margin and the termination date (subject to parameters as set out in the


-----

Second Lien Facility Agreement). The indebtedness incurred under the Second Lien Incremental Facilities
must be otherwise permitted under the Second Lien Facility Agreement.

**_Maturity_**

The Second Lien Facility matures on the date falling 96 months after Issue Date.

**_Interest and Fees_**

Loans under the Second Lien Facility Agreement bear interest at a per annum rate to be determined and
SONIA plus a spread adjustment (if any is agreed).

The margin on any loans under a Second Lien Incremental Facilities will be agreed between the Parent
and the relevant lenders.

If SONIA (as applicable) is less than zero, SONIA (as applicable) shall be deemed to be zero in respect of
any loan under the Second Lien Facility Agreement.

Default interest is calculated as an additional 1% per annum on any overdue amount.

The Parent is also required to pay (or procure the payment of) customary agency and arrangement fees in
connection with the Second Lien Facility.

**_Repayment_**

All outstanding amounts under the Second Lien Facility are required to be repaid on the maturity date
referred to above.

The termination date in respect of a Second Lien Incremental Facilities will be the date agreed between
the Parent and the relevant lenders.

**_Prepayment_**

The Second Lien Facility Agreement allows for voluntary prepayments (subject to a minimum amount
and certain conditions).

The Second Lien Facility Agreement also permits each lender to require the mandatory prepayment of
all amounts due to that lender upon a change of control of the Parent or a sale of the whole or substantially
the whole of the business and assets of the restricted group. The asset dispositions covenant in the Second
Lien Facility Agreement also requires the Parent to prepay the Second Lien Facility with the net proceeds
received from certain disposals (subject to certain exceptions and reinvestment rights).

Subject to certain exceptions, if the Second Lien Facility is voluntarily prepaid (or mandatorily prepaid
upon a change of control) before the date falling 24 months after the first utilization of the Second Lien
Facility, the Parent is required to pay (or procure that another member of the restricted group will pay) a
prepayment fee as set out and calculated under the Second Lien Facility Agreement.

**_Guarantees_**

The Second Lien Facility Agreement is guaranteed by the same entities that guarantee the Senior
Facilities. See “—Senior Facilities Agreement—Guarantees” above.

The Second Lien Facility Agreement includes a “Guarantor Coverage Threshold” (being, subject to
certain exceptions, the requirement that the consolidated EBITDA of the Guarantors represents not less than
80% of the consolidated EBITDA of the restricted group excluding any member of the restricted group that
is not required to become a guarantor in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles). In addition, if the
Guarantor Coverage Threshold is not met when tested by reference to delivery of the annual financial
statements of the Parent for the relevant year, within 60 days each Material Company that is not already a
guarantor (together with such other members of the restricted group as necessary) shall become guarantors
under the Second Lien Facility Agreement in order to meet the Guarantor Coverage Threshold at that time.
“Material Company” is generally defined under the Second Lien Facility Agreement to include, among other
things, any member of the restricted group that is incorporated or established in a Security Jurisdiction and
that has earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization representing more than 5% of
consolidated EBITDA of the restricted group. “Security Jurisdiction” is defined in the Agreed Security


-----

Principles as being (i) England and Wales, and (ii) any other jurisdiction in which, based upon the most recent
annual financial statements delivered under the Second Lien Facility ties Agreement, members of the restricted
group incorporated in that jurisdiction (disregarding the earnings from ordinary activities before interest,
taxation, depreciation, amortization and exceptional items (calculated on the same basis as Consolidated
EBITDA, mutatis mutandis) (“Jurisdiction Entity EBITDA”) of any such member of the restricted group
that generates negative Jurisdiction Entity EBITDA) account for 15 per cent. or more of consolidated
EBITDA of the restricted group. The Agreed Security Principles provide that no member of the restricted
group incorporated or established outside of a Security Jurisdiction shall be required to provide any guarantee
or security (unless such member is a borrower of the Second Lien Facility) and no member of the restricted
group shall be required to provide any security in respect of any shares or other ownership interests held in
any member of the restricted group incorporated or established outside of a Security Jurisdiction or any
member of the restricted group which is not an obligor under the Second Lien Facility Agreement.

**_Security_**

The Second Lien Facility Agreement is secured by the same security interests granted as security for the
Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Security—The Collateral.”

**_Representations and Warranties_**

The Second Lien Facility Agreement contains the same customary representations and warranties as the
Senior Facilities Agreement (subject to certain exceptions and qualifications and with certain representations
and warranties being repeated).

**_Covenants_**

The Second Lien Facility Agreement contains the same incurrence covenants and related definitions
(with certain adjustments) that are included in the Senior Facilities Agreement.

The Second Lien Facility Agreement also requires certain members of the restricted group to observe
certain affirmative covenants, including covenants relating to maintenance of authorizations, compliance
with laws, environmental compliance, payment of taxes, preservation of intellectual property, pari passu
ranking, funding of pensions, maintenance of insurances, further assurance with respect to security interests
granted, sanctions and anti-corruption, access upon an event of default, maintenance of Guarantor Coverage
Threshold on an annual basis (see “—Guarantees” above), as well as a limitation on speculative hedging
transactions and a customary anti-layering covenant.

Certain of the covenants under the Second Lien Facility Agreement will be suspended including upon an
initial public offering where the consolidated senior secured leverage ratio is equal to or less than 3.75:1, or
upon the Parent receiving Investment Grade Status (as defined in the Second Lien Facility Agreement).

The Second Lien Facility Agreement also contains an “information covenant”under which, among other
things, the Parent is required to deliver to the Second Lien Facility Agent annual financial statements,
quarterly financial statements, an annual budget and compliance certificates. In addition, the Parent may be
requested to hold an annual presentation pursuant to the terms of the Second Lien Facility Agreement.

**_Events of Default_**

The Second Lien Facility Agreement contains a limited number of events of default (misrepresentation,
unlawfulness, invalidity, rescission and repudiation), subject in certain cases to agreed grace periods and other
qualifications. Additionally, the Second Lien Facility Agreement has events of default substantially similar to
those applicable to the Notes, subject in certain cases to agreed grace periods and other qualifications.

**_Governing law_**

The Second Lien Facility Agreement is governed by English law.

**Intercreditor Agreement**

**_General_**

To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements, the Issuer,
the Parent and certain other members of the Group which have acceded or otherwise become a party to the


-----

Intercreditor Agreement as a debtor (together the “Debtors”) are parties to the Intercreditor Agreement dated
on or around the Issue Date between, among others, HSBC Bank plc as Senior Facility Agent and Second
Lien Facility Agent, HSBC Corporate Trustee Company (UK) Limited as Security Agent and GLAS Trust
Company LLC (the “Senior Notes Trustee”). The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law and
sets out, among other things, the relative ranking of certain indebtedness of the Debtors, the relative ranking
of certain security granted by the Debtors, when payments can be made in respect of certain debt of the
Debtors, when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that indebtedness, the terms pursuant to which
certain of that indebtedness will be subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and
turnover provisions.

Capitalized terms set forth and used in this summary of the Intercreditor Agreement may have different
meanings from that given to such terms and used elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Definitions_**

The following capitalized terms used in this summary of the Intercreditor Agreement have the meaning
given to them below:

“Agent” means each of any Senior Agent, Second Lien Agent, Senior Parent Agent and the Security
Agent, as the context requires.

“Creditors” means the Senior Secured Creditors, the Second Lien Secured Creditors, the Senior Parent
Creditors, the Hedge Counterparties, the Intra-Group Lenders and the Investors.

“Debtor” means any person that is a party to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Debtor.

“Group” means Constellation Automotive Group Limited and its Restricted Subsidiaries.

“Hedge Counterparty” means any person that executes or accedes to the Intercreditor Agreement as a
Hedge Counterparty.

“Hedging Liabilities” means the liabilities owed by any Debtor to Hedge Counterparties in respect of
certain hedging agreements.

“Insolvency Event” means, generally, certain events of insolvency in relation to any company that is a
member of the Group.

“Intra-Group Lender” means each Debtor which has made a loan available to, granted credit to or made
any other financial arrangement having similar effect with another Debtor and which is a party to the
Intercreditor Agreement as an Intra-Group Lender.

“Investor” means any person that is a party to the Intercreditor Agreement as an Investor.

“Majority Permitted Parent Financing Creditors” means, in relation to any Permitted Parent Financing
Debt, the requisite number or percentage of Permitted Parent Financing Creditors under the Permitted Parent
Financing Agreement on whose instructions the Permitted Parent Financing Creditor Representative is
required to act in relation to the relevant matter.

“Majority Permitted Second Lien Financing Creditors” means, in relation to any Permitted Second Lien
Financing Debt, the requisite number or percentage of Permitted Second Lien Financing Creditors under the
Permitted Second Lien Financing Agreement on whose instructions the Permitted Second Lien Financing
Creditor Representative is required to act in relation to the relevant matter.

“Majority Permitted Senior Financing Creditors” means, in relation to any Permitted Senior Financing
Debt, the requisite number or percentage of Permitted Senior Financing Creditors under the Permitted Senior
Financing Agreement on whose instructions the Permitted Senior Financing Creditor Representative is
required to act in relation to the relevant matter.

“Majority Second Lien Facility Lenders” means, at any time, subject to certain provisions of the Second
Lien Facility Agreement, a Second Lien Facility Lender or Second Lien Facility Lenders whose commitments
under the Second Lien Facility Agreement aggregate more than 50 per cent. of the total commitments under
the Second Lien Facility Agreement (or if the total commitments under the Second Lien Facility Agreement
have been reduced to zero, aggregated more than 50 per cent. of the total commitments under the Second Lien
Facility Agreement immediately prior to that reduction).


-----

“Majority Senior Lenders” means, at any time, subject to certain provisions of the Senior Facilities
Agreement, a Senior Lender or Senior Lenders whose commitments under the Senior Facilities Agreement
aggregate more than 50 per cent. of the total commitments under the Senior Facilities Agreement (or if the
total commitments under the Senior Facilities Agreement have been reduced to zero, aggregated more than 50
per cent. of the total commitments under the Senior Facilities Agreement immediately prior to that reduction).

“Material Event of Default”means, generally, certain events of default relating to insolvency proceedings,
failure to pay judgement debt and invalidity, ineffectiveness or unlawfulness of security, under each of the
Senior Facilities Agreement (prior to the Senior Facilities Discharge Date), the Senior Notes Indenture (prior
to the Senior Notes Discharge Date) and any Permitted Senior Financing Agreement (prior to the Permitted
Senior Financing Discharge Date).

“Operating Facility” means any facility or financial accommodation (including, without limitation, any
overdraft or other current account facility, any foreign exchange facility, any guarantee, bonding, documentary
or standby letter of credit facility, any credit card or automated payments facility, any short term loan facility,
any derivatives facility, any cash pooling arrangement or other cash management arrangement, chequing or
note encashment facility) provided to a member of the Group by an Operating Facility Lender which is
notified to the Security Agent by the Parent in writing as a facility or financial accommodation to be treated
as an “Operating Facility” for the purposes of the Intercreditor Agreement.

“Operating Facility Document” means, at the election of the Parent, any document relating to or

“Operating Facility Lender”means any person that executes or accedes to the Intercreditor Agreement as
an Operating Facility Lender.

“Operating Facility Liabilities”means the liabilities owed by any Debtor to the Operating Facility Lenders

“Permitted Parent Financing Agreement” means, in relation to any Permitted Parent Financing Debt, the

“Permitted Parent Financing Creditor Representative” means, in relation to any Permitted Parent

“Secured Creditors” means the Senior Secured Creditors and the Second Lien Secured Creditors.

“Secured Debt Documents” means the Operating Facility Documents, the Hedging Agreements, the

and/or the Permitted Parent Financing Documents, as the context requires.

“Secured Party” means, to the extent legally possible and subject to the Agreed Security Principles, each
of the Security Agent, any receiver or delegate and each of the creditor representatives of the relevant secured

Lenders, the Secured Creditors and the Senior Parent Creditors from time to time but, to the extent required
by the Intercreditor Agreement, only if it is a party to the Intercreditor Agreement or has acceded to it, in the

“Senior Agent” means each of the Senior Facility Agent, any Senior Notes Trustee and/or any Permitted

“Senior Arranger” means any arranger of the credit facilities under the Senior Facilities Agreement.

“Senior Debt Documents” means, generally, the finance documents in relation to the Senior Facilities

-----

“Senior Discharge Date” means the first date on which each of the Senior Facilities Discharge Date, the

“Senior Event of Default” means an event of default (howsoever described) under any Senior Debt

“Senior Facility Agent” means the agent under the Senior Facilities Agreement.

“Senior Facilities Discharge Date” means the first date on which all Senior Facilities Liabilities have been
